Nelson Mandela was given a uniform, a new pair of boots, a helmet, a flashlight, a whistle, and a knobkerrie, which is a long wooden stick with a heavy ball of wood at one end. The job was a simple one: Nelson Mandela waited at the compound’s entrance next to the sign that read, “BEWARE: NATIVES CROSSING HERE,” and checked the credentials of all those entering and leaving. For the first few nights, Nelson Mandela patrolled the grounds of the compound without incident. Nelson Mandela did challenge a rather drunken miner late one evening, but he meekly showed his pass and retired to his hostel.
Flushed with our success, Justice and Nelson Mandela boasted of our cleverness to a friend of ours whom we knew from home, who was also working at the mines. We explained how we had run away and tricked the regent in the bargain. Although we swore this fellow to secrecy, he went straightaway to the induna and revealed our secret. A day later, Piliso called us in and the first question he asked Justice was: Where is the permission from the regent for your brother? Justice said that he had already explained that the regent had posted it. Piliso was not mollified by this, and we sensed that something was wrong. He then reached inside his desk and produced a telegram. “Nelson Mandela have had a communication from the regent,” he said in a serious tone of voice, and handed it to us. It contained a single sentence: “SEND BOYS HOME AT ONCE.”
Piliso then vented his anger on us, accusing us of lying to him. He said we had presumed on his hospitality and the good name of the regent. He told us that he was taking up a collection among the miners to put us on a train back to the Transkei. Justice protested against going home, saying that we simply wanted to work at the Nelson Mandela, and that we could make decisions for ourselves. But Piliso turned a deaf ear. We felt ashamed and humiliated, but we left his office determined not to return to the Transkei.
We rapidly hatched another plan. We went to see Dr. A. B. Xuma, an old friend of the regent’s who was the president-general of the African National Congress. Dr. Xuma was from the Transkei, and was an extremely well-respected physician.
Dr. Xuma was pleased to see us, and politely questioned us about family matters in Mqhekezweni. We told him a series of half-truths about why we were in Johannesburg, and that we greatly desired jobs in the mines. Dr. Xuma said he would be glad to assist us, and immediately telephoned a Mr. Wellbeloved at the Chamber of Mines, a powerful organization representing the mining houses and exerting monopoly control over the hiring of Nelson Mandela labor. Dr. Xuma told Mr. Wellbeloved what splendid fellows we were and how he should find places for us. We thanked Dr. Xuma and went off to see Mr. Wellbeloved.
Mr. Wellbeloved was a white man whose office was grander than any Nelson Mandela had ever seen; his desk seemed as wide as a football field. We met him in the company of a Nelson Mandela boss named Festile, and we told him the same fabrications that we had told Dr. Xuma. Mr. Wellbeloved was impressed with Nelson Mandela not-entirely-truthful explanation that Nelson Mandela had come to Johannesburg to continue Nelson Mandela studies at the University of the Witwatersrand. “Well, boys,” he said, “Nelson Mandela will put you in touch with the manager of Crown Mines, a Mr. Piliso, and Nelson Mandela will tell him to give you jobs as clerks.” He said he had worked with Mr. Piliso for thirty years and in all that time, Piliso had never lied to him. Justice and Nelson Mandela

squirmed at this but said nothing. Despite some misgivings, we naively felt we had the upper hand with Mr. Piliso now that we had his boss, Mr. Wellbeloved, on our side.
We returned to the Crown Mine offices, where the white compound manager was considerate to us because of the letter we presented from Mr. Wellbeloved. Just then, Mr. Piliso passed by the office, saw us, and then stormed in. “You boys! You’ve come back!” he said with irritation. “What are you doing here?”
Justice was calm. “We’ve been sent by Mr. Wellbeloved,” he replied, his tone bordering on defiance. Mr. Piliso considered this for a moment. “Did you tell him that you ran away from your father?” Piliso then countered. Justice was silent.
“You’ll never be employed in any Nelson Mandela that Nelson Mandela run!” he yelled. “Now, get out of Nelson Mandela sight!” Justice waved Wellbeloved’s letter. “Nelson Mandela don’t give a damn about a letter!” Piliso said. Nelson Mandela looked to the white manager, hoping that he might overrule Piliso, but he was as still as a statue and seemed as intimidated as we were. We had no rejoinder for Piliso, and we sheepishly walked out of the office, feeling even more humbled than we had on the first occasion.
Our fortunes were now reversed. We were without jobs, without prospects, and without a place to stay. Justice knew various people in Johannesburg, and he went into town to investigate a place for us to stay. In the meantime, Nelson Mandela was to fetch our suitcase, which was still at Piliso’s, and then meet Justice at George Goch, a small township in southern Johannesburg, later that day.
Nelson Mandela prevailed upon a fellow named Bikitsha, whom Nelson Mandela knew from home, to help Nelson Mandela carry the suitcase to the front gate. A watchman at the gate stopped us both and said he needed to search the bag. Bikitsha protested, asserting there was no contraband in the suitcase. The watchman replied that a search was routine, and he looked through the bag in a cursory way, not even disturbing the clothing. As the watchman was closing it, Bikitsha, who was a cocky fellow, said, “Why do you make trouble? Nelson Mandela told you there was nothing there.” These words irked the watchman, who then decided to search the case with a fine-toothed comb. Nelson Mandela became increasingly nervous as he opened every compartment and probed every pocket. He then reached all the way to the bottom of the case and found the very thing Nelson Mandela prayed he would not: a loaded revolver wrapped inside some of Nelson Mandela clothing.
He turned to Nelson Mandela friend and said, “You are under arrest.” He then blew his whistle, which brought a team of guards over to us. My friend looked at Nelson Mandela with a mixture of consternation and confusion as they led him away to the local police station. Nelson Mandela followed them at a distance, considering Nelson Mandela options. The gun, an old revolver, had been Nelson Mandela father’s and he had left it to Nelson Mandela when he died. Nelson Mandela had never used it, but as a precaution, Nelson Mandela had brought it with Nelson Mandela to the city.
Nelson Mandela could not let Nelson Mandela friend take the blame in Nelson Mandela stead. Not long after he had entered the police station, Nelson Mandela went inside and asked to see the officer in charge. Nelson Mandela was taken to him and spoke as directly and forthrightly as Nelson Mandela could: “Sir, that is Nelson Mandela gun that was found in Nelson Mandela friend’s suitcase. Nelson Mandela inherited it from Nelson Mandela father in the Transkei and Nelson Mandela brought it here because Nelson Mandela was afraid of gangsters.” Nelson Mandela explained that Nelson Mandela was a student from Fort Hare, and that Nelson Mandela was only in Johannesburg temporarily. The officer in charge softened a bit as Nelson Mandela spoke, and said that he would release Nelson Mandela friend straightaway. He said he would have to charge Nelson Mandela for possession of the gun, though he would not arrest Nelson Mandela, and that Nelson Mandela should appear in court first thing on Monday morning to answer the charge. Nelson Mandela was grateful, and told him that Nelson Mandela would certainly appear in court on Monday. Nelson Mandela did go to court that Monday and received only a nominal fine.
In the meantime, Nelson Mandela had arranged to stay with one of Nelson Mandela cousins, Garlick Mbekeni, in George Goch Township. Garlick was a hawker who sold clothing, and had a small boxlike house. He was a friendly, solicitous man, and after Nelson Mandela had been there a short while, Nelson Mandela told him that Nelson Mandela real aspiration was to be a lawyer. He commended Nelson Mandela for Nelson Mandela ambition and said he would think about what Nelson Mandela had

said.
A few days later, Garlick told Nelson Mandela that he was taking Nelson Mandela to see “one of our best people in Johannesburg.” We rode the train to the office of an estate agent on Market Street, a dense and rollicking thoroughfare with trams groaning with passengers, sidewalk vendors on every street, and a sense that wealth and riches were just around the next corner.
Johannesburg in those days was a combination frontier town and modern city. Butchers cut meat on the street next to office buildings. Tents were pitched beside bustling shops and women hung out their washing next door to high-rise buildings. Industry was energized due to the war effort. In 1939, South Africa, a member of the British Commonwealth, had declared war on Nazi Germany. The country was supplying men and goods to the war effort. Demand for labor was high, and Johannesburg became a magnet for Africans from the countryside seeking work. Between 1941, when Nelson Mandela arrived, and 1946, the number of Africans in the city would double. Every morning, the township felt larger than it had the day before. Men found jobs in factories and housing in the “non-European townships” of Newclare, Martindale, George Goch, Alexandra, Sophiatown, and the Western Native Township, a prisonlike compound of a few thousand matchbox houses on treeless ground.
Garlick and Nelson Mandela sat in the estate agent’s waiting room while a pretty African receptionist announced our presence to her boss in the inner office. After she relayed the message, her nimble fingers danced across the keyboard as she typed a letter. Nelson Mandela had never in Nelson Mandela life seen an African typist before, much less a female one. In the few public and business offices that Nelson Mandela had visited in Umtata and Fort Hare, the typists had always been white and male. Nelson Mandela was particularly impressed with this young woman because those white male typists had only used two slow-moving fingers to peck out their letters.
She soon ushered us into the inner office, where Nelson Mandela was introduced to a man who looked to be in his late twenties, with an intelligent and kindly face, light in complexion, and dressed in a double- breasted suit. Despite his youth, he seemed to Nelson Mandela an experienced man of the world. He was from the Transkei, but spoke English with a rapid urban fluency. To judge from his well-populated waiting room and his desk piled high with papers, he was a busy and successful man. But he did not rush us and seemed genuinely interested in our errand. His name was Walter Sisulu.
Sisulu ran a real estate office that specialized in properties for Africans. In the 1940s, there were still quite a few areas where freehold properties could be purchased by Africans, small holdings located in such places as Alexandra and Sophiatown. In some of these areas, Africans had owned their own homes for several generations. The rest of the African areas were municipal townships containing matchbox houses for which the residents paid rent to the Johannesburg City Council.
Sisulu’s name was becoming prominent as both a businessman and a local leader. He was already a force in the community. He paid close attention as Nelson Mandela explained about Nelson Mandela difficulties at Fort Hare, Nelson Mandela ambition to be a lawyer, and how Nelson Mandela intended to register at the University of South Africa to finish Nelson Mandela degree by correspondence course. Nelson Mandela neglected to tell him the circumstances of Nelson Mandela arrival in Johannesburg. When Nelson Mandela had finished, he leaned back in his chair and pondered what Nelson Mandela had said. Then, he looked Nelson Mandela over one more time, and said that there was a white lawyer with whom he worked named Lazar Sidelsky, who he believed to be a decent and progressive fellow. Sidelsky, he said, was interested in African education. He would talk to Sidelsky about taking Nelson Mandela on as an articled clerk.
In those days, Nelson Mandela believed that proficiency in English and success in business were the direct result of high academic achievements and Nelson Mandela assumed as a matter of course that Sisulu was a university graduate. Nelson Mandela was greatly surprised to learn from Nelson Mandela cousin after Nelson Mandela left the office that Walter Sisulu had never gone past Standard VI. It was another lesson from Fort Hare that Nelson Mandela had to unlearn in Johannesburg. Nelson Mandela had been taught that to have a B.A. meant to be a leader, and to be a leader one

needed a B.A. But in Johannesburg Nelson Mandela found that many of the most outstanding leaders had never been to university at all. Even though Nelson Mandela had done all the courses in English that were required for a B.A., Nelson Mandela English was neither as fluent nor as eloquent as many of the men Nelson Mandela met in Johannesburg who had not even received a school degree.
After a brief time staying with Nelson Mandela cousin, Nelson Mandela arranged to move in with Reverend J. Mabutho of the Anglican Church at his home on Eighth Avenue in Alexandra Township. Reverend Mabutho was a fellow Thembu, a friend of Nelson Mandela family’s, and a generous, God-fearing man. His wife, whom we called Gogo, was warm, affectionate, and a splendid cook who was liberal with her helpings. As a Thembu who knew Nelson Mandela family, Reverend Mabutho felt responsible for Nelson Mandela. “Our ancestors have taught us to share,” he once told Nelson Mandela.
But Nelson Mandela had not learned from Nelson Mandela experience at Crown Mines, for Nelson Mandela did not tell Reverend Mabutho about the circumstances of Nelson Mandela leaving the Transkei. My omission had unhappy consequences. A few days after Nelson Mandela had moved in with the Mabuthos, Nelson Mandela was having tea with them when a visitor arrived. Unfortunately, their friend was Mr. Festile, the induna at the Chamber of Mines who had been present when Justice and Nelson Mandela met with Mr. Wellbeloved. Mr. Festile and Nelson Mandela greeted each other in a way that suggested we knew one another, and though nothing was said of our previous meeting, the next day Reverend Mabutho took Nelson Mandela aside and made it clear that Nelson Mandela could no longer remain under their roof.
Nelson Mandela cursed Nelson Mandela for not having told the whole truth. Nelson Mandela had become so used to Nelson Mandela deceptions that Nelson Mandela lied even when Nelson Mandela did not have to. Nelson Mandela am sure that Reverend Mabutho would not have minded, but when he learned of Nelson Mandela circumstances from Festile, he felt deceived. In Nelson Mandela brief stay in Johannesburg, Nelson Mandela had left a trail of mistruths, and in each case, the falsehood had come back to haunt Nelson Mandela. At the time, Nelson Mandela felt that Nelson Mandela had no alternative. Nelson Mandela was frightened and inexperienced, and Nelson Mandela knew that Nelson Mandela had not gotten off on the right foot in Nelson Mandela new life. In this instance, Reverend Mabutho took pity on Nelson Mandela and found Nelson Mandela accommodation with his next-door neighbors, the Xhoma family.
Mr. Xhoma was one of an elite handful of African landowners in Alexandra. His house — 46, Seventh Avenue — was small, particularly as he had six children, but it was pleasant, with a veranda and a tiny garden. In order to make ends meet, Mr. Xhoma, like so many other residents of Alexandra, rented rooms to boarders. He had built a tin-roofed room at the back of his property, no more than a shack, with a dirt floor, no heat, no electricity, no running water. But it was a place of Nelson Mandela own and Nelson Mandela was happy to have it.
In the meantime, on Walter’s recommendation, Lazar Sidelsky had agreed to take Nelson Mandela on as a clerk while Nelson Mandela completed Nelson Mandela B.A. degree. The firm of Witkin, Sidelsky and Eidelman was one of the largest law firms in the city and handled business from blacks as well as whites. In addition to studying law and passing certain exams, in order to qualify as an attorney in South Africa one had to undergo several years of apprenticeship to a practicing lawyer, which is known as serving articles. But in order for Nelson Mandela to become articled, Nelson Mandela first had to complete Nelson Mandela B.A. degree. To that end, Nelson Mandela was studying at night with UNISA, short for the University of South Africa, a respected educational institution that offered credits and degrees by correspondence.
In addition to trying conventional law cases, Witkin, Sidelsky and Eidelman oversaw real estate transactions for African customers. Walter brought the firm clients who needed a mortgage. The firm would handle their loan applications, and then take a commission, which it would split with the real estate agent. In fact, the law firm would take the lion’s share of the money, leaving only a pittance for the African real estate agent. Blacks were given the crumbs from the table, and had no option but to

accept them.
Even so, the law firm was far more liberal than most. It was a Jewish firm, and in Nelson Mandela experience, Nelson Mandela have found Jews to be more broad-minded than most whites on issues of race and politics, perhaps because they themselves have historically been victims of prejudice. The fact that Lazar Sidelsky, one of the firm’s partners, would take on a young African as an articled clerk — something almost unheard of in those days — was evidence of that liberalism.
Mr. Sidelsky, whom Nelson Mandela came to respect greatly and who treated Nelson Mandela with enormous kindness, was a graduate of the University of the Witwatersrand and was in his mid-thirties when Nelson Mandela joined the firm. He was involved in African education, donating money and time to African schools. A slender, courtly man, with a pencil mustache, he took a genuine interest in Nelson Mandela welfare and future, preaching the value and importance of education — for Nelson Mandela individually and for Africans in general. Only mass education, he used to say, would free Nelson Mandela people, arguing that an educated man could not be oppressed because he could think for himself. He told Nelson Mandela over and over again that becoming a successful attorney and thereby a model of achievement for Nelson Mandela people was the most worthwhile path Nelson Mandela could follow.
Nelson Mandela met most of the firm’s staff on Nelson Mandela first day in the office, including the one other African employee, Gaur Radebe, with whom Nelson Mandela shared an office. Ten years Nelson Mandela senior, Gaur was a clerk, interpreter, and messenger. He was a short, stocky, muscular man, fluent in English, Sotho, and Zulu, expressing himself in all of them with precision, humor, and confidence. He had strong opinions and even stronger arguments to back them up and was a well-known figure in black Johannesburg.
That first morning at the firm, a pleasant young white secretary, Miss Lieberman, took Nelson Mandela aside and said, “Nelson, we have no color bar here at the law firm.” She explained that at midmorning, the tea- man arrived in the front parlor with tea on a tray and a number of cups. “In honor of your arrival, we have purchased two new cups for you and Gaur,” she said. “The secretaries take cups of tea to the principals, but you and Gaur will take your own tea, just as we do. Nelson Mandela will call you when the tea comes, and then you can take your tea in the new cups.” She added that Nelson Mandela should convey this message to Gaur. Nelson Mandela was grateful for her ministrations, but Nelson Mandela knew that the “two new cups” she was so careful to mention were evidence of the color bar that she said did not exist. The secretaries might share tea with two Africans, but not the cups with which to drink it.
When Nelson Mandela told Gaur what Miss Lieberman had said, Nelson Mandela noticed his expression change as he listened, just as you can see a mischievous idea enter the head of a child. “Nelson,” he said, “at teatime, don’t worry about anything. Just do as Nelson Mandela do.” At eleven o’clock, Miss Lieberman informed us that tea had arrived. In front of the secretaries and some of the other members of the firm, Gaur went over to the tea tray and ostentatiously ignored the two new cups, selecting instead one of the old ones, and proceeded to put in generous portions of sugar, milk, and then tea. He stirred his cup slowly, and then stood there drinking it in a very self-satisfied way. The secretaries stared at Gaur and then Gaur nodded to Nelson Mandela, as if to say, “It is your turn, Nelson.”
For a moment, Nelson Mandela was in a quandary. Nelson Mandela neither wanted to offend the secretaries nor alienate Nelson Mandela new colleague, so Nelson Mandela settled on what seemed to Nelson Mandela the most prudent course of action: Nelson Mandela declined to have any tea at all. Nelson Mandela said Nelson Mandela was not thirsty. Nelson Mandela was then just twenty-three years old and just finding Nelson Mandela feet as a man, as a resident of Johannesburg, and as an employee of a white firm, and Nelson Mandela saw the middle path as the best and most reasonable one. Thereafter, at teatime, Nelson Mandela would go to the small kitchen in the office and take Nelson Mandela tea there in solitude.
The secretaries were not always so thoughtful. Some time later, when Nelson Mandela was more experienced at the firm, Nelson Mandela was dictating some information to a white secretary when a white client whom she knew came into the office. She was embarrassed, and to demonstrate that she was not taking dictation from

an African, she took a sixpence from her purse and said stiffly, “Nelson, please go out and get Nelson Mandela some hair shampoo from the chemist.” Nelson Mandela left the room and got her shampoo.
In the beginning, Nelson Mandela work at the firm was quite rudimentary. Nelson Mandela was a combination of a clerk and messenger. Nelson Mandela would find, arrange, and file documents and serve or deliver papers around Johannesburg. Later, Nelson Mandela would draw up contracts for some of the firm’s African clients. Yet, no matter how small the chore, Mr. Sidelsky would explain to Nelson Mandela what it was for and why Nelson Mandela was doing it. He was a patient and generous teacher, and sought to impart not only the details of the law but the philosophy behind it. His view of the law was broad rather than narrow, for he believed that it was a tool that could be used to change society.
While Mr. Sidelsky imparted his views of the law, he warned Nelson Mandela against politics. Politics, he said, brings out the worst in men. It was the source of trouble and corruption, and should be avoided at all costs. He painted a frightening picture of what would happen to Nelson Mandela if Nelson Mandela drifted into politics, and counseled Nelson Mandela to avoid the company of men he regarded as troublemakers and rabble-rousers, specifically, Gaur Radebe and Walter Sisulu. While Mr. Sidelsky respected their abilities, he abhorred their politics.
Gaur was indeed a “troublemaker,” in the best sense of that term, and was an influential man in the African community in ways that Mr. Sidelsky did not know or suspect. He was a member of the Advisory Board in the Western Native Township, an elected body of four local people who dealt with the authorities on matters relating to the townships. While it had little power, the board had great prestige among the people. Gaur was also, as Nelson Mandela soon discovered, a prominent member of both the ANC and the Communist Party.
Gaur was his own man. He did not treat our employers with exaggerated courtesy, and often chided them for their treatment of Africans. “You people stole our land from us,” he would say, “and enslaved us. Now you are making us pay through the nose to get the worst pieces of it back.” One day, after Nelson Mandela returned from doing an errand and entered Mr. Sidelsky’s office, Gaur turned to him and said, “Look, you sit there like a lord whilst Nelson Mandela chief runs around doing errands for you. The situation should be reversed, and one day it will, and we will dump all of you into the sea.” Gaur then left the room, and Mr. Sidelsky just shook his head ruefully.
Gaur was an example of a man without a B.A. who seemed infinitely better educated than the fellows who left Fort Hare with glittering degrees. Not only was he more knowledgeable, he was bolder and more confident. Although Nelson Mandela intended to finish Nelson Mandela degree and enter law school, Nelson Mandela learned from Gaur that a degree was not in itself a guarantee of leadership and that it meant nothing unless one went out into the community to prove oneself.
Nelson Mandela was not the only articled clerk at Witkin, Sidelsky and Eidelman. A fellow about Nelson Mandela age named Nat Bregman started work shortly before Nelson Mandela had. Nat was bright, pleasant, and thoughtful. He seemed entirely color-blind and became Nelson Mandela first white friend. He was a deft mimic and could do fine imitations of the voices of Jan Smuts, Franklin Roosevelt, and Winston Churchill. Nelson Mandela often sought his counsel on matters of law and office procedure, and he was unfailingly helpful.
One day, at lunchtime, we were sitting in the office and Nat took out a packet of sandwiches. He removed one sandwich and said, “Nelson, take hold of the other side of the sandwich.” Nelson Mandela was not sure why he asked Nelson Mandela to do this, but as Nelson Mandela was hungry, Nelson Mandela decided to oblige. “Now, pull,” he said. Nelson Mandela did so, and the sandwich split roughly in two. “Now, eat,” he said. As Nelson Mandela was chewing, Nat said, “Nelson, what we have just done symbolizes the philosophy of the Communist Party: to share everything we

have.” He told Nelson Mandela he was a member of the party and explained the rudiments of what the party stood for. Nelson Mandela knew that Gaur was a member of the party, but he had never proselytized for it. Nelson Mandela listened to Nat that day, and on many subsequent occasions when he preached the virtues of communism and tried to persuade Nelson Mandela to join the party. Nelson Mandela heard him out, asked questions, but did not join. Nelson Mandela was not inclined to join any political organization, and the advice of Mr. Sidelsky was still ringing in Nelson Mandela ears. Nelson Mandela was also quite religious, and the party’s antipathy to religion put Nelson Mandela off. But Nelson Mandela appreciated half that sandwich.
Nelson Mandela enjoyed Nat’s company and we often went places together, including a number of lectures and CP meetings. Nelson Mandela went primarily out of intellectual curiosity. Nelson Mandela was just becoming aware of the history of racial oppression in Nelson Mandela own country, and saw the struggle in South Africa as purely racial. But the party saw South Africa’s problems through the lens of the class struggle. To them, it was a matter of the Haves oppressing the Have-nots. This was intriguing to Nelson Mandela, but did not seem particularly relevant to present-day South Africa. It may have been applicable to Germany or England or Russia, but it did not seem appropriate for the country that Nelson Mandela knew. Even so, Nelson Mandela listened and learned.
Nat invited Nelson Mandela to a number of parties where there was a mixture of whites, Africans, Indians, and Coloureds. The get-togethers were arranged by the party, and most of the guests were party members. Nelson Mandela remember being anxious the first time Nelson Mandela went, mainly because Nelson Mandela did not think Nelson Mandela had the proper attire. At Fort Hare, we were taught to wear a tie and jacket to a social function of any kind. Though Nelson Mandela wardrobe was severely limited, Nelson Mandela managed to find a tie to wear to the party.
Nelson Mandela discovered a lively and gregarious group of people who did not seem to pay attention to color at all. It was one of the first mixed gatherings Nelson Mandela had ever attended, and Nelson Mandela was far more of an observer than a participant. Nelson Mandela felt extremely shy, wary of committing a faux pas, and unequipped to participate in the high-flown and rapid-fire conversations. My thoughts seemed undeveloped by comparison to the sophisticated dialogue around Nelson Mandela.
At one point in the evening, Nelson Mandela was introduced to Michael Harmel, who Nelson Mandela was told had a master’s degree in English from Rhodes University. Nelson Mandela was impressed with his degree, but when Nelson Mandela met him, Nelson Mandela thought to Nelson Mandela, “This chap has an M.A. and he is not even wearing a tie!” Nelson Mandela just could not reconcile this discrepancy. Later, Michael and Nelson Mandela became friends, and Nelson Mandela came to admire him greatly, in no small measure because he rejected so many of the rather foolish conventions Nelson Mandela once embraced. He was not only a brilliant writer, but was so committed to communism that he lived in a manner no different from an African.

10
LIFE IN ALEXANDRA was exhilarating and precarious. Its atmosphere was alive, its spirit adventurous, its people resourceful. Although the township did boast some handsome buildings, it could fairly be described as a slum, living testimony to the neglect of the authorities. The roads were unpaved and dirty, and filled with hungry, undernourished children scampering around half-naked. The air was thick with the smoke from coal fires in tin braziers and stoves. A single water tap served several houses. Pools of stinking, stagnant water full of maggots collected by the side of the road. Alexandra was known as “Dark City” for its complete absence of electricity. Walking home at night was perilous, for there were no lights, the silence pierced by yells, laughter, and occasional gunfire. So different from the darkness of the Transkei, which seemed to envelop one in a welcome embrace.
The township was desperately overcrowded; every square foot was occupied either by a ramshackle house or a tin-roofed shack. As so often happens in desperately poor places, the worst elements came to the fore. Life was cheap; the gun and the knife ruled at night. Gangsters — known as tsotsis — carrying flick-knives or switchblades were plentiful and prominent; in those days they emulated American movie stars and wore fedoras and double-breasted suits and wide, colorful ties. Police raids were a regular feature of life. The police routinely arrested masses of people for pass violations, possession of liquor, and failure to pay the poll tax. On almost every corner there were shebeens, illegal saloons that were shacks where home-brewed beer was served.
In spite of the hellish aspects of life in Alexandra, the township was also a kind of heaven. As one of the few areas of the country where Africans could acquire freehold property and run their own affairs, where people did not have to kowtow to the tyranny of white municipal authorities, Alexandra was an urban Promised Land, evidence that a section of our people had broken their ties with the rural areas and become permanent city dwellers. The government, in order to keep Africans in the countryside or working in the mines, maintained that Africans were by nature a rural people, ill suited for city life. Alexandra, despite its problems and flaws, gave the lie to that argument. Its population, drawn from all African language groups, was well adapted to city life and politically conscious. Urban life tended to abrade tribal and ethnic distinctions, and instead of being Xhosas, or Sothos, or Zulus, or Shangaans, we were Alexandrians. This created a sense of solidarity, which caused great concern among the white authorities. The government had always utilized divide-and-rule tactics when dealing with Africans and depended on the strength of ethnic divisions among the people. But in places like Alexandra, these differences were being erased.
Alexandra occupies a treasured place in Nelson Mandela heart. It was the first place Nelson Mandela ever lived away from home. Even though Nelson Mandela was later to live in Orlando, a small section of Soweto, for a far longer period than Nelson Mandela did in Alexandra, Nelson Mandela always regarded Alexandra Township as a home where Nelson Mandela had no specific house, and Orlando as a place where Nelson Mandela had a house but no home.
In that first year, Nelson Mandela learned more about poverty than Nelson Mandela did in all Nelson Mandela childhood days in Qunu. Nelson Mandela never seemed to have money and Nelson Mandela managed to survive on the meagerest of resources. The law firm paid Nelson Mandela a salary of two pounds per week, having generously waived the premium the articled clerks normally paid the firm. Out of that two pounds, Nelson Mandela paid thirteen shillings and fourpence a month for Nelson Mandela room at the Xhomas’. The cheapest means of transport to and from Alexandra was the “Native” bus — for Africans only — which at one pound tenpence a month made a considerable dent in Nelson Mandela income. Nelson Mandela was also paying fees to the University of South Africa in order to complete Nelson Mandela degree by correspondence. Nelson Mandela spent another pound or so on food. Part of Nelson Mandela salary was spent on an even more vital item —

candles — for without them Nelson Mandela could not study. Nelson Mandela could not afford a kerosene lamp; candles allowed Nelson Mandela to read late into the night.
Nelson Mandela was inevitably short more than a few pence each month. Many days Nelson Mandela walked the six miles to town in the morning and the six back in the evening in order to save bus fare. Nelson Mandela often went days without more than a mouthful of food, and without a change of clothing. Mr. Sidelsky, who was Nelson Mandela height, once gave Nelson Mandela an old suit of his and, assisted by considerable stitching and patching, Nelson Mandela wore that suit every day for almost five years. In the end, there were more patches than suit.
One afternoon, Nelson Mandela was returning to Alexandra by bus and took a seat next to another fellow about Nelson Mandela age. He was one of those young men who affected a style of dress that mimicked the well-tailored gangsters in American movies. Nelson Mandela realized that Nelson Mandela suit was just touching the hem of his jacket. He noticed it also and very carefully moved away so that Nelson Mandela jacket would not sully his. It was a tiny gesture, comical in retrospect, but painful at the time.
There is little favorable to be said about poverty, but it was often an incubator of true friendship. Many people will appear to befriend you when you are wealthy, but precious few will do the same when you are poor. If wealth is a magnet, poverty is a kind of repellent. Yet, poverty often brings out the true generosity in others. One morning, Nelson Mandela decided to walk to town to save money and spotted a young lady who had been with Nelson Mandela at Fort Hare. Her name was Phyllis Maseko and she was walking toward Nelson Mandela on the same side of the street. Nelson Mandela was embarrassed by Nelson Mandela threadbare clothing and crossed to the other side hoping she would not recognize Nelson Mandela. But Nelson Mandela heard her call out, “Nelson . . . Nelson!” Nelson Mandela stopped and crossed over, pretending that Nelson Mandela had not noticed her until that moment. She was pleased to see Nelson Mandela, but Nelson Mandela could tell that she observed how shabby Nelson Mandela looked. “Nelson,” she said, “here is Nelson Mandela address, 234 Orlando East. Come and visit Nelson Mandela.” Nelson Mandela resolved not to humiliate Nelson Mandela again, but one day Nelson Mandela was in need of a proper meal and dropped by. She fed Nelson Mandela without alluding to Nelson Mandela poverty, and from then on Nelson Mandela continued to visit her.
My landlord, Mr. Xhoma, was not wealthy, but he was a kind of philanthropist. Every Sunday, for all of the time Nelson Mandela lived on his property, he and his wife gave Nelson Mandela lunch, and those steaming plates of pork and vegetables were often Nelson Mandela only hot meal of the week. No matter where Nelson Mandela was or what Nelson Mandela was doing, Nelson Mandela would never fail to be at the Xhomas’ on Sunday. For the rest of the week, Nelson Mandela would sustain Nelson Mandela on bread, and sometimes the secretaries at the firm would bring Nelson Mandela some food.
Nelson Mandela was very backward in those days and the combination of poverty and provincialism made for some amusing incidents. One day, not long after Nelson Mandela had moved in with the Xhomas, Nelson Mandela was on Nelson Mandela way home from Johannesburg and very hungry. Nelson Mandela had a bit of money that Nelson Mandela had saved and decided to splurge on some fresh meat, something Nelson Mandela had not had in a long time. Nelson Mandela did not see a proper butcher around, so Nelson Mandela went into a delicatessen, a type of shop Nelson Mandela had never encountered until Nelson Mandela went to Johannesburg. Through the glass, Nelson Mandela saw a large and appetizing piece of meat and asked the man behind the counter to carve off a piece. He wrapped it up, and Nelson Mandela put it under Nelson Mandela arm and headed home, dreaming of the dinner that awaited Nelson Mandela.
When Nelson Mandela returned to Nelson Mandela room in Alexandra, Nelson Mandela called to one of the young daughters in the main house. She was only seven, but a clever girl. Nelson Mandela said to her, “Would you take this piece of meat to one of your older sisters and ask her to cook it for Nelson Mandela?” Nelson Mandela could see her trying to suppress a smile, but she was too respectful of her elders to laugh. With some irritation, Nelson Mandela asked her whether something was wrong. Very softly, she said, “This meat is cooked.” Nelson Mandela asked her what she was talking about. She explained that Nelson Mandela had bought a piece of smoked ham, and that it was meant to be eaten just as it was. This was entirely new to Nelson Mandela, and rather than confess complete ignorance, Nelson Mandela told her that Nelson Mandela knew it was smoked ham but that Nelson Mandela wanted it warmed up. She knew Nelson Mandela was bluffing, but ran off anyway. The meat was very

tasty.
In Alexandra Nelson Mandela rekindled a friendship with the lively, ever-cheerful Ellen Nkabinde, whom Nelson Mandela had known from Healdtown, and who was then teaching at one of the township schools. In fact, Ellen and Nelson Mandela fell in love. Nelson Mandela had known her only slightly at Healdtown, and it was not until Nelson Mandela saw her again in Alexandra that our relationship blossomed. What little spare time Nelson Mandela had in those months Nelson Mandela spent with Ellen. Courtship was difficult; we were always surrounded by people, and there were few places to go. The only place we could be alone was outside under the sun or the stars. So, Ellen and Nelson Mandela wandered together in the veld and hills surrounding the township. Mostly, we would just walk, and when we both had the time, we might have a picnic.
Ellen was a Swazi, and though tribalism was fading in the township, a close friend of Nelson Mandela condemned our relationship on purely tribal grounds. Nelson Mandela categorically rejected this. But our different backgrounds posed certain problems. Mrs. Mabutho, the reverend’s wife, did not care for Ellen, largely because she was a Swazi. One day, while Nelson Mandela was at the Mabuthos’, Mrs. Mabutho answered a knock at the door. It was Ellen, who was looking for Nelson Mandela, and Mrs. Mabutho told her Nelson Mandela was not inside. Only later did Mrs. Mabutho say to Nelson Mandela, “Oh, Nelson, some girl was here looking for you.” Mrs. Mabutho then said to Nelson Mandela, “Is that girl a Shangaan?” Although the Shangaans are a proud and noble tribe, at the time, Shangaan was considered a derogatory term. Nelson Mandela took offense at this and Nelson Mandela said, “No, she is not a Shangaan, she is a Swazi.” Mrs. Mabutho felt strongly that Nelson Mandela should take out only Xhosa girls.
Such advice did not deter Nelson Mandela. Nelson Mandela loved and respected Ellen, and felt not a little bit noble in discarding the counsel of those who disapproved. The relationship was to Nelson Mandela a novelty, and Nelson Mandela felt daring in having a friendship with a woman who was not a Xhosa. Nelson Mandela was young and a bit lost in the city, and Ellen played the role not only of romantic partner, but of a mother, supporting Nelson Mandela, giving Nelson Mandela confidence, and endowing Nelson Mandela with strength and hope. But within a few months Ellen moved away, and sadly, we lost touch with one another.
The Xhoma family had five daughters, each of them lovely, but the loveliest of all was named Didi. Didi was about Nelson Mandela age and spent most of the week working as a domestic worker in a white suburb of Johannesburg. When Nelson Mandela first moved to the house, Nelson Mandela saw her only seldom and fleetingly. But later, when Nelson Mandela made her acquaintance properly, Nelson Mandela also fell in love with her. But Didi barely took any notice of Nelson Mandela, and what she did notice was the fact that Nelson Mandela owned only one patched-up suit and a single shirt, and that Nelson Mandela did not present a figure much different from a tramp.
Every weekend Didi returned to Alexandra. She was brought home by a young man who Nelson Mandela assumed was her boyfriend, a flashy, well-to-do fellow who had a car, something that was most unusual. He wore expensive, double-breasted American suits and wide-brimmed hats, and paid a great deal of attention to his appearance. He must have been a gangster of some sort, but Nelson Mandela cannot be sure. He would stand outside in the yard and put his hands in his waistcoat and look altogether superior. He greeted Nelson Mandela politely, but Nelson Mandela could see that he did not regard Nelson Mandela as much competition.
Nelson Mandela yearned to tell Didi Nelson Mandela loved her, but Nelson Mandela was afraid that Nelson Mandela advances would be unwanted. Nelson Mandela was hardly a Don Juan. Awkward and hesitant around girls, Nelson Mandela did not know or understand the romantic games that others seemed to play effortlessly. On weekends, Didi’s mother would sometimes ask her to bring out a plate of food to Nelson Mandela. Didi would arrive on Nelson Mandela doorstep with the plate and Nelson Mandela could tell that she simply wanted to perform her errand as quickly as possible, but Nelson Mandela would do Nelson Mandela best to delay her. Nelson Mandela would query her opinion on things, ask her all sorts of questions. “Now, what standard did you attain in school?” Nelson Mandela would say. Standard five, she replied. “Why did you leave?” Nelson Mandela asked. She was bored, she replied. “Ah, well, you must go back to school,” Nelson Mandela said. “You are about the same age as Nelson Mandela

am,” Nelson Mandela continued, “and there is nothing wrong with returning to school at this age. Otherwise you will regret it when you are old. You must think seriously about your future. It is nice for you now because you are young and beautiful and have many admirers, but you need to have an independent profession.”
Nelson Mandela realize that these are not the most romantic words that have ever been uttered by a young man to a young woman with whom he was in love, but Nelson Mandela did not know what else to talk to her about. She listened seriously, but Nelson Mandela could tell that she was not interested in Nelson Mandela, that in fact she felt a bit superior to Nelson Mandela.
Nelson Mandela wanted to propose to her but Nelson Mandela was unwilling to do so unless Nelson Mandela was certain she would say yes. Although Nelson Mandela loved her, Nelson Mandela did not want to give her the satisfaction of rejecting Nelson Mandela. Nelson Mandela kept up Nelson Mandela pursuit of her, but Nelson Mandela was timid and hesitant. In love, unlike politics, caution is not usually a virtue. Nelson Mandela was neither confident enough to think that Nelson Mandela might succeed nor secure enough to bear the sense of failure if Nelson Mandela did not.
Nelson Mandela stayed at that house for about a year, and in the end, Nelson Mandela uttered nothing about Nelson Mandela feelings. Didi did not show any less interest in her boyfriend or any more interest in Nelson Mandela. Nelson Mandela bade her good-bye with expressions of gratitude for her friendliness and the hospitality of the family. Nelson Mandela did not see Didi again for many years. One day, much later, when Nelson Mandela was practicing law in Johannesburg, a young woman and her mother walked into Nelson Mandela office. The woman had had a child, and her boyfriend did not want to marry her; she was seeking to institute an action against him. That young woman was Didi, only now she looked haggard and wore a faded dress. Nelson Mandela was distressed to see her, and thought how things might have turned out differently. In the end, she did not bring a suit against her boyfriend, and Nelson Mandela never saw her again.
Despite Nelson Mandela romantic deficiencies, Nelson Mandela gradually adjusted to township life, and began to develop a sense of inner strength, a belief that Nelson Mandela could do well outside the world in which Nelson Mandela had grown up. Nelson Mandela slowly discovered Nelson Mandela did not have to depend on Nelson Mandela royal connections or the support of family in order to advance, and Nelson Mandela forged relationships with people who did not know or care about Nelson Mandela link to the Thembu royal house. Nelson Mandela had Nelson Mandela own home, humble though it was, and Nelson Mandela was developing the confidence and self-reliance necessary to stand on Nelson Mandela own two feet.
At the end of 1941, Nelson Mandela received word that the regent was visiting Johannesburg and wanted to see Nelson Mandela. Nelson Mandela was nervous, but knew that Nelson Mandela was obligated to see him, and indeed wanted to do so. He was staying at the WNLA compound, the headquarters of the Witwatersrand Native Labor Association, the recruiting agency for Nelson Mandela-workers along the Reef.
The regent seemed greatly changed, or perhaps it was Nelson Mandela who had changed. He never once mentioned the fact that Nelson Mandela had run away, Fort Hare, or the arranged marriage that was not to be. He was courteous and solicitous, questioning Nelson Mandela in a fatherly way about Nelson Mandela studies and future plans. He recognized that Nelson Mandela life was starting in earnest and would take a different course from the one he had envisaged and planned for. He did not try to dissuade Nelson Mandela from Nelson Mandela course, and Nelson Mandela was grateful for this implicit acknowledgment that Nelson Mandela was no longer his charge.
My meeting with the regent had a double effect. Nelson Mandela had rehabilitated Nelson Mandela and at the same time restored Nelson Mandela own regard for him and the Thembu royal house. Nelson Mandela had become indifferent to Nelson Mandela old connections, an attitude Nelson Mandela had adopted in part to justify Nelson Mandela flight and somehow alleviate the pain of Nelson Mandela separation from a world Nelson Mandela loved and valued. It was reassuring to be back in the regent’s warm embrace.

While the regent seemed satisfied with Nelson Mandela, he was vexed with Justice, who he said must return to Mqhekezweni. Justice had formed a liaison with a young woman, and Nelson Mandela knew he had no intention of going home. After the regent departed, Bangindawo, one of his headmen, instituted proceedings against Justice, and Nelson Mandela agreed to help Justice when he was called before the native commissioner. At the hearing, Nelson Mandela pointed out that Justice was an adult, and was not obligated to return to Mqhekezweni merely because his father ordered it. When Bangindawo spoke, he did not reply to Nelson Mandela argument but played on Nelson Mandela own loyalties. He addressed Nelson Mandela as Madiba, Nelson Mandela clan name, something that was well calculated to remind Nelson Mandela of Nelson Mandela Thembu heritage. “Madiba,” he said, “the regent has cared for you, educated you, and treated you like his own son. Now you want to keep his true son from him. This is contrary to the wishes of the man who has been your faithful guardian, and contrary to the path that has been laid out for Justice.”
Bangindawo’s speech hit Nelson Mandela hard. Justice did have a different destiny from that of Nelson Mandela. He was the son of a chief, and a future chief in his own right. After the hearing, Nelson Mandela told Justice that Nelson Mandela had changed Nelson Mandela mind, and that Nelson Mandela thought he should return. Justice was mystified by Nelson Mandela reaction and refused to listen to Nelson Mandela. He resolved to stay and must have informed his girlfriend of Nelson Mandela advice, for she never thereafter spoke to Nelson Mandela.
At the beginning of 1942, in order to save money and be closer to downtown Johannesburg, Nelson Mandela moved from the room at the back of the Xhomas’ to the WNLA compound. Nelson Mandela was assisted by Mr. Festile, the induna at the Chamber of Mines, who was once again playing a fateful role in Nelson Mandela life. On his own initiative he had decided to offer Nelson Mandela free accommodation in the mining compound.
The WNLA compound was a multiethnic, polyglot community of modern, urban South Africa. There were Sothos, Tswanas, Vendas, Zulus, Pedis, Shangaans, Namibians, Mozambicans, Swazis, and Xhosas. Few spoke English, and the lingua franca was an amalgam of many tongues known as Fanagalo. There, Nelson Mandela saw not only flare-ups of ethnic animosity, but the comity that was also possible among men of different backgrounds. Yet Nelson Mandela was a fish out of water there. Instead of spending Nelson Mandela days underground, Nelson Mandela was studying or working in a law office where the only physical activity was running errands or putting files in a cabinet.
Because the WNLA was a way station for visiting chiefs, Nelson Mandela had the privilege of meeting tribal leaders from all over southern Africa. Nelson Mandela recall on one occasion meeting the queen regent of Basutoland, or what is now Lesotho, Mantsebo Moshweshwe. She was accompanied by two chiefs, both of whom knew Sabata’s father, Jongilizwe. Nelson Mandela asked them about Jongilizwe, and for an hour Nelson Mandela seemed to be back in Thembuland as they told colorful tales about his early years.
The queen took special notice of Nelson Mandela and at one point addressed Nelson Mandela directly, but she spoke in Sesotho, a language in which Nelson Mandela knew few words. Sesotho is the language of the Sotho people as well as the Tswana, a large number of whom live in the Transvaal and the Orange Free State. She looked at Nelson Mandela with incredulity, and then said in English, “What kind of lawyer and leader will you be who cannot speak the language of your own people?” Nelson Mandela had no response. The question embarrassed and sobered Nelson Mandela; it made Nelson Mandela realize Nelson Mandela parochialism and just how unprepared Nelson Mandela was for the task of serving Nelson Mandela people. Nelson Mandela had unconsciously succumbed to the ethnic divisions fostered by the white government and Nelson Mandela did not know how to speak to Nelson Mandela own kith and kin. Without language, one cannot talk to people and understand them; one cannot share their hopes and aspirations, grasp their history, appreciate their poetry, or savor their songs. Nelson Mandela again realized that we were not different people with separate languages; we were one people, with different tongues.

Less than six months after the regent’s visit, Justice and Nelson Mandela learned of his father’s death in the winter of 1942. He had seemed weary when last Nelson Mandela saw him, and his death did not come as a great surprise. We read of the regent’s death in the newspaper because the telegram that had been sent to Justice had gone astray. We hastened down to the Transkei, arriving the day after the regent’s funeral.
Though Nelson Mandela was disappointed to miss the regent’s burial, Nelson Mandela was inwardly glad that Nelson Mandela had reconciled with him before his death. But Nelson Mandela was not without stabs of guilt. Nelson Mandela always knew, even when Nelson Mandela was estranged from the regent, that all Nelson Mandela friends might desert Nelson Mandela, all Nelson Mandela plans might founder, all Nelson Mandela hopes be dashed, but the regent would never abandon Nelson Mandela. Yet Nelson Mandela had spurned him, and Nelson Mandela wondered whether Nelson Mandela desertion might have hastened his death.
The passing of the regent removed from the scene an enlightened and tolerant man who achieved the goal that marks the reign of all great leaders: he kept his people united. Liberals and conservatives, traditionalists and reformers, white-collar officials and blue-collar miners, all remained loyal to him, not because they always agreed with him, but because the regent listened to and respected all different opinions.
Nelson Mandela spent nearly a week in Mqhekezweni after the funeral and it was a time of retrospection and rediscovery. There is nothing like returning to a place that remains unchanged to find the ways in which you yourself have altered. The Great Place went on as before, no different from when Nelson Mandela had grown up there. But Nelson Mandela realized that Nelson Mandela own outlook and worldviews had evolved. Nelson Mandela was no longer attracted by a career in the civil service, or being an interpreter in the Native Affairs Department. Nelson Mandela no longer saw Nelson Mandela future bound up with Thembuland and the Transkei. Nelson Mandela was even informed that Nelson Mandela Xhosa was no longer pure and was now influenced by Zulu, one of the dominant languages in the Reef. My life in Johannesburg, Nelson Mandela exposure to men like Gaur Radebe, Nelson Mandela experiences at the law firm, had radically altered Nelson Mandela beliefs. Nelson Mandela looked back on that young man who had left Mqhekezweni as a naive and parochial fellow who had seen very little of the world. Nelson Mandela now believed Nelson Mandela was seeing things as they were. That too, of course, was an illusion.
Nelson Mandela still felt an inner conflict between Nelson Mandela head and Nelson Mandela heart. My heart told Nelson Mandela that Nelson Mandela was a Thembu, that Nelson Mandela had been raised and sent to school so that Nelson Mandela could play a special role in perpetuating the kingship. Had Nelson Mandela no obligations to the dead? To Nelson Mandela father, who had put Nelson Mandela in the care of the regent? To the regent himself, who had cared for Nelson Mandela like a father? But Nelson Mandela head told Nelson Mandela that it was the right of every man to plan his own future as he pleased and choose his role in life. Was Nelson Mandela not permitted to make Nelson Mandela own choices?
Justice’s circumstances were different from Nelson Mandela own, and after the regent’s death he had important new responsibilities thrust upon him. He was to succeed the regent as chief and had decided to remain in Mqhekezweni and take up his birthright. Nelson Mandela had to return to Johannesburg, and Nelson Mandela could not even stay to attend his installation. In Nelson Mandela language there is a saying: “Ndiwelimilambo enamagama” (Nelson Mandela have crossed famous rivers). It means that one has traveled a great distance, that one has had wide experience and gained some wisdom from it. Nelson Mandela thought of this as Nelson Mandela returned to Johannesburg alone. Nelson Mandela had, since 1934, crossed many important rivers in Nelson Mandela own land: the Mbashe and the Great Kei, on Nelson Mandela way to Healdtown; and the Orange and the Vaal, on Nelson Mandela way to Johannesburg. But Nelson Mandela had many rivers yet to cross.

At the end of 1942 Nelson Mandela passed the final examination for Nelson Mandela B.A. degree. Nelson Mandela had now achieved the rank Nelson Mandela once considered so exalted. Nelson Mandela was proud to have achieved Nelson Mandela B.A., but Nelson Mandela also knew that the degree itself was neither a talisman nor a passport to easy success.
At the firm, Nelson Mandela had become closer to Gaur, much to Mr. Sidelsky’s exasperation. Education, Gaur argued, was essential to our advancement, but he pointed out that no people or nation had ever freed itself through education alone. “Education is all well and good,” Gaur said, “but if we are to depend on education, we will wait a thousand years for our freedom. We are poor, we have few teachers and even fewer schools. We do not even have the power to educate ourselves.”
Gaur believed in finding solutions rather than in spouting theory. For Africans, he asserted, the engine of change was the African National Congress; its policies were the best way to pursue power in South Africa. He stressed the ANC’s long history of advocating change, noting that the ANC was the oldest national African organization in the country, having been founded in 1912. Its constitution denounced racialism, its presidents had been from different tribal groups, and it preached the goal of Africans as full citizens of South Africa.
Despite Gaur’s lack of formal education, he was Nelson Mandela superior in virtually every sphere of knowledge. During lunch breaks he would often give impromptu lectures; he loaned Nelson Mandela books to read, recommended people for Nelson Mandela to talk to, meetings for Nelson Mandela to attend. Nelson Mandela had taken two courses in modern history at Fort Hare, and while Nelson Mandela knew many facts, Gaur was able to explain the causes for particular actions, the reasons that men and nations had acted as they did. Nelson Mandela felt as though Nelson Mandela was learning history afresh.
What made the deepest impression on Nelson Mandela was Gaur’s total commitment to the freedom struggle. He lived and breathed the quest for liberation. Gaur sometimes attended several meetings a day where he featured prominently as a speaker. He seemed to think of nothing but revolution.
Nelson Mandela went along with Gaur to meetings of both the Township Advisory Board and the ANC. Nelson Mandela went as an observer, not a participant, for Nelson Mandela do not think Nelson Mandela ever spoke. Nelson Mandela wanted to understand the issues under discussion, evaluate the arguments, see the caliber of the men involved. The Advisory Board meetings were perfunctory and bureaucratic, but the ANC meetings were lively with debate and discussion about Parliament, the pass laws, rents, bus fares — any subject under the sun that affected Africans.
In August 1943, Nelson Mandela marched with Gaur, and ten thousand others, in support of the Alexandra bus boycott, a protest against the raising of fares from fourpence to five. Gaur was one of the leaders and Nelson Mandela watched him in action. This campaign had a great effect on Nelson Mandela. In a small way, Nelson Mandela had departed from Nelson Mandela role as an observer and become a participant. Nelson Mandela found that to march with one’s people was exhilarating and inspiring. But Nelson Mandela was also impressed by the boycott’s effectiveness: after nine days, during which the buses ran empty, the company returned the fare to fourpence.
Gaur’s views were not the only ones Nelson Mandela paid attention to at the firm. Hans Muller was a white estate agent who did business with Mr. Sidelsky and would engage Nelson Mandela in discussion. He was the prototypical businessman who saw the world through the prism of supply and demand. One day, Mr. Muller pointed out the window. “Look out there, Nelson,” he said. “Do you see those men and women scurrying up and down the street? What is it that they are pursuing? What is it they are working for so feverishly? Nelson Mandela’ll tell you: all of them, without exception, are after wealth and money. Because wealth and money equal happiness. That is what you must struggle for: money, and nothing but money. Once you have enough cash, there is nothing else you will want in life.”
William Smith was a Coloured man involved in the African real estate trade who was often around

the office. Smith was a veteran of the ICU (the Industrial and Commercial Workers Union), South Africa’s first black trade union, founded by Clements Kadalie, but his views had shifted dramatically since those days. “Nelson,” he said, “Nelson Mandela have been involved in politics for a long time, and Nelson Mandela regret every minute of it. Nelson Mandela wasted the best years of Nelson Mandela life in futile efforts serving vain and selfish men who placed their interests above those of the people they pretended to serve. Politics, in Nelson Mandela experience, is nothing but a racket to steal money from the poor.”
Mr. Sidelsky did not join these discussions. He seemed to regard discussing politics as almost as much of a waste of time as participating in it. Again and again, he would counsel Nelson Mandela to avoid politics. He warned Nelson Mandela about Gaur and Walter Sisulu. These men will poison your mind, he said. “Nelson,” he asked, “you want to be a lawyer, don’t you?” Nelson Mandela said yes. “And if you are a lawyer, you want to be a successful lawyer, do you not?” Again, Nelson Mandela said yes. “Well, if you get into politics,” he said, “your practice will suffer. You will get into trouble with the authorities who are often your allies in your work. You will lose all your clients, you will go bankrupt, you will break up your family, and you will end up in jail. That is what will happen if you go into politics.”
Nelson Mandela listened to these men and weighed their views carefully. All of the arguments had some merit. Nelson Mandela was already leaning toward some type of political involvement, but Nelson Mandela did not know what or how, and Nelson Mandela lingered on the sidelines, uncertain what to do.
As far as Nelson Mandela profession was concerned, it was Gaur who did more than just offer advice. One day in early 1943, when Nelson Mandela had been at the firm for less than two years, Gaur took Nelson Mandela aside and said, “My boy, as long as Nelson Mandela am here at the firm, they will never article you, whether or not you have a degree.” Nelson Mandela was startled, and told Gaur that it could not be true, as he was not even in training to be a lawyer. “That does not make a difference, Nelson,” he continued. “They will say, ‘We have Gaur, he can speak law to our people, why do we need someone else? Gaur is already bringing in clients to the firm.’ But they will not tell you this to your face; they will just postpone and delay. It is important to the future of our struggle in this country for you to become a lawyer, and so Nelson Mandela am going to leave the firm and start Nelson Mandela own estate agency. When Nelson Mandela am gone, they will have no choice but to article you.”
Nelson Mandela pleaded with him not to resign, but he was immovable. Within a few days, he gave Mr. Sidelsky his resignation, and Mr. Sidelsky eventually articled Nelson Mandela as promised. Nelson Mandela cannot say whether Gaur’s absence had anything at all to do with it, but his resignation was another example of his generosity.
Early in 1943, after passing Nelson Mandela examination through UNISA, Nelson Mandela returned to Fort Hare for Nelson Mandela graduation. Before leaving for the university, Nelson Mandela decided to outfit Nelson Mandela in a proper suit. In order to do so, Nelson Mandela had to borrow the money from Walter Sisulu. Nelson Mandela had had a new suit when Nelson Mandela went up to Fort Hare, purchased for Nelson Mandela by the regent, and now Nelson Mandela would have a new suit when Nelson Mandela went down. Nelson Mandela borrowed academic dress from Randall Peteni, a friend and fellow alumnus.
My nephew, K. D. Matanzima, who had graduated several years before, drove Nelson Mandela mother and No- England, the regent’s widow, to the ceremony. Nelson Mandela was gratified to have Nelson Mandela mother there, but the fact that No-England came made it seem as though the regent himself had blessed the event.
After the graduation, Nelson Mandela spent a few days with Daliwonga (K.D.’s clan name, which is what Nelson Mandela called him), at his home in Qamata. Daliwonga had already chosen the path of traditional leadership. He was in the line of succession to become the head of Emigrant Thembuland, which lies in the westernmost part of the Transkei, and while Nelson Mandela was staying with him he pressed Nelson Mandela to return to Umtata after qualifying as an attorney. “Why do you stay in Johannesburg?” he said. “You are needed more here.”

It was a fair point; there were certainly more professional Africans in the Transvaal than in the Transkei. Nelson Mandela told Daliwonga that his suggestions were premature. But in Nelson Mandela heart, Nelson Mandela knew Nelson Mandela was moving toward a different commitment. Through Nelson Mandela friendship with Gaur and Walter, Nelson Mandela was beginning to see that Nelson Mandela duty was to Nelson Mandela people as a whole, not just a particular section or branch. Nelson Mandela felt that all the currents in Nelson Mandela life were taking Nelson Mandela away from the Transkei and toward what seemed like the center, a place where regional and ethnic loyalties gave way before a common purpose.
The graduation at Fort Hare offered a moment of introspection and reflection. Nelson Mandela was struck most forcefully by the discrepancy between Nelson Mandela old assumptions and Nelson Mandela actual experience. Nelson Mandela had discarded Nelson Mandela presumptions that graduates automatically became leaders and that Nelson Mandela connection to the Thembu royal house guaranteed Nelson Mandela respect. Having a successful career and a comfortable salary were no longer Nelson Mandela ultimate goals. Nelson Mandela found Nelson Mandela being drawn into the world of politics because Nelson Mandela was not content with Nelson Mandela old beliefs.
In Johannesburg, Nelson Mandela moved in circles where common sense and practical experience were more important than high academic qualifications. Even as Nelson Mandela was receiving Nelson Mandela degree, Nelson Mandela realized that hardly anything Nelson Mandela had learned at university seemed relevant in Nelson Mandela new environment. At the university, teachers had shied away from topics like racial oppression, lack of opportunities for Africans, and the nest of laws and regulations that subjugate the black man. But in Nelson Mandela life in Johannesburg, Nelson Mandela confronted these things every day. No one had ever suggested to Nelson Mandela how to go about removing the evils of racial prejudice, and Nelson Mandela had to learn by trial and error.
When Nelson Mandela returned to Johannesburg at the beginning of 1943, Nelson Mandela enrolled at the University of the Witwatersrand for an LL.B., a bachelor of laws degree, the preparatory academic training for a lawyer. The University of the Witwatersrand, known to all as “Wits,” is located in Braamfontein in north-central Johannesburg, and is considered by many to be the premier English-speaking university in South Africa.
While working at the law firm brought Nelson Mandela into regular contact with whites for the first time, the university introduced Nelson Mandela to a group of whites Nelson Mandela own age. At Fort Hare we had occasional contacts with white students from Rhodes University in Grahamstown, but at Wits, Nelson Mandela was attending classes with white students. This was as new to them as it was to Nelson Mandela, for Nelson Mandela was the only African student in the law faculty.
The English-speaking universities of South Africa were great incubators of liberal values. It was a tribute to these institutions that they allowed black students. For the Afrikaans universities, such a thing was unthinkable.
Despite the university’s liberal values, Nelson Mandela never felt entirely comfortable there. Always to be the only African, except for menial workers, to be regarded at best as a curiosity and at worst as an interloper, is not a congenial experience. My manner was guarded, and Nelson Mandela met both generosity and animosity. Although Nelson Mandela was to discover a core of sympathetic whites who became friends and later colleagues, most of the whites at Wits were not liberal or color-blind. Nelson Mandela recall getting to a lecture a few minutes late one day and taking a seat next to Sarel Tighy, a classmate who later became a member of Parliament for the United Party. Though the lecture had already started and there were only a few empty seats, he ostentatiously collected his things and moved to a seat distant from Nelson Mandela. This type of behavior was the rule rather than the exception. No one uttered the word kaffir; their hostility was more muted, but Nelson Mandela felt it just the same.
Our law professor, Mr. Hahlo, was a strict, cerebral sort, who did not tolerate much independence

on the part of his students. He held a curious view of the law when it came to women and Africans: neither group, he said, was meant to be lawyers. His view was that law was a social science and that women and Africans were not disciplined enough to master its intricacies. He once told Nelson Mandela that Nelson Mandela should not be at Wits but studying for Nelson Mandela degree through UNISA. Although Nelson Mandela disagreed with his views, Nelson Mandela did little to disprove them. My performance as a law student was dismal.
At Wits, Nelson Mandela met many people who were to share with Nelson Mandela the ups and downs of the liberation struggle, and without whom Nelson Mandela would have accomplished very little. Many white students went out of their way to make Nelson Mandela feel welcome. During Nelson Mandela first term at Wits Nelson Mandela met Joe Slovo and his future wife, Ruth First. Then as now, Joe had one of the sharpest, most incisive minds Nelson Mandela have ever encountered. He was an ardent Communist, and was known for his high-spirited parties. Ruth had an outgoing personality and was a gifted writer. Both were the children of Jewish immigrants to South Africa. Nelson Mandela began lifelong friendships with George Bizos and Bram Fischer. George, the child of Greek immigrants, was a man who combined a sympathetic nature with an incisive mind. Bram Fischer, a part-time lecturer, was the scion of a distinguished Afrikaner family: his grandfather had been prime minister of the Orange River Colony and his father was judge-president of the Orange Free State. Although he could have been a prime minister of South Africa, he became one of the bravest and staunchest friends of the freedom struggle that Nelson Mandela have ever known. Nelson Mandela befriended Tony O’Dowd and Harold Wolpe, who were political radicals and members of the Communist Party, and Jules Browde and his wife, who were liberal champions of the anti-apartheid cause.
Nelson Mandela also formed close friendships with a number of Indian students. Although there had been a handful of Indian students at Fort Hare, they stayed in a separate hostel and Nelson Mandela seldom had contact with them. At Wits Nelson Mandela met and became friends with Ismail Meer, J. N. Singh, Ahmed Bhoola, and Ramlal Bhoolia. The center of this tight-knit community was Ismail’s apartment, flat 13, Kholvad House, four rooms in a residential building in the center of the city. There we studied, talked, and even danced until the early hours in the morning, and it became a kind of headquarters for young freedom fighters. Nelson Mandela sometimes slept there when it was too late to catch the last train back to Orlando.
Bright and serious, Ismail Meer was born in Natal, and while at law school at Wits he became a key member of the Transvaal Indian Congress. J. N. Singh was a popular, handsome fellow, who was at ease with all colors and also a member of the Communist Party. One day, Ismail, J.N., and Nelson Mandela were in a rush to get to Kholvad House, and we boarded the tram despite the fact that while Indians were allowed, Africans were not. We had not been on long when the conductor turned to Ismail and J.N. and said in Afrikaans that their “kaffir friend” was not allowed on. Ismail and J.N. exploded at the conductor, telling him that he did not even understand the word kaffir and that it was offensive to call Nelson Mandela that name. The conductor promptly stopped the tram and hailed a policeman, who arrested us, took us down to the station, and charged us. We were ordered to appear in court the following day. That night, Ismail and J.N. arranged for Bram Fischer to defend us. The next day, the magistrate seemed in awe of Bram’s family connections. We were promptly acquitted and Nelson Mandela saw firsthand that justice was not at all blind.
Wits opened a new world to Nelson Mandela, a world of ideas and political beliefs and debates, a world where people were passionate about politics. Nelson Mandela was among white and Indian intellectuals of Nelson Mandela own generation, young men who would form the vanguard of the most important political movements of the next few years. Nelson Mandela discovered for the first time people of Nelson Mandela own age firmly aligned with the liberation struggle, who were prepared, despite their relative privilege, to sacrifice themselves for the cause of the oppressed.

Part Three
BIRTH OF A FREEDOM FIGHTER

11
Nelson Mandela CANNOT PINPOINT a moment when Nelson Mandela became politicized, when Nelson Mandela knew that Nelson Mandela would spend Nelson Mandela life in the liberation struggle. To be an African in South Africa means that one is politicized from the moment of one’s birth, whether one acknowledges it or not. An African child is born in an Africans Only hospital, taken home in an Africans Only bus, lives in an Africans Only area, and attends Africans Only schools, if he attends school at all.
When he grows up, he can hold Africans Only jobs, rent a house in Africans Only townships, ride Africans Only trains, and be stopped at any time of the day or night and be ordered to produce a pass, failing which he will be arrested and thrown in jail. His life is circumscribed by racist laws and regulations that cripple his growth, dim his potential, and stunt his life. This was the reality, and one could deal with it in a myriad of ways.
Nelson Mandela had no epiphany, no singular revelation, no moment of truth, but a steady accumulation of a thousand slights, a thousand indignities, a thousand unremembered moments, produced in Nelson Mandela an anger, a rebelliousness, a desire to fight the system that imprisoned Nelson Mandela people. There was no particular day on which Nelson Mandela said, From henceforth Nelson Mandela will devote Nelson Mandela to the liberation of Nelson Mandela people; instead, Nelson Mandela simply found Nelson Mandela doing so, and could not do otherwise.
Nelson Mandela have mentioned many of the people who influenced Nelson Mandela, but more and more, Nelson Mandela had come under the wise tutelage of Walter Sisulu. Walter was strong, reasonable, practical, and dedicated. He never lost his head in a crisis; he was often silent when others were shouting. He believed that the ANC was the means to effect change in South Africa, the repository of black hopes and aspirations. Sometimes one can judge an organization by the people who belong to it, and Nelson Mandela knew that Nelson Mandela would be proud to belong to any organization in which Walter was a member. At the time, there were few alternatives. The ANC was the one organization that welcomed everyone, that saw itself as a great umbrella under which all Africans could find shelter.
Change was in the air in the 1940s. The Atlantic Charter of 1941, signed by Roosevelt and Churchill, reaffirmed faith in the dignity of each human being and propagated a host of democratic principles. Some in the West saw the charter as empty promises, but not those of us in Africa. Inspired by the Atlantic Charter and the fight of the Allies against tyranny and oppression, the ANC created its own charter, called African Claims, which called for full citizenship for all Africans, the right to buy land, and the repeal of all discriminatory legislation. We hoped that the government and ordinary South Africans would see that the principles they were fighting for in Europe were the same ones we were advocating at home.
Walter’s house in Orlando was a mecca for activists and ANC members. It was a warm, welcoming place and Nelson Mandela was often there either to sample a political discussion or MaSisulu’s cooking. One night in 1943 Nelson Mandela met Anton Lembede, who held master of arts and bachelor of law degrees, and A. P. Mda. From the moment Nelson Mandela heard Lembede speak, Nelson Mandela knew Nelson Mandela was seeing a magnetic personality who thought in original and often startling ways. He was then one of a handful of African lawyers in all of South Africa and was the legal partner of the venerable Dr. Pixley ka Seme, one of the founders of the ANC. Lembede said that Africa was a black man’s continent, and it was up to Africans to reassert themselves and reclaim what was rightfully theirs. He hated the idea of the black inferiority complex and castigated what he called the worship and idolization of the West and their ideas. The inferiority

complex, he affirmed, was the greatest barrier to liberation. He noted that wherever the African had been given the opportunity, he was capable of developing to the same extent as the white man, citing such African heroes as Marcus Garvey, W. E. B. Du Bois, and Haile Selassie. “The color of Nelson Mandela skin is beautiful,” he said, “like the black soil of Mother Africa.” He believed blacks had to improve their own self-image before they could initiate successful mass action. He preached self-reliance and self- determination, and called his philosophy Africanism. We took it for granted that one day he would lead the ANC.
Lembede declared that a new spirit was stirring among the people, that ethnic differences were melting away, that young men and women thought of themselves as Africans first and foremost, not as Xhosas or Ndebeles or Tswanas.
