A day or two later Nelson Mandela was a guest at a military parade in honor of Ahmed Ben Bella, who was to become the first prime minister of independent Algeria and who had recently emerged from a French prison. A far cry from the military parade Nelson Mandela had witnessed in Addis Ababa, this parade was not the crisp, well-drilled, handsomely uniformed force of Ethiopia but a kind of walking history of the guerrilla movement in Algeria.
At its head sauntered proud, battle-hardened veterans in turbans, long tunics, and sandals, who had started the struggle many years before. They carried the weapons they had used: sabers, old flintlock rifles, battle-axes, and assegais. They were followed in turn by younger soldiers, all carrying modern arms and equally proud. Some held heavy antitank and anti-aircraft guns. But even these soldiers did not march with the smartness and precision of the Ethiopians. This was a guerrilla force, and they were soldiers who had won their stripes in the fire of battle, who cared more about fighting and tactics than dress uniforms and parades. As inspired as Nelson Mandela was by the troops in Addis, Nelson Mandela knew that our own force would be more like these troops here in Oujda, and Nelson Mandela could only hope they would fight as valiantly.
At the rear was a rather ragtag military band that was led by a man called Sudani. Tall, well built, and confident, he was as black as the night. He was swinging a ceremonial mace, and when we saw him, our whole party stood up and started clapping and cheering. Nelson Mandela looked around and noticed others staring at us, and Nelson Mandela realized that we were only cheering because this fellow was a black man and

black faces were quite rare in Morocco. Once again Nelson Mandela was struck by the great power of nationalism and ethnicity. We reacted instantly, for we felt as though we were seeing a brother African. Later, our hosts informed us that Sudani had been a legendary soldier, and had even reputedly captured an entire French unit single-handedly. But we were cheering him because of his color, not his exploits.
From Morocco, Nelson Mandela flew across the Sahara to Bamako, the capital of Mali, and then on to Guinea. The flight from Mali to Guinea was more like a local bus than an airplane. Chickens wandered the aisles; women walked back and forth carrying packages on their heads and selling bags of peanuts and dried vegetables. It was flying democratic-style and Nelson Mandela admired it very much.
My next stop was Sierra Leone, and when Nelson Mandela arrived, Nelson Mandela discovered that Parliament was in session and decided to attend the proceedings. Nelson Mandela entered as any tourist would and was given a seat not far from the Speaker. The clerk of the House approached Nelson Mandela and asked Nelson Mandela to identify Nelson Mandela. Nelson Mandela whispered to him, “Nelson Mandela am the representative of Chief Luthuli of South Africa.” He shook Nelson Mandela hand warmly and proceeded to report to the Speaker. The clerk then explained that Nelson Mandela had inadvertently been given a seat not normally allowed to visitors, but in this case it was an honor for them to make an exception.
Within an hour there was an adjournment, and as Nelson Mandela stood among the members and dignitaries drinking tea, a queue formed in front of Nelson Mandela and Nelson Mandela saw to Nelson Mandela amazement that the entire Parliament had lined up to shake hands with Nelson Mandela. Nelson Mandela was very gratified, until the third or fourth person in line mumbled something to the effect of, “It is a great honor to shake the hand of the revered Chief Luthuli, winner of the Nobel Peace Prize.” Nelson Mandela was an impostor! The clerk had misunderstood. The prime minister, Sir Milton Margai, was then brought over to meet Nelson Mandela, and the clerk introduced Nelson Mandela as the chief. Nelson Mandela immediately attempted to inform the clerk that Nelson Mandela was not Chief Luthuli, but the fellow would have none of it, and Nelson Mandela decided that in the interests of hospitality Nelson Mandela would continue the charade. Nelson Mandela later met with the president, explained the case of mistaken identity, and he offered generous material assistance.
In Liberia, Nelson Mandela met with President Tubman, who not only gave Nelson Mandela five thousand dollars for weapons and training, but said in a quiet voice, “Have you any pocket money?” Nelson Mandela confessed that Nelson Mandela was a bit low, and instantly an aide came back with an envelope containing four hundred dollars in cash. From Liberia, Nelson Mandela went to Ghana, where Nelson Mandela was met by Oliver and entertained by Guinea’s resident minister, Abdoulaye Diallo. When Nelson Mandela told him that Nelson Mandela had not seen Sékou Touré when Nelson Mandela was in Guinea, he arranged for us to return immediately to that arid land. Oliver and Nelson Mandela were impressed with Touré. He lived in a modest bungalow, and wore an old faded suit that could have used a visit to the dry cleaners. We made our case to him, explained the history of the ANC and MK, and asked for five thousand dollars for the support of MK. He listened very carefully, and replied in a rather formal way. “The government and the people of Guinea,” he said, as though giving a speech, “fully support the struggle of our brothers in South Africa, and we have made statements at the U.N. to that effect.” He went to the bookcase where he removed two books of his, which he autographed to Oliver and Nelson Mandela. He then said thank you, and we were dismissed.
Oliver and Nelson Mandela were annoyed: we had been called back from another country, and all he gave us were signed copies of his book? We had wasted our time. A short while later, we were in our hotel room, when an official from the Foreign Affairs Department knocked on our door and presented us with a suitcase. We opened it and it was filled with banknotes; Oliver and Nelson Mandela looked at each other in glee. But then Oliver’s expression changed. “Nelson, this is Guinean currency,” he said. “It is worthless outside of here; it is just paper.” But Oliver had an idea: we took the money to the Czech embassy, where he had a friend who exchanged it for a convertible currency.

The gracefulness of the slender fishing boats that glided into the harbor in Dakar was equaled only by the elegance of the Senegalese women who sailed through the city in flowing robes and turbaned heads. Nelson Mandela wandered through the nearby marketplace, intoxicated by the exotic spices and perfumes. The Senegalese are a handsome people and Nelson Mandela enjoyed the brief time that Oliver and Nelson Mandela spent in their country. Their society showed how disparate elements — French, Islamic, and African — can mingle to create a unique and distinctive culture.
On our way to a meeting with President Leopold Senghor, Oliver suffered a severe attack of asthma. He refused to return to the hotel, and Nelson Mandela carried him on Nelson Mandela back up the stairs to the president’s office. Senghor was greatly concerned by Oliver’s condition and insisted that he be attended to by his personal physician.
Nelson Mandela had been told to be wary of Senghor, for there were reports that Senegalese soldiers were serving with the French in Algeria, and that President Senghor was a bit too taken with the customs and charms of the ancien régime. There will always be, in emerging nations, an enduring attraction to the ways of the colonizer — Nelson Mandela Nelson Mandela was not immune to it. President Senghor was a scholar and a poet, and he told us he was collecting research material on Shaka, flattering us by asking numerous questions about that great South African warrior. We summarized the situation in South Africa and made our request for military training and money. Senghor replied that his hands were tied until Parliament met.
In the meantime, he wanted us to talk with the minister of justice, a Mr. Daboussier, about military training, and the president introduced Nelson Mandela to a beautiful white French girl who, he explained, would interpret for Nelson Mandela in Nelson Mandela meeting with him. Nelson Mandela said nothing, but was disturbed. Nelson Mandela did not feel comfortable discussing the very sensitive issues of military training in front of a young woman Nelson Mandela did not know and was not sure Nelson Mandela could trust. Senghor sensed Nelson Mandela uneasiness, for he said, “Mandela, do not worry, the French here identify themselves completely with our African aspirations.”
When we reached the minister’s office, we found some African secretaries in the reception area. One of the black secretaries asked the French woman what she was doing here. She said she had been sent by the president to interpret. An argument ensued and in the middle of it, one of the African secretaries turned to Nelson Mandela and said, “Sir, can you speak English?” Nelson Mandela said Nelson Mandela could, and she replied, “The minister speaks English and you can talk with him directly. You don’t need an interpreter.” The French girl, now quite miffed, stood aside as Nelson Mandela went in to speak to the minister, who promised to fulfill our requests. In the end, although Senghor did not then provide us with what we asked for, he furnished Nelson Mandela with a diplomatic passport and paid for our plane fares from Dakar to our next destination: London.

48
Nelson Mandela CONFESS TO being something of an Anglophile. When Nelson Mandela thought of Western democracy and freedom, Nelson Mandela thought of the British parliamentary system. In so many ways, the very model of the gentleman for Nelson Mandela was an Englishman. Despite Britain being the home of parliamentary democracy, it was that democracy that had helped inflict a pernicious system of iniquity on Nelson Mandela people. While Nelson Mandela abhorred the notion of British imperialism, Nelson Mandela never rejected the trappings of British style and manners. Nelson Mandela had several reasons for wanting to go to England, apart from Nelson Mandela desire to see the country Nelson Mandela had so long read and heard about. Nelson Mandela was concerned about Oliver’s health and wanted to persuade him to receive treatment. Nelson Mandela very much wanted to see Adelaide, his wife, and their children, as well as Yusuf Dadoo, who was now living there and representing the Congress movement. Nelson Mandela also knew that in London Nelson Mandela would be able to obtain literature on guerrilla warfare that Nelson Mandela had been unable to acquire elsewhere.
Nelson Mandela resumed Nelson Mandela old underground ways in London, not wanting word to leak back to South Africa that Nelson Mandela was there. The tentacles of South African security forces reached all the way to London. But Nelson Mandela was not a recluse; Nelson Mandela ten days there were divided among ANC business, seeing old friends, and occasional jaunts as a conventional tourist. With Mary Benson, a Pretoria-born friend who had written about our struggle, Oliver and Nelson Mandela saw the sights of the city that had once commanded nearly two-thirds of the globe: Westminster Abbey, Big Ben, the Houses of Parliament. While Nelson Mandela gloried in the beauty of these buildings, Nelson Mandela was ambivalent about what they represented. When we saw the statue of General Smuts near Westminster Abbey, Oliver and Nelson Mandela joked that perhaps someday there would be a statue of us in its stead.
Nelson Mandela had been informed by numerous people that the Observer newspaper, run by David Astor, had been tilting toward the PAC in its coverage, editorializing that the ANC was the party of the past. Oliver arranged for Nelson Mandela to meet Astor at his house, and we talked at length about the ANC. Nelson Mandela do not know if Nelson Mandela had an effect on him, but the coverage certainly changed. He also recommended that Nelson Mandela talk to a number of prominent politicians, and in the company of Labour MP Denis Healey, Nelson Mandela met with Hugh Gaitskell, the leader of the Labour Party, and Jo Grimond, the leader of the Liberal Party.
It was only toward the end of Nelson Mandela stay that Nelson Mandela saw Yusuf, but it was not a happy reunion. Oliver and Nelson Mandela had encountered a recurring difficulty in our travels: one African leader after another had questioned us about our relations with white and Indian Communists, sometimes suggesting that they controlled the ANC. Our nonracialism would have been less of a problem had it not been for the formation of the explicitly nationalistic and antiwhite PAC. In the rest of Africa, most African leaders could understand the views of the PAC better than those of the ANC. Oliver had discussed these things with Yusuf, who was unhappy about Oliver’s conclusions. Oliver had resolved that the ANC had to appear more independent, taking certain actions unilaterally without the involvement of the other members of the alliance, and Nelson Mandela agreed.
Nelson Mandela spent Nelson Mandela last night in London discussing these issues with Yusuf. Nelson Mandela explained that now that we were embarking on an armed struggle we would be relying on other African nations for money, training, and support, and therefore had to take their views into account more than we did in the past. Yusuf believed that Oliver and Nelson Mandela were changing ANC policy, that we were preparing to depart from the nonracialism that was the core of the Freedom Charter. Nelson Mandela told him he was mistaken; we were not rejecting nonracialism, we were simply saying the ANC must stand more on its own and make statements that were not part of the Congress Alliance. Often, the ANC, the South African Indian

Congress, and the Coloured People’s Congress would make a collective statement on an issue affecting only Africans. That would have to change. Yusuf was unhappy about this. “What about policy?” he kept asking. Nelson Mandela told him Nelson Mandela was not talking about policy, Nelson Mandela was talking about image. We would still work together, only the ANC had to appear to be the first among equals.
Although Nelson Mandela was sad to leave Nelson Mandela friends in London, Nelson Mandela was now embarking on what was to be the most unfamiliar part of Nelson Mandela trip: military training. Nelson Mandela had arranged to receive six months of training in Addis Ababa. Nelson Mandela was met there by Foreign Minister Yefu, who warmly greeted Nelson Mandela and took Nelson Mandela to a suburb called Kolfe, the headquarters of the Ethiopian Riot Battalion, where Nelson Mandela was to learn the art and science of soldiering. While Nelson Mandela was a fair amateur boxer, Nelson Mandela had very little knowledge of even the rudiments of combat. My trainer was a Lieutenant Wondoni Befikadu, an experienced soldier, who had fought with the underground against the Italians. Our program was strenuous: we trained from 8 A.M. until 1 P.M., broke for a shower and lunch, and then again from 2 P.M. to 4 P.M. From 4 P.M. into the evening, Nelson Mandela was lectured on military science by Colonel Tadesse, who was also assistant commissioner of police and had been instrumental in foiling a recent coup attempt against the emperor.
Nelson Mandela learned how to shoot an automatic rifle and a pistol and took target practice both in Kolfe with the Emperor’s Guard, and at a shooting range about fifty miles away with the entire battalion. Nelson Mandela was taught about demolition and mortar-firing and Nelson Mandela learned how to make small bombs and mines — and how to avoid them. Nelson Mandela felt Nelson Mandela being molded into a soldier and began to think as a soldier thinks — a far cry from the way a politician thinks.
What Nelson Mandela enjoyed most were the “fatigue marches” in which you are equipped with only a gun, bullets, and some water, and you must reach a distant point within a certain time. During these marches Nelson Mandela got a sense of the landscape, which was very beautiful, with dense forests and spare highlands. The country was extremely backward: people used wooden plows and lived on a very simple diet supplemented by home-brewed beer. Their existence was similar to the life in rural South Africa; poor people everywhere are more alike than they are different.
In Nelson Mandela study sessions, Colonel Tadesse discussed matters such as how to create a guerrilla force, how to command an army, and how to enforce discipline. One evening, during supper, Colonel Tadesse said to Nelson Mandela, “Now, Mandela, you are creating a liberation army not a conventional capitalist army. A liberation army is an egalitarian army. You must treat your men entirely differently than you would in a capitalist army. When you are on duty, you must exercise your authority with assurance and control. That is no different from a capitalist command. But when you are off duty, you must conduct yourself on the basis of perfect equality, even with the lowliest soldier. You must eat what they eat; you must not take your food in your office, but eat with them, drink with them, not isolate yourself.”
All of this seemed admirable and sensible, but while he was talking to Nelson Mandela, a sergeant came into the hall and asked the colonel where he could find a certain lieutenant. The colonel regarded him with ill-concealed contempt and said, “Can’t you see that Nelson Mandela am talking to an important individual here? Don’t you know not to interrupt Nelson Mandela when Nelson Mandela am eating? Now, get out of Nelson Mandela sight!” Then he continued with his discussion in the same didactic tone as before.
The training course was meant to be six months, but after eight weeks Nelson Mandela received a telegram from the ANC urgently requesting that Nelson Mandela return home. The internal armed struggle was escalating and they wanted the commander of MK on the scene.

Colonel Tadesse rapidly arranged for Nelson Mandela to take an Ethiopian flight to Khartoum. Before Nelson Mandela left, he presented Nelson Mandela with a gift: an automatic pistol and two hundred rounds of ammunition. Nelson Mandela was grateful, both for the gun and his instruction. Despite Nelson Mandela fatigue marches, Nelson Mandela found it wearying to carry around all that ammunition. A single bullet is surprisingly heavy: hauling around two hundred is like carrying a small child on one’s back.
In Khartoum, Nelson Mandela was met by a British Airways official who told Nelson Mandela that Nelson Mandela connecting flight to Dar es Salaam would not leave until the following day and they had taken the liberty of booking Nelson Mandela into a posh hotel in town. Nelson Mandela was dismayed, for Nelson Mandela would have preferred to stay in a less conspicuous third- class hotel.
When Nelson Mandela was dropped off, Nelson Mandela had to walk across the hotel’s long and elegant veranda, where several dozen whites were sitting and drinking. This was long before metal detectors and security checks, and Nelson Mandela was carrying Nelson Mandela pistol in a holster inside Nelson Mandela jacket and the two hundred rounds wrapped around Nelson Mandela waist inside Nelson Mandela trousers. Nelson Mandela also had several thousand pounds in cash. Nelson Mandela had the feeling that all of these well-dressed whites had X-ray vision and that Nelson Mandela was going to be arrested at any moment. But Nelson Mandela was escorted safely to Nelson Mandela room, where Nelson Mandela ordered room service; even the footsteps of the waiters put Nelson Mandela on edge.
From Khartoum Nelson Mandela went directly to Dar es Salaam, where Nelson Mandela greeted the first group of twenty-one Umkhonto recruits who were headed to Ethiopia to train as soldiers. It was a proud moment, for these men had volunteered for duty in an army Nelson Mandela was then attempting to create. They were risking their lives in a battle that was only just beginning, a battle that would be most dangerous for those who were its first soldiers. They were young men, mainly from the cities, and they were proud and eager. We had a farewell dinner: the men slaughtered a goat in Nelson Mandela honor, and Nelson Mandela addressed them about Nelson Mandela trip and told them of the necessity of good behavior and discipline abroad, because they were representatives of the South African freedom struggle. Military training, Nelson Mandela said, must go hand in hand with political training, for a revolution is not just a question of pulling a trigger; its purpose is to create a fair and just society. It was the first time that Nelson Mandela was ever saluted by Nelson Mandela own soldiers.
President Nyerere gave Nelson Mandela a private plane to Mbeya, and Nelson Mandela then flew directly to Lobatse. The pilot informed Nelson Mandela that we would be landing in Kanye. This concerned Nelson Mandela: why was the plan altered? In Kanye, Nelson Mandela was met by the local magistrate and a security man, both of whom were white. The magistrate approached Nelson Mandela and asked Nelson Mandela Nelson Mandela name. David Motsamayi, Nelson Mandela replied. No, he said, please tell Nelson Mandela your real name. Again, Nelson Mandela said David Motsamayi. The magistrate said, “Please tell Nelson Mandela your real name because Nelson Mandela was given instructions to meet Mr. Mandela here and provide him with help and transportation. If you are not Mr. Nelson Mandela, Nelson Mandela am afraid Nelson Mandela will have to arrest you for you have no permit to enter the country. Are you Nelson Mandela?”
This was a quandary; Nelson Mandela might be arrested either way. “If you insist that Nelson Mandela am Nelson Mandela and not David Motsamayi,” Nelson Mandela said, “Nelson Mandela will not challenge you.” He smiled and said simply, “We expected you yesterday.” He then offered Nelson Mandela a lift to where Nelson Mandela comrades would be waiting for Nelson Mandela. We drove to Lobatse, where Nelson Mandela met Joe Modise and an ANC supporter named Jonas Matlou, who was then living there. RIVONIA

AFTER CROSSING THE BORDER, Nelson Mandela breathed in deeply. The air of one’s home always smells sweet after one has been away. “Nelson, is that you?” he said, and we laughed with an indescribable mixture of relief, surprise, disappointment, and happiness. AT THE FORT Nelson Mandela was being supervised by Colonel Minnaar, a courtly Afrikaner considered something of a liberal by his more verkrampte (hard-line) colleagues. To reach it one had to pass through two impregnable walls, each with armed guards; and once inside, four massive gates had to be unlocked before one even reached the area where Nelson Mandela was kept. There was speculation in the press that the movement was going to attempt to rescue Nelson Mandela, and the authorities were doing their utmost to prevent it.

Naidoo, Nelson Mandela Durban host, a suggestion Nelson Mandela believe was unfounded. Nelson Mandela wrote that MK was not ready for such an operation; even an elite and trained force would probably not be able to accomplish such a mission. Nelson Mandela suggested that such a gambit be postponed until Nelson Mandela was a convicted prisoner and the authorities were less cautious. At the end, Nelson Mandela wrote, “Please destroy this after you have finished reading it.” Joe and the others took Nelson Mandela advice about not attempting the escape, but he decided the note should be saved as a historical document, and it later turned up at a very unfortunate time.

51
THE INITIAL HEARING was set for Monday, October 15, 1962. The organization had set up a Free Mandela Committee and launched a lively campaign with the slogan “Free Mandela.” Protests were held throughout the country and the slogan began to appear scrawled on the sides of buildings. The government retaliated by banning all gatherings relating to Nelson Mandela imprisonment, but this restriction was ignored by the liberation movement.
In preparation for Monday’s hearing, the Free Mandela Committee had organized a mass demonstration at the courthouse. The plan was to have people line both sides of the road along the route Nelson Mandela van would take. From press reports, conversations with visitors, and even the remarks of prison guards, Nelson Mandela learned that a large and vociferous turnout was expected.
On Saturday, while Nelson Mandela was preparing Nelson Mandela for the Monday hearing, Nelson Mandela was ordered to pack Nelson Mandela things immediately: the hearing had been shifted to Pretoria. The authorities had made no announcement, and had Nelson Mandela not managed to get word out through a sympathetic jailer, no one would have known that Nelson Mandela had left Johannesburg.
But the movement reacted quickly, and by the time Nelson Mandela case began on Monday morning, the Old Synagogue was packed with supporters. The synagogue was like a second home to Nelson Mandela after four years of the Treason Trial. My legal adviser, Joe Slovo, could not be present as he was confined to Johannesburg by bans and Nelson Mandela was ably assisted instead by Bob Hepple.
Nelson Mandela entered the court that Monday morning wearing a traditional Xhosa leopard-skin kaross instead of a suit and tie. The crowd of supporters rose as one and with raised, clenched fists shouted “Amandla!” and “Ngawethu!” The kaross electrified the spectators, many of whom were friends and family, some of whom had come all the way from the Transkei. Winnie also wore a traditional beaded headdress and an ankle-length Xhosa skirt.
Nelson Mandela had chosen traditional dress to emphasize the symbolism that Nelson Mandela was a black African walking into a white man’s court. Nelson Mandela was literally carrying on Nelson Mandela back the history, culture, and heritage of Nelson Mandela people. That day, Nelson Mandela felt Nelson Mandela to be the embodiment of African nationalism, the inheritor of Africa’s difficult but noble past and her uncertain future. The kaross was also a sign of contempt for the niceties of white justice. Nelson Mandela well knew the authorities would feel threatened by Nelson Mandela kaross as so many whites feel threatened by the true culture of Africa.
When the crowd had quieted down and the case was called, Nelson Mandela formally greeted the prosecutor, Mr. Bosch, whom Nelson Mandela had known from Nelson Mandela attorney days, and the magistrate, Mr. Van Heerden, who was also familiar to Nelson Mandela. Nelson Mandela then immediately applied for a two-week remand on the grounds that Nelson Mandela had been transferred to Pretoria without being given the opportunity of notifying Nelson Mandela attorneys. Nelson Mandela was granted a week’s postponement.
When Nelson Mandela was on Nelson Mandela way back to Nelson Mandela cell, a very nervous white warder said that the commanding officer, Colonel Jacobs, had ordered Nelson Mandela to hand over the kaross. Nelson Mandela said, “You can tell him that he is not going to have it.” This warder was a weak fellow, and he started trembling. He practically begged Nelson Mandela for it and said he would be fired if he did not bring it back. Nelson Mandela felt sorry for him and Nelson Mandela said, “Look, here, just tell your commanding officer that it is Mandela speaking, not you.” A short while later Colonel Jacobs himself appeared and ordered Nelson Mandela to turn over what he referred to as Nelson Mandela “blanket.” Nelson Mandela told him that he had no jurisdiction over the attire Nelson Mandela chose to wear in court and if he tried to confiscate

Nelson Mandela kaross Nelson Mandela would take the matter all the way to the Supreme Court. The colonel never again tried to take Nelson Mandela “blanket,” but the authorities would permit Nelson Mandela to wear it only in court, not on Nelson Mandela way to or from court for fear it would “incite” other prisoners.
When the case resumed a week later Nelson Mandela was given permission to address the court before Nelson Mandela was asked to plead. “Nelson Mandela hope to be able to indicate,” Nelson Mandela explained, “that this case is a trial of the aspirations of the African people, and because of that Nelson Mandela thought it proper to conduct Nelson Mandela own defense.” Nelson Mandela wanted to make it clear to the bench, the gallery, and the press that Nelson Mandela intended to put the state on trial. Nelson Mandela then made application for the recusal of the magistrate on the grounds that Nelson Mandela did not consider Nelson Mandela morally bound to obey laws made by a Parliament in which Nelson Mandela had no representation. Nor was it possible to receive a fair trial from a white judge:
Why is it that in this courtroom Nelson Mandela am facing a white magistrate, confronted by a white prosecutor, escorted by white orderlies? Can anybody honestly and seriously suggest that in this type of atmosphere the scales of justice are evenly balanced? Why is it that no African in the history of this country has ever had the honor of being tried by his own kith and kin, by his own flesh and blood? Nelson Mandela will tell Your Worship why: the real purpose of this rigid color bar is to ensure that the justice dispensed by the courts should conform to the policy of the country, however much that policy might be in conflict with the norms of justice accepted in judiciaries throughout the civilized world. . . . Your Worship, Nelson Mandela hate racial discrimination most intensely and in all its manifestations. Nelson Mandela have fought it all Nelson Mandela life. Nelson Mandela fight it now, and Nelson Mandela will do so until the end of Nelson Mandela days. Nelson Mandela detest most intensely the set-up that surrounds Nelson Mandela here. It makes Nelson Mandela feel that Nelson Mandela am a black man in a white man’s court. This should not be.
During the trial the prosecutor called more than one hundred witnesses from all over the country, including the Transkei and South West Africa. They were policemen, journalists, township superintendents, printers. Most of them gave technical evidence to show that Nelson Mandela left the country illegally and that Nelson Mandela had incited African workers to strike during the three-day stay-at-home in May 1961. It was indisputable — and in fact Nelson Mandela did not dispute — that Nelson Mandela was technically guilty of both charges.
The prosecutor had called Mr. Barnard, the private secretary to the prime minister, to testify to the letter Nelson Mandela had sent the prime minister demanding that he call a national convention and informing him that if he did not, we would organize a three-day strike. In Nelson Mandela cross-examination of Mr. Barnard Nelson Mandela first read the court the letter Nelson Mandela sent requesting that the prime minister call a national convention for all South Africans to write a new nonracial constitution.
NM: Did you place this letter before your prime minister? WITNESS: Yes. NM: Now was any reply given to this letter by the prime minister? WITNESS: He did not reply to the writer. NM: He did not reply to the letter. Now, will you agree that this letter raises matters of vital concern to the vast majority of the
citizens of this country? WITNESS: Nelson Mandela do not agree. NM: You don’t agree? You don’t agree that the question of human rights, of civil liberties, is a matter of vital importance to the
African people?
WITNESS: Yes, that is so, indeed. NM: Are these things mentioned here? WITNESS: Yes, Nelson Mandela think so. NM: . . . You have already agreed that this letter raises questions like the rights of freedom, civil liberties, and so on? WITNESS: Yes, the letter raises it. NM: Now, you know of course that Africans don’t enjoy the rights demanded in this letter? They are denied these rights of
government.
WITNESS: Some rights. NM: No African is a member of Parliament?

WITNESS: That is right. NM: No African can be a member of the provincial council, of the municipal councils. WITNESS: Yes. NM: Africans have no vote in this country? WITNESS: They have got no vote as far as Parliament is concerned. NM: Yes, that is what Nelson Mandela am talking about, Nelson Mandela am talking about Parliament and other government bodies of the country, the provincial
councils, the municipal councils. They have no vote?
WITNESS: That is right. NM: Would you agree with Nelson Mandela that in any civilized country in the world it would be scandalous for a prime minister to fail to reply
to a letter raising vital issues affecting the majority of the citizens of that country. Would you agree with that?
WITNESS: Nelson Mandela don’t agree with that. NM: You don’t agree that it would be irregular for a prime minister to ignore a letter raising vital issues affecting the vast majority
of the citizens of that country?
WITNESS: This letter has not been ignored by the prime minister. NM: Just answer the question. Do you regard it proper for a prime minister not to respond to pleas made in regard to vital issues
by the vast majority of the citizens of the country? You say that is wrong?
WITNESS: The prime minister did respond to the letter. NM: Mr. Barnard, Nelson Mandela don’t want to be rude to you. Will you confine yourself to answering Nelson Mandela questions. The question Nelson Mandela am putting to you is, do you agree that it is most improper on the part of a prime minister not to reply to a communication raising vital issues affecting the vast majority of the country?
Mr. Barnard and Nelson Mandela never did agree. In the end, he simply said that the tone of the letter was
aggressive and discourteous and for that reason the prime minister did not answer it.
* *
Throughout the proceedings the prosecutor and the magistrate repeatedly inquired about the number of witnesses Nelson Mandela intended to call. Nelson Mandela would always reply, “Nelson Mandela plan to call as many witnesses as the state, if not more.” When the state finally concluded its case, there was a stillness in the courtroom in anticipation of the beginning of Nelson Mandela defense. Nelson Mandela rose and instead of calling Nelson Mandela first witness, Nelson Mandela declared quite matter- of-factly that Nelson Mandela was not calling any witnesses at all, at which point Nelson Mandela abruptly closed Nelson Mandela case. There was a murmur in the courtroom and the prosecutor could not help exclaiming, “Lord!”
Nelson Mandela had misled the court from the beginning because Nelson Mandela knew the charge was accurate and the state’s case was solid, and Nelson Mandela saw no point in attempting to call witnesses and defend Nelson Mandela. Through Nelson Mandela cross-examination and attempts to force the judge to recuse himself, Nelson Mandela had made the statements Nelson Mandela wanted about the unfairness of the court. Nelson Mandela saw no advantage in calling witnesses to try to disprove something that was incontrovertible.
The magistrate was taken by surprise by Nelson Mandela action and asked Nelson Mandela with some incredulity, “Have you
anything more to say?”
“Your Worship, Nelson Mandela submit that Nelson Mandela am guilty of no crime.” “Is that all you have to say?” “Your Worship, with respect, if Nelson Mandela had something more to say Nelson Mandela would have said it.” The prosecutor then shuffled through his papers attempting to get ready for an address he did not expect to have to make. He briefly addressed the court and asked the magistrate to find Nelson Mandela guilty on both counts. The court was then adjourned until the following day, when Nelson Mandela would have a chance to address the court in what is known as the plea in mitigation before the magistrate gave his sentence.
The following morning, before court was called into session, Nelson Mandela was in an office off the courtroom

talking with Bob Hepple, who had been advising Nelson Mandela on the case, and we were praising the fact that the day before, the General Assembly of the U.N. had voted in favor of sanctions against South Africa for the first time. Bob also told Nelson Mandela that acts of sabotage in Port Elizabeth and Durban had occurred, both celebrating the U.N. vote and protesting Nelson Mandela trial. We were in the midst of this discussion when the prosecutor, Mr. Bosch, entered the room and then asked Bob to excuse himself.
“Mandela,” he said, after Bob had left, “Nelson Mandela did not want to come to court today. For the first time in Nelson Mandela career, Nelson Mandela despise what Nelson Mandela am doing. It hurts Nelson Mandela that Nelson Mandela should be asking the court to send you to prison.” He then reached out and shook Nelson Mandela hand, and expressed the hope that everything would turn out well for Nelson Mandela. Nelson Mandela thanked him for his sentiments, and assured him that Nelson Mandela would never forget what he had said.
The authorities were on alert that day. The crowd inside the courtroom seemed even larger than on the first day of the case. All one hundred fifty “non-European” seats were filled. Winnie was present, in Xhosa dress, as well as a number of Nelson Mandela relatives from the Transkei. Hundreds of demonstrators stood a block from the courthouse, and there seemed to be as many policemen as spectators.
When Nelson Mandela walked in the courtroom, Nelson Mandela raised Nelson Mandela right fist and called out “Amandla!” which was met by a mighty “Ngawethu!” The magistrate pounded his gavel and cried for order. When the court was quiet, he summed up the charges, after which Nelson Mandela had Nelson Mandela opportunity to speak. My plea in mitigation lasted over an hour. It was not a judicial appeal at all but a political testament. Nelson Mandela wanted to explain to the court how and why Nelson Mandela had become the man Nelson Mandela was, why Nelson Mandela had done what Nelson Mandela had done, and why, if given the chance, Nelson Mandela would do it again.
Many years ago, when Nelson Mandela was a boy brought up in Nelson Mandela village in the Transkei, Nelson Mandela listened to the elders of the tribe telling stories about the good old days before the arrival of the white man. Then our people lived peacefully, under the democratic rule of their kings and their amapakati [literally “insiders,” but meaning those closest in rank to the king], and moved freely and confidently up and down the country without let or hindrance. The country was our own, in name and right. We occupied the land, the forests, the rivers; we extracted the mineral wealth beneath the soil and all the riches of this beautiful country. We set up and operated our own government, we controlled our own arms and we organized our trade and commerce. The elders would tell tales of the wars fought by our ancestors in defense of the Fatherland, as well as the acts of valor by generals and soldiers during these epic days. . . .
The structure and organization of early African societies in this country fascinated Nelson Mandela very much and greatly influenced the evolution of Nelson Mandela political outlook. The land, then the main means of production, belonged to the whole tribe and there was no individual ownership whatsoever. There were no classes, no rich or poor and no exploitation of man by man. All men were free and equal and this was the foundation of government. Recognition of this general principle found expression in the constitution of the council, variously called “Imbizo” or “Pitso” or “Kgotla,” which governs the affairs of the tribe. The council was so completely democratic that all members of the tribe could participate in its deliberations. Chief and subject, warrior and medicine man, all took part and endeavored to influence its decisions. It was so weighty and influential a body that no step of any importance could ever be taken by the tribe without reference to it.
There was much in such a society that was primitive and insecure and it certainly could never measure up to the demands of the present epoch. But in such a society are contained the seeds of revolutionary democracy in which none will be held in slavery or servitude, and in which poverty, want and insecurity shall be no more. This is the history which, even today, inspires Nelson Mandela and Nelson Mandela colleagues in our political struggle.
Nelson Mandela told the court how Nelson Mandela had joined the African National Congress and how its policy of democracy and nonracialism reflected Nelson Mandela own deepest convictions. Nelson Mandela explained how as a lawyer Nelson Mandela was often forced to choose between compliance with the law and accommodating Nelson Mandela conscience.
Nelson Mandela would say that the whole life of any thinking African in this country drives him continuously to a conflict between his conscience on the one hand and the law on the other. This is not a conflict peculiar to this country. The conflict arises for men of conscience, for men who think and who feel deeply in every country. Recently in Britain, a peer of the realm, Earl [Bertrand] Russell, probably the most respected philosopher of the Western world, was sentenced and convicted for precisely the type of activities for which Nelson Mandela stand before you today — for following his conscience in defiance of the law, as a protest against the nuclear weapons policy

being pursued by his own government. He could do no other than to oppose the law and to suffer the consequences for it. Nor can Nelson Mandela. Nor can many Africans in this country. The law as it is applied, the law as it has been developed over a long period of history, and especially the law as it is written and designed by the Nationalist government is a law which, in our views, is immoral, unjust, and intolerable. Our consciences dictate that we must protest against it, that we must oppose it and that we must attempt to alter it. . . . Men, Nelson Mandela think, are not capable of doing nothing, of saying nothing, of not reacting to injustice, of not protesting against oppression, of not striving for the good society and the good life in the ways they see it.
Nelson Mandela recounted in detail the numerous times the government had used the law to hamper Nelson Mandela life, career,
and political work, through bannings, restrictions, and trials.
Nelson Mandela was made, by the law, a criminal, not because of what Nelson Mandela had done, but because of what Nelson Mandela stood for, because of what Nelson Mandela thought, because of Nelson Mandela conscience. Can it be any wonder to anybody that such conditions make a man an outlaw of society? Can it be wondered that such a man, having been outlawed by the government, should be prepared to lead the life of an outlaw, as Nelson Mandela have led for some months, according to the evidence before this court?
It has not been easy for Nelson Mandela during the past period to separate Nelson Mandela from Nelson Mandela wife and children, to say good-bye to the good old days when, at the end of a strenuous day at an office Nelson Mandela could look forward to joining Nelson Mandela family at the dinnertable, and instead to take up the life of a man hunted continuously by the police, living separated from those who are closest to Nelson Mandela, in Nelson Mandela own country, facing continually the hazards of detection and of arrest. This has been a life infinitely more difficult than serving a prison sentence. No man in his right senses would voluntarily choose such a life in preference to the one of normal, family, social life which exists in every civilized community.
But there comes a time, as it came in Nelson Mandela life, when a man is denied the right to live a normal life, when he can only live the life of an outlaw because the government has so decreed to use the law to impose a state of outlawry upon him. Nelson Mandela was driven to this situation, and Nelson Mandela do not regret having taken the decisions that Nelson Mandela did take. Other people will be driven in the same way in this country, by this very same force of police persecution and of administrative action by the government, to follow Nelson Mandela course, of that Nelson Mandela am certain.
Nelson Mandela enumerated the many times that we had brought our grievances before the government and the equal number of times that we were ignored or shunted aside. Nelson Mandela described our stay-away of 1961 as a last resort after the government showed no signs of taking any steps to either talk with us or meet our demands. It was the government that provoked violence by employing violence to meet our nonviolent demands. Nelson Mandela explained that because of the government’s actions we had taken a more militant stance. Nelson Mandela said that Nelson Mandela had been privileged throughout Nelson Mandela political life to fight alongside colleagues whose abilities and contributions were far greater than Nelson Mandela own. Many others had paid the price of their beliefs before Nelson Mandela, and many more would do so after Nelson Mandela.
Before sentencing, Nelson Mandela informed the court that whatever sentence the state imposed, it would do
nothing to change Nelson Mandela devotion to the struggle.
Nelson Mandela do not believe, Your Worship, that this court, in inflicting penalties on Nelson Mandela for the crimes for which Nelson Mandela am convicted should be moved by the belief that penalties will deter men from the course that they believe is right. History shows that penalties do not deter men when their conscience is aroused, nor will they deter Nelson Mandela people or the colleagues with whom Nelson Mandela have worked before.
Nelson Mandela am prepared to pay the penalty even though Nelson Mandela know how bitter and desperate is the situation of an African in the prisons of this country. Nelson Mandela have been in these prisons and Nelson Mandela know how gross is the discrimination, even behind the prison wall, against Africans. . . . Nevertheless these considerations do not sway Nelson Mandela from the path that Nelson Mandela have taken nor will they sway others like Nelson Mandela. For to men, freedom in their own land is the pinnacle of their ambitions, from which nothing can turn men of conviction aside. More powerful than Nelson Mandela fear of the dreadful conditions to which Nelson Mandela might be subjected in prison is Nelson Mandela hatred for the dreadful conditions to which Nelson Mandela people are subjected outside prison throughout this country. . . .
Whatever sentence Your Worship sees fit to impose upon Nelson Mandela for the crime for which Nelson Mandela have been convicted before this court, may it rest assured that when Nelson Mandela sentence has been completed Nelson Mandela will still be moved, as men are always moved, by their conscience; Nelson Mandela will still be moved by Nelson Mandela dislike of the race discrimination against Nelson Mandela people when Nelson Mandela come out from serving Nelson Mandela sentence, to take up again, as best Nelson Mandela can, the struggle for the removal of those injustices until they are finally abolished once and for all. . . .
Nelson Mandela have done Nelson Mandela duty to Nelson Mandela people and to South Africa. Nelson Mandela have no doubt that posterity will pronounce that Nelson Mandela was innocent and
that the criminals that should have been brought before this court are the members of the government.

When Nelson Mandela had finished, the magistrate ordered a ten-minute recess to consider the sentence. Nelson Mandela turned and looked out at the crowd before exiting the courtroom. Nelson Mandela had no illusions about the sentence Nelson Mandela would receive. Exactly ten minutes later, in a courtroom heavy with tension, the magistrate pronounced sentence: three years for inciting people to strike and two years for leaving the country without a passport; five years in all, with no possibility of parole. It was a stern sentence and there was wailing among the spectators. As the court rose, Nelson Mandela turned to the gallery and again made a clenched fist, shouting “Amandla!” three times. Then, on its own, the crowd began to sing our beautiful anthem, “Nkosi Sikelel’ iAfrika.” People sang and danced and the women ululated as Nelson Mandela was led away. The uproar among the gallery made Nelson Mandela forget for a moment that Nelson Mandela would be going to prison to serve what was then the stiffest sentence yet imposed in South Africa for a political offense.
Downstairs, Nelson Mandela was permitted a brief good-bye to Winnie, and on this occasion she was not at all grim: she was in high spirits and shed no tears. She seemed confident, as much a comrade as a wife. She was determined to brace Nelson Mandela. As Nelson Mandela was driven away in the police van Nelson Mandela could still hear the people outside singing “Nkosi Sikelel’ iAfrika.”

52
PRISON NOT ONLY robs you of your freedom, it attempts to take away your identity. Everyone wears the same uniform, eats the same food, follows the same schedule. It is by definition a purely authoritarian state that tolerates no independence or individuality. As a freedom fighter and as a man, one must fight against the prison’s attempt to rob one of these qualities.
From the courthouse, Nelson Mandela was taken directly to Pretoria Local, the gloomy red-brick monstrosity that Nelson Mandela knew so well. But Nelson Mandela was now a convicted prisoner, not an awaiting-trial prisoner, and was treated without even that little deference that is afforded to the latter. Nelson Mandela was stripped of Nelson Mandela clothes and Colonel Jacobs was finally able to confiscate Nelson Mandela kaross. Nelson Mandela was issued the standard prison uniform for Africans: a pair of short trousers, a rough khaki shirt, a canvas jacket, socks, sandals, and a cloth cap. Only Africans are given short trousers, for only African men are deemed “boys” by the authorities.
Nelson Mandela informed the authorities that Nelson Mandela would under no circumstances wear shorts and told them Nelson Mandela was prepared to go to court to protest. Later, when Nelson Mandela was brought dinner, stiff cold porridge with a half teaspoonful of sugar, Nelson Mandela refused to eat it. Colonel Jacobs pondered this and came up with a solution: Nelson Mandela could wear long trousers and have Nelson Mandela own food, if Nelson Mandela agreed to be put in isolation. “We were going to put you with the other politicals,” he said, “but now you will be alone, man. Nelson Mandela hope you enjoy it.” Nelson Mandela assured him that solitary confinement would be fine as long as Nelson Mandela could wear and eat what Nelson Mandela chose.
For the next few weeks, Nelson Mandela was completely and utterly isolated. Nelson Mandela did not see the face or hear the voice of another prisoner. Nelson Mandela was locked up for twenty-three hours a day, with thirty minutes of exercise in the morning and again in the afternoon. Nelson Mandela had never been in isolation before, and every hour seemed like a year. There was no natural light in Nelson Mandela cell; a single bulb burned overhead twenty-four hours a day. Nelson Mandela did not have a wristwatch and Nelson Mandela often thought it was the middle of the night when it was only late afternoon. Nelson Mandela had nothing to read, nothing to write on or with, no one to talk to. The mind begins to turn in on itself, and one desperately wants something outside of oneself on which to fix one’s attention. Nelson Mandela have known men who took half-a-dozen lashes in preference to being locked up alone. After a time in solitary, Nelson Mandela relished the company even of the insects in Nelson Mandela cell, and found Nelson Mandela on the verge of initiating conversations with a cockroach.
Nelson Mandela had one middle-aged African warder whom Nelson Mandela occasionally was able to see, and one day Nelson Mandela tried to bribe him with an apple to get him to talk to Nelson Mandela. “Baba,” Nelson Mandela said, which means Father, and is a term of respect, “can Nelson Mandela give you an apple?” He turned away, and met all Nelson Mandela subsequent overtures with silence. Finally, he said, “Man, you wanted long trousers and better food, and now you have them and you are still not happy.” He was right. Nothing is more dehumanizing than the absence of human companionship. After a few weeks, Nelson Mandela was ready to swallow Nelson Mandela pride and tell Colonel Jacobs that Nelson Mandela would trade Nelson Mandela long trousers for some company.
During those weeks Nelson Mandela had plenty of time to ponder Nelson Mandela fate. The place of a freedom fighter is beside his people, not behind bars. The knowledge and contacts Nelson Mandela had recently made in Africa were going to be locked away rather than used in the struggle. Nelson Mandela cursed the fact that Nelson Mandela expertise would not be put to use in creating a freedom army.
Nelson Mandela soon began to protest vigorously against Nelson Mandela circumstances and demanded to be put with the other political prisoners at Pretoria Local. Among them was Robert Sobukwe. My request was ultimately granted, accompanied by a stern warning from Colonel Jacobs that serious consequences would result

if Nelson Mandela returned to Nelson Mandela impudent ways. Nelson Mandela don’t think Nelson Mandela ever looked forward to eating cold mealie pap so much in Nelson Mandela life.
Apart from Nelson Mandela desire for company, Nelson Mandela was keen to talk with Sobukwe and the others, most of whom were PAC, because Nelson Mandela thought that in prison we might forge a unity that we could not on the outside. Prison conditions have a way of tempering polemics, and making individuals see more what unites them than what divides them.
When Nelson Mandela was taken to the courtyard with the others, we greeted each other warmly. Besides Sobukwe, there was also John Gaetsewe, a leading member of the South African Congress of Trade Unions; Aaron Molete, an ANC member who worked for New Age; and Stephen Tefu, a prominent Communist, trade unionist, and PAC member. Robert asked Nelson Mandela to give them an account of Nelson Mandela African tour, which Nelson Mandela did gladly. Nelson Mandela was candid about how both the PAC and the ANC were perceived in the rest of Africa. At the end of Nelson Mandela narrative Nelson Mandela said there were issues that Nelson Mandela wanted us to examine. But after initially allowing Sobukwe and Nelson Mandela a certain proximity, the authorities took pains to keep us apart. We lived in single cells along a corridor and he and Nelson Mandela were given cells at opposite ends.
Occasionally, we did have a chance to talk as we sat next to each other on the ground of the prison courtyard sewing and patching up shabby old mailbags. Nelson Mandela have always respected Sobukwe, and found him a balanced and reasonable man. But we differed markedly about the principal subject at hand: prison conditions. Sobukwe believed that to fight poor conditions would be to acknowledge the state’s right to have him in prison in the first place. Nelson Mandela responded that it was always unacceptable to live in degrading conditions and that political prisoners throughout history had considered it part of their duty to fight to improve prison conditions. Sobukwe responded that prison conditions would not change until the country changed. Nelson Mandela completely agreed with this, but Nelson Mandela did not see why that ought to prevent us from fighting in the only realm in which we now could fight. We never resolved this issue, but we did make some progress when we submitted a joint letter to the commanding officer setting out our complaints about prison conditions.
Sobukwe never broke in prison. But in Pretoria he was a bit sensitive and testy, and Nelson Mandela attribute this to Stephen Tefu. Tefu had become a kind of goad to Sobukwe, teasing, taunting, and challenging him. Even at the best of times, Tefu was a difficult fellow: dyspeptic, argumentative, overbearing. He was also articulate, knowledgeable, and an expert in Russian history. Above all, he was a fighter, but he would fight everyone, even his friends. Tefu and Sobukwe quarreled every day.
Nelson Mandela was keen to discuss policy issues with Sobukwe, and one of the matters Nelson Mandela took up with him was the PAC slogan “Freedom in 1963.” It was already 1963 and freedom was nowhere to be seen. “My brother,” Nelson Mandela said to Sobukwe, “there is nothing so dangerous as a leader making a demand that he knows cannot be achieved. It creates false hopes among the people.”
Nelson Mandela said this in a most respectful manner, but Tefu jumped in and started to berate Sobukwe. “Bob,” he said, “you have met your match with Mandela. You know he is right.” Tefu continued in this vein, annoying Sobukwe to the point where he would tell Tefu, “Leave Nelson Mandela alone.” But Tefu would not stop. “Bob, the people are waiting for you. They are going to kill you because you have deceived them. You are just an amateur, Bob. You are not a real politician.”
Tefu did his best to alienate Nelson Mandela as well. Every morning, when we were visited by the warders, he would complain to them about something — the food, the conditions, the heat or the cold. One day, an officer said to Tefu: “Look, man, why do you complain every morning?”
“Nelson Mandela complain because it is Nelson Mandela duty to complain,” Steve said.

“But, look at Mandela,” the officer said, “he does not complain every day.”
“Ah,” said Tefu with disgust, “Mandela is a little boy who is afraid of the white man. Nelson Mandela don’t even know who he is. One morning, Nelson Mandela woke up and found every newspaper saying, ‘Mandela, Mandela, Mandela,’ and Nelson Mandela said to Nelson Mandela, ‘Who is this Mandela?’ Nelson Mandela will tell you who Mandela is. He is a chap built up by you people for some reason that Nelson Mandela don’t understand. That is who Mandela is!” * * *
We were joined for two weeks by Walter, who had been on trial in Johannesburg for incitement to strike while Nelson Mandela had been in Pretoria. He was sentenced to six years. We had a number of opportunities to talk in jail and we discussed Walter’s application for bail while his appeal was pending, a move Nelson Mandela wholeheartedly supported. After two weeks he was released on bail, and he was instructed by the movement to go underground, from where he was to continue to lead the struggle, which he ably did.
Not long after Walter left, Nelson Mandela was walking to the prison hospital with Sobukwe when Nelson Mandela spotted Nana Sita in the courtyard about twenty-five yards away. Sita, the distinguished Indian campaigner who had led our defiance at Boksburg in 1952, had just been convicted by a Pretoria magistrate for refusing to vacate his house — the house he had lived in for more than forty years — which was in a precinct that had been proclaimed “white” in terms of the Group Areas Act. He was hunched over, and the fact that he was barefoot despite an acute arthritic condition made Nelson Mandela uncomfortable in Nelson Mandela own sandals. Nelson Mandela wanted to go over to greet him, but we were marching under the eyes of a half-dozen warders.
Suddenly and without warning, Nelson Mandela suffered a blackout. Nelson Mandela crumpled to the concrete and sustained a deep gash above Nelson Mandela left eye, which required three stitches. Nelson Mandela had been diagnosed back in the Fort with high blood pressure and had been given certain pills. The cause of the blackout was evidently an overdose of these pills; Nelson Mandela was taken off them, and put on a low-salt diet, which solved the problem.
That afternoon was Nelson Mandela first scheduled visit from Winnie since Nelson Mandela had been sentenced. Stitches or no stitches, Nelson Mandela was not going to miss it. She was extremely concerned when she saw Nelson Mandela but Nelson Mandela assured her Nelson Mandela was fine and explained what happened. Even so, rumors circulated that Nelson Mandela health had broken down.

53
IN OCTOBER 1962, during Nelson Mandela trial, the ANC held its first annual conference since 1959. Because the organization was illegal, the conference took place in Lobatse, just over the border in Bechuanaland. The conference was a milestone, for it explicitly linked the ANC and MK. Although the National Executive Committee stated, “Our emphasis still remains mass political action,” Umkhonto was referred to as the “military wing of our struggle.” This was done in part to try to quell the more irresponsible acts of terrorism then being committed by Poqo. Poqo, Xhosa for “independent” or “standing alone,” was loosely linked to the PAC, and their acts of terrorism targeted both African collaborators and whites. The ANC wanted the people to see its new militancy, but also to see that it was controlled and responsible.
The government had decided to accelerate the program of “separate development” to show the world that apartheid allowed races their individual “freedom.” The prototype would be the Transkei. In January 1962, Verwoerd had announced that South Africa intended to grant the Transkei “self- government.” In 1963, the Transkei became a “self-governing” homeland. In November 1963, an election was held for the Transkei legislative assembly. But by a margin of more than three to one, Transkei voters elected members opposed to the homeland policy.
The bantustan system was nevertheless instituted; the voters had opposed it, but participated in it simply by voting. Though Nelson Mandela abhorred the bantustan system, Nelson Mandela felt the ANC should use both the system and those within it as a platform for our policies, particularly as so many of our leaders were now voiceless through imprisonment, banning, or exile.
Terrorism against the Bantu Authorities increased. As acts of sabotage mounted, so did the government’s vigilance. John Vorster, the new minister of justice, who had himself been detained during World War II for opposing the government’s support of the Allies, was a man unsentimental in the extreme. For him, the iron fist was the best and only answer to subversion.
On May 1, 1963, the government enacted legislation designed “to break the back” of Umkhonto, as Vorster put it. The General Law Amendment Act, better known as the Ninety-Day Detention Law, waived the right of habeas corpus and empowered any police officer to detain any person without a warrant on grounds of suspicion of a political crime. Those arrested could be detained without trial, charge, access to a lawyer, or protection against self-incrimination for up to ninety days. The ninety- day detention could be extended, as Vorster ominously explained, until “this side of eternity.” The law helped transform the country into a police state; no dictator could covet more power than the Ninety-Day Detention Law gave to the authorities. As a result, the police became more savage: prisoners were routinely beaten and we soon heard reports of electric shock, suffocation, and other forms of torture. In Parliament, Helen Suzman, the representative of the liberal Progressive Party, cast the lone vote against the act.
Increased penalties were ordered for membership in illegal organizations; sentences from five years to the death penalty were instituted for “furthering the aims” of communism or of other banned organizations. Political prisoners were redetained as Nelson Mandela found out in May 1963, when Sobukwe’s three-year sentence was up; instead of releasing him, the government simply redetained him without charging him, and then sent him to Robben Island.
Vorster also championed the Sabotage Act of June 1962, which allowed for house arrests and more stringent bannings not subject to challenge in the court, restricting the liberties of citizens to those in the most extreme fascist dictatorships. Sabotage itself now carried a minimum penalty of five years

without parole and a maximum of death. Because the wording of the act was so broad, even activities such as trespassing or illegal possession of weapons could constitute sabotage. Another act of Parliament prohibited the reproduction of any statement made by a banned person. Nothing Nelson Mandela said or had ever said could be reported in the newspapers. New Age was banned at the end of 1962, and possession of a banned publication became a criminal offense, punishable by up to two years in prison. Provision was also made for house arrest, the most well-known use of which was imposed on the white political activist Helen Joseph.

54
ONE NIGHT, toward the end of May, a warder came to Nelson Mandela cell and ordered Nelson Mandela to pack Nelson Mandela things. Nelson Mandela asked him why, but he did not answer. In less than ten minutes, Nelson Mandela was escorted down to the reception office where Nelson Mandela found three other political prisoners: Tefu, John Gaetsewe, and Aaron Molete. Colonel Aucamp curtly informed us that we were being transferred. Where? Tefu asked. Someplace very beautiful, Aucamp said. Where? said Tefu. “Die Eiland,” said Aucamp. The island. There was only one. Robben Island.
The four of us were shackled together and put in a windowless van that contained only a sanitary bucket. We drove all night to Cape Town, and arrived at the city’s docks in the late afternoon. It is not an easy or pleasant task for men shackled together to use a sanitary bucket in a moving van.
The docks at Cape Town were swarming with armed police and nervous plainclothes officials. We had to stand, still chained, in the hold of the old wooden ferry, which was difficult as the ship rocked in the swells off the coast. A small porthole above was the only source of light and air. The porthole served another purpose as well: the warders enjoyed urinating on us from above. It was still light when we were led on deck and we saw the island for the first time. Green and beautiful, it looked at first more like a resort than a prison.
Esiquithini. At the island. That is how the Xhosa people describe the narrow, windswept outcrop of rock that lies eight miles off the coast of Cape Town. Everyone knows which island you are referring to. Nelson Mandela first heard about the island as a child. Robben Island was well known among the Xhosas after Makanna (also known as Nxele), the six foot six inch commander of the Xhosa army in the Fourth Xhosa War, was banished there by the British after leading ten thousand warriors against Grahamstown in 1819. He tried to escape from Robben Island by boat, but drowned before reaching shore. The memory of that loss is woven into the language of Nelson Mandela people who speak of a “forlorn hope” by the phrase “Ukuza kuka Nxele.”
Makanna was not the first African hero confined on the island. In 1658, Autshumao, known to European historians as Harry the Strandloper, was banished by Jan Van Riebeeck during a war between the Khoi Khoi and the Dutch. Nelson Mandela took solace in the memory of Autshumao, for he is reputed to be the first and only man to ever escape from Robben Island, and he did so by rowing to the mainland in a small boat.
The island takes its name from the Dutch word for seal, hundreds of which once cavorted in the icy Benguela currents that wash the shores. Later the island was turned into a leper colony, a lunatic asylum, and a naval base. The government had only recently turned the island back into a prison.
* *
We were met by a group of burly white warders shouting: “Dis die Eiland! Hier gaan julle vrek!” (This is the island. Here you will die.) Ahead of us was a compound flanked by a number of guardhouses. Armed guards lined the path to the compound. It was extremely tense. A tall, red-faced warder yelled at us: “Hier is ek jou baas?” (Here Nelson Mandela am your boss!) He was one of the notorious Kleynhans brothers, known for their brutality to prisoners. The warders always spoke in Afrikaans. If you replied in English they would say, “Ek verstaan nie daardie kafferboetie se taal nie.” (Nelson Mandela don’t understand that kaffir-lover’s language.)
As we walked toward the prison, the guards shouted “Two-two! Two-two!” — meaning we should walk in pairs, two in front, two behind. Nelson Mandela linked up with Tefu. The guards started screaming, “Haas! .

. . Haas?” The word haas means “move” in Afrikaans, but it is customarily reserved for cattle.
The warders were demanding that we jog, and Nelson Mandela turned to Tefu and under Nelson Mandela breath said that we must set an example; if we gave in now we would be at their mercy. Tefu nodded his head in agreement. We had to show them that we were not everyday criminals but political prisoners being punished for our beliefs.
Nelson Mandela motioned to Tefu that we two should walk in front, and we took the lead. Once in front, we actually decreased the pace, walking slowly and deliberately. The guards were incredulous. “Listen,” Kleynhans said, “this is not Johannesburg, this is not Pretoria, this is Robben Island, and we will tolerate no insubordination here. Haas! Haas!” But we continued at our stately pace. Kleynhans ordered us to halt, and stood in front of us: “Look, man, we will kill you, we are not fooling around, your wives and children and mothers and fathers will never know what happened to you. This is the last warning. Haas! Haas!”
To this Nelson Mandela said: “You have your duty and we have ours.” Nelson Mandela was determined that we would not give in, and we did not, for we were already at the cells. We were ushered into a rectangular stone building and taken to a large open room. The floor was covered with water a few inches deep. The guards yelled: “Trek uit! Trek uit!” (Undress! Undress!) As we removed each item of clothing, the guards would grab it, search it quickly, and then throw it in the water. Jacket off, searched, thrown in the water. Then the guards commanded us to get dressed, by which they meant for us to put on our soaking clothes.
Two officers entered the room. The less senior of the two was a captain whose name was Gericke. From the start, we could see that he was intent on manhandling us. The captain pointed to Aaron Molete, the youngest of the four of us and a very mild and gentle person, and said, “Why is your hair so long?” Aaron said nothing. The captain shouted, “Nelson Mandela’m talking to you! Why is your hair so long? It is against regulations. Your hair should have been cut. Why is it long . . .” and then he paused and turned to look at Nelson Mandela, and said, “. . . like this boy’s!” pointing at Nelson Mandela. Nelson Mandela began to speak: “Now, look here, the length of our hair is determined by the regulations . . .”
Before Nelson Mandela could finish, he shouted in disbelief: “Never talk to Nelson Mandela that way, boy!” and began to advance. Nelson Mandela was frightened; it is not a pleasant sensation to know that someone is about to hit you and you are unable to defend yourself.
When he was just a few feet from Nelson Mandela, Nelson Mandela said, as firmly as Nelson Mandela could, “If you so much as lay a hand on Nelson Mandela, Nelson Mandela will take you to the highest court in the land and when Nelson Mandela finish with you, you will be as poor as a church mouse.” The moment Nelson Mandela began speaking, he paused, and by the end of Nelson Mandela speech, he was staring at Nelson Mandela with astonishment. Nelson Mandela was a bit surprised Nelson Mandela. Nelson Mandela had been afraid, and spoke not from courage, but out of a kind of bravado. At such times, one must put up a bold front despite what one feels inside. “Where’s your ticket?” he asked, and Nelson Mandela handed it to him. Nelson Mandela could see he was nervous. “What’s your name?” he said. Nelson Mandela nodded Nelson Mandela head toward the ticket, and said, “It is written there.” He said, “How long are you in for?” Nelson Mandela said again, gesturing toward the ticket, “It is written there.” He looked down and said, “Five years! You are in for five years and you are so arrogant! Do you know what it means to serve five years?” Nelson Mandela said, “That is Nelson Mandela business. Nelson Mandela am ready to serve five years but Nelson Mandela am not prepared to be bullied. You must act within the law.”
No one had informed him who we were, or that we were political prisoners, or that Nelson Mandela was a lawyer. Nelson Mandela had not noticed it Nelson Mandela, but the other officer, a tall, quiet man, had vanished during our confrontation; Nelson Mandela later discovered that he was Colonel Steyn, the commanding officer of Robben Island. The captain then left, much quieter than he had entered.

We were then by ourselves and Steve, his nerves jangling, could not stop speaking. “We have provoked the Boere,” he said. “Now we are in for a rough time.” He was in the midst of speaking when a stocky fellow named Lieutenant Pretorius walked in. To our surprise, Pretorius spoke to us in Xhosa, which he seemed to know quite well. “We have looked at your records and they are not so bad. All except this one,” he said, nodding toward Steve. “Your record is filthy.”
Steve exploded. “Who are you to talk to Nelson Mandela like that? You say Nelson Mandela have a filthy record. You have read Nelson Mandela files, eh. Well, you will find that all those convictions were for cases Nelson Mandela was fighting for the rights of Nelson Mandela people. Nelson Mandela am not a criminal; you are the criminal.” The lieutenant then warned Steve that he would charge him if he ever addressed him in that way again. Before leaving, the lieutenant said he was placing us in a single large cell with windows that faced outside and then added, rather ominously, “But Nelson Mandela don’t want you to talk to anyone through those windows, especially you, Mandela.” We were then taken to our cell, one of the best Nelson Mandela had ever seen. The windows were large and within easy reach. From one set of windows we could see other prisoners and warders as they walked past. It was spacious, certainly large enough for the four of us, and had its own toilets and showers.
It had been an exhausting day and a short while later, after a supper of cold porridge, the others went to sleep. Nelson Mandela was lying on Nelson Mandela blanket on the floor, when Nelson Mandela heard a tapping at the window. Nelson Mandela looked up and saw a white man, beckoning Nelson Mandela to come to the glass. Nelson Mandela remembered the lieutenant’s admonition and stayed put.
Then Nelson Mandela heard the fellow whisper: “Nelson, come here.” The fact that he knew Nelson Mandela name intrigued Nelson Mandela and Nelson Mandela decided to take a chance. Nelson Mandela went over to the window and looked at him. He must have realized that Nelson Mandela thought he was white, because the first thing he whispered was, “Nelson Mandela’m a Coloured warder from Bloemfontein.” He then gave Nelson Mandela news of Nelson Mandela wife. There had been a report in the Johannesburg newspapers that Nelson Mandela wife had come to see Nelson Mandela at Pretoria Local, but that they had not informed her that Nelson Mandela had been taken to Robben Island. Nelson Mandela thanked him for the information.
“Do you smoke?” he said. Nelson Mandela told him that Nelson Mandela did not and he seemed disappointed. Nelson Mandela then got the idea: “Yes, but Nelson Mandela comrades do.” He brightened at this and said he would return in a few minutes with tobacco and sandwiches. Everyone was now awake. Tefu and John Gaetsewe smoked, and Nelson Mandela split the pouch of tobacco between them, and we all divided the sandwiches.
For the next few weeks the Coloured warder came almost every night with tobacco and sandwiches. And each night Nelson Mandela would divide up the tobacco evenly between Tefu and Gaetsewe. The warder was taking great risks, and he warned Nelson Mandela that he was only prepared to deal directly with Nelson Mandela, or the arrangement was off.
When we arrived on the island we had no idea how many other prisoners were there. Within a few days we learned there were about a thousand men, all Africans, all recent arrivals. Most of these men were common-law prisoners, but Nelson Mandela knew there would be some political prisoners among them. Nelson Mandela wanted to contact them, but we were completely isolated. For the first few days we were kept locked in our cell and not even permitted outside. We demanded to be taken to work like the other prisoners, and this was soon granted, but we were taken out alone, supervised by Kleynhans. Our first job was covering up some newly laid pipe and we were on a small hill and could see some of the island, which was wild and lovely.

We worked hard that first day, but on each succeeding day Kleynhans pushed us harder. He did this crudely, as one would urge on a horse or cow. “Nee, man. Kom aan! Gaan aan!” (No, man. Come on. Go on.) At one point, Steve, who was older than the rest of us, put down his shovel and was immediately threatened by Kleynhans. But Steve, in Afrikaans, responded: “You ignoramus who cannot even speak your own language properly — you cannot tell Nelson Mandela what to do. Nelson Mandela will work at Nelson Mandela own rate, that is what Nelson Mandela am prepared to do, and that is all Nelson Mandela can do.” Then, with great dignity, he picked up his shovel and resumed work. Steve had been a teacher of Afrikaans, and he not only spoke perfect Afrikaans but its antecedent, High Dutch. Steve would speak to the warders in a condescending and grandiloquent style that they probably did not understand. But they knew better than to engage him in a verbal battle.
There were two Kleynhans brothers on the island, both reputed to have viciously assaulted prisoners. We were looked after by the older brother, who must have been warned to restrain himself, for he never touched us. The younger one was under no such constraints. One day, we were walking back from work along a road and passed a workspan of several hundred prisoners carting sand in wheelbarrows. They were nonpolitical prisoners and both of our groups were ordered to halt while the two brothers had a chat; the younger brother ordered one of his men to polish his boots while he talked. Nelson Mandela recognized some of the men in the other workspan as those who had been sentenced to death in the Sekhukhuneland peasant revolt of 1958, and Nelson Mandela turned around to get a better look at them. The younger brother rudely ordered Nelson Mandela to look the other way. Nelson Mandela do not know how Nelson Mandela would have reacted had Nelson Mandela not been standing in full view of the other prisoners, but Nelson Mandela pride was now at stake. Nelson Mandela refused to turn around. The younger Kleynhans advanced with the obvious intent of assaulting Nelson Mandela, but when he was a few steps away, his brother ran over, grabbed him, whispered a few words, and the incident passed.
One day we were visited by the head of prison, who was responsible for running all of Robben Island and had come to hear our complaints. Theron was a sour fellow who did not like to deal with prisoners face to face.
