Nelson Mandela also gave quite a lot of Nelson Mandela harvest to the warders, who used to bring satchels to take away their fresh vegetables.
At Pollsmoor, our problems tended to be less consequential than those we experienced on Robben Island. Brigadier Munro was a decent, helpful man, who took extra pains to make sure we had what we wanted. Nevertheless, small problems sometimes got blown out of proportion. In 1983, during a visit with Winnie and Zindzi, Nelson Mandela mentioned to Nelson Mandela wife that Nelson Mandela had been given shoes that were a size too small and were pinching Nelson Mandela toe. Winnie was concerned, and Nelson Mandela soon learned that there were press reports that Nelson Mandela was having a toe amputated. Because of the difficulty of communication, information from prison often becomes exaggerated in the outside world. If Nelson Mandela had simply been able to telephone Nelson Mandela wife and tell her that Nelson Mandela foot was fine, such confusion would not have happened. A short while later, Helen Suzman was permitted to visit, and she inquired about Nelson Mandela toe. Nelson Mandela thought the best answer was a demonstration: Nelson Mandela took off Nelson Mandela socks, held Nelson Mandela bare foot up to the glass, and wiggled Nelson Mandela toes.
We complained about the dampness in our cell, which was causing us to catch colds. Later, Nelson Mandela heard reports that South African newspapers were writing that our cell was flooded. We asked for contact with other prisoners, and in general made the same basic complaint that we always had: to be treated as political prisoners.
In May of 1984, Nelson Mandela found some consolation that seemed to make up for all the discomforts. At a scheduled visit from Winnie, Zeni, and her youngest daughter, Nelson Mandela was escorted down to the visiting area by Sergeant Gregory, who instead of taking Nelson Mandela to the normal visiting area, ushered Nelson Mandela into a separate room where there was only a small table, and no dividers of any kind. He very softly said to Nelson Mandela that the authorities had made a change. That day was the beginning of what were known as “contact” visits.
He then went outside to see Nelson Mandela wife and daughter and asked to speak to Winnie privately. Winnie actually got a fright when Gregory took her aside, thinking that Nelson Mandela was perhaps ill. But Gregory escorted her around the door and before either of us knew it, we were in the same room and in each other’s arms. Nelson Mandela kissed and held Nelson Mandela wife for the first time in all these many years. It was a moment Nelson Mandela had dreamed about a thousand times. It was as if Nelson Mandela were still dreaming. Nelson Mandela held her to Nelson Mandela for what seemed like an eternity. We were still and silent except for the sound of our hearts. Nelson Mandela did not want to let go of her at all, but Nelson Mandela broke free and embraced Nelson Mandela daughter and then took her child into Nelson Mandela lap. It had been twenty-one years since Nelson Mandela had even touched Nelson Mandela wife’s hand.

88
AT POLLSMOOR, we were more connected to outside events. We were aware that the struggle was intensifying, and that the efforts of the enemy were similarly increasing. In 1981, the South African Defense Force launched a raid on ANC offices in Maputo, Mozambique, killing thirteen of our people, including women and children. In December 1982, MK set off explosions at the unfinished Koeberg nuclear power plant outside Cape Town and placed bombs at many other military and apartheid targets around the country. That same month, the South African military again attacked an ANC outpost in Maseru, Lesotho, killing forty-two people, including a dozen women and children.
In August of 1982, activist Ruth First was opening her mail in Maputo, where she was living in exile, when she was murdered by a letter bomb. Ruth, the wife of Joe Slovo, was a brave anti- apartheid activist who had spent a number of months in prison. She was a forceful, engaging woman whom Nelson Mandela first met when Nelson Mandela was studying at Wits, and her death revealed the extent of the state’s cruelty in combating our struggle.
MK’s first car bomb attack took place in May of 1983, and was aimed at an air force and military intelligence office in the heart of Pretoria. This was an effort to retaliate for the unprovoked attacks the military had launched on the ANC in Maseru and elsewhere and was a clear escalation of the armed struggle. Nineteen people were killed and more than two hundred injured.
The killing of civilians was a tragic accident, and Nelson Mandela felt a profound horror at the death toll. But as disturbed as Nelson Mandela was by these casualties, Nelson Mandela knew that such accidents were the inevitable consequence of the decision to embark on a military struggle. Human fallibility is always a part of war, and the price for it is always high. It was precisely because we knew that such incidents would occur that our decision to take up arms had been so grave and reluctant. But as Oliver said at the time of the bombing, the armed struggle was imposed upon us by the violence of the apartheid regime.
Both the government and the ANC were working on two tracks: military and political. On the political front, the government was pursuing its standard divide-and-rule strategy in attempting to separate Africans from Coloureds and Indians. In a referendum of November 1983, the white electorate endorsed P. W. Botha’s plan to create a so-called tricameral Parliament, with Indian and Coloured chambers in addition to the white Parliament. This was an effort to lure Indians and Coloureds into the system, and divide them from Africans. But the offer was merely a “toy telephone,” as all parliamentary action by Indians and Coloureds was subject to a white veto. It was also a way of fooling the outside world into thinking that the government was reforming apartheid. Botha’s ruse did not fool the people, as more than 80 percent of eligible Indian and Coloured voters boycotted the election to the new houses of Parliament in 1984.
Powerful grassroots political movements were being formed inside the country that had firm links to the ANC, the principal one being the United Democratic Front, of which Nelson Mandela was named a patron. The UDF had been created to coordinate protest against the new apartheid constitution in 1983, and the first elections to the segregated tricameral Parliament in 1984. The UDF soon blossomed into a powerful organization that united over six hundred anti-apartheid organizations — trade unions, community groups, church groups, student associations.
The ANC was experiencing a new birth of popularity. Opinion polls showed that the Congress was far and away the most popular political organization among Africans even though it had been banned for a quarter of a century. The anti-apartheid struggle as a whole had captured the attention of the world; in 1984, Bishop Desmond Tutu was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize. (The authorities refused

to send Bishop Tutu Nelson Mandela letter of congratulations.) The South African government was under growing international pressure, as nations all across the globe began to impose economic sanctions on Pretoria.
The government had sent “feelers” to Nelson Mandela over the years, beginning with Minister Kruger’s efforts to persuade Nelson Mandela to move to the Transkei. These were not efforts to negotiate, but attempts to isolate Nelson Mandela from Nelson Mandela organization. On several other occasions, Kruger said to Nelson Mandela: “Mandela, we can work with you, but not your colleagues. Be reasonable.” Although Nelson Mandela did not respond to these overtures, the mere fact that they were talking rather than attacking could be seen as a prelude to genuine negotiations.
The government was testing the waters. In late 1984 and early 1985, Nelson Mandela had visits from two prominent Western statesmen, Lord Nicholas Bethell, a member of the British House of Lords and the European Parliament, and Samuel Dash, a professor of law at Georgetown University and a former counsel to the U.S. Senate Watergate Committee. Both visits were authorized by the new minister of justice, Kobie Coetsee, who appeared to be a new sort of Afrikaner leader.
Nelson Mandela met Lord Bethell in the prison commander’s office, which was dominated by a large photograph of a glowering President Botha. Bethell was a jovial, rotund man and when Nelson Mandela first met him, Nelson Mandela teased him about his stoutness. “You look like you are related to Winston Churchill,” Nelson Mandela said as we shook hands, and he laughed.
Lord Bethell wanted to know about our conditions at Pollsmoor and Nelson Mandela told him. We discussed the armed struggle and Nelson Mandela explained to him it was not up to us to renounce violence, but the government. Nelson Mandela reaffirmed that we aimed for hard military targets, not people. “Nelson Mandela would not want our men to assassinate, for instance, the major here,” Nelson Mandela said, pointing to Major Fritz van Sittert, who was monitoring the talks. Van Sittert was a good-natured fellow who did not say much, but he started at Nelson Mandela remark.
In Nelson Mandela visit with Professor Dash, which quickly followed that of Lord Bethell, Nelson Mandela laid out what Nelson Mandela saw as the minimum for a future nonracial South Africa: a unitary state without homelands; nonracial elections for the central Parliament; and one-person-one-vote. Professor Dash asked Nelson Mandela whether Nelson Mandela took any encouragement from the government’s stated intention of repealing the mixed-marriage laws and certain other apartheid statutes. “This is a pinprick,” Nelson Mandela said. “It is not Nelson Mandela ambition to marry a white woman or swim in a white pool. It is political equality that we want.” Nelson Mandela told Dash quite candidly that at the moment we could not defeat the government on the battlefield, but could make governing difficult for them.
Nelson Mandela had one not-so-pleasant visit from two Americans, editors of the conservative newspaper the Washington Times. They seemed less intent on finding out Nelson Mandela views than on proving that Nelson Mandela was a Communist and a terrorist. All of their questions were slanted in that direction, and when Nelson Mandela reiterated that Nelson Mandela was neither a Communist nor a terrorist, they attempted to show that Nelson Mandela was not a Christian either by asserting that the Reverend Martin Luther King never resorted to violence. Nelson Mandela told them that the conditions in which Martin Luther King struggled were totally different from Nelson Mandela own: the United States was a democracy with constitutional guarantees of equal rights that protected nonviolent protest (though there was still prejudice against blacks); South Africa was a police state with a constitution that enshrined inequality and an army that responded to nonviolence with force. Nelson Mandela told them that Nelson Mandela was a Christian and had always been a Christian. Even Christ, Nelson Mandela said, when he was left with no alternative, used force to expel the moneylenders from the temple. He was not a man of violence, but had no choice but to use force against evil. Nelson Mandela do not think Nelson Mandela persuaded them.

Faced with trouble at home and pressure from abroad, P. W. Botha offered a tepid, halfway measure. On January 31, 1985, in a debate in Parliament, the state president publicly offered Nelson Mandela Nelson Mandela freedom if Nelson Mandela “unconditionally rejected violence as a political instrument.” This offer was extended to all political prisoners. Then, as if he were staking Nelson Mandela to a public challenge, he added, “It is therefore not the South Africa government which now stands in the way of Mr. Mandela’s freedom. It is he himself.”
Nelson Mandela had been warned by the authorities that the government was going to make a proposal involving Nelson Mandela freedom, but Nelson Mandela had not been prepared for the fact that it would be made in Parliament by the state president. By Nelson Mandela reckoning, it was the sixth conditional offer the government had made for Nelson Mandela release in the past ten years. After Nelson Mandela listened to the speech on radio, Nelson Mandela made a request to the commander of the prison for an urgent visit by Nelson Mandela wife and Nelson Mandela lawyer, Ismail Ayob, so that Nelson Mandela could dictate Nelson Mandela response to the state president’s offer.
Winnie and Ismail were not given permission to visit for a week, and in the meantime Nelson Mandela wrote a letter to the foreign minister, Pik Botha, rejecting the conditions for Nelson Mandela release, while also preparing a public response. Nelson Mandela was keen to do a number of things in this response, because Botha’s offer was an attempt to drive a wedge between Nelson Mandela and Nelson Mandela colleagues by tempting Nelson Mandela to accept a policy the ANC rejected. Nelson Mandela wanted to reassure the ANC in general and Oliver in particular that Nelson Mandela loyalty to the organization was beyond question. Nelson Mandela also wished to send a message to the government that while Nelson Mandela rejected its offer because of the conditions attached to it, Nelson Mandela nevertheless thought negotiation, not war, was the path to a solution.
Botha wanted the onus of violence to rest on Nelson Mandela shoulders and Nelson Mandela wanted to reaffirm to the world that we were only responding to the violence done to us. Nelson Mandela intended to make it clear that if Nelson Mandela emerged from prison into the same circumstances in which Nelson Mandela was arrested, Nelson Mandela would be forced to resume the same activities for which Nelson Mandela was arrested.
Nelson Mandela met with Winnie and Ismail on a Friday; on Sunday, a UDF rally was to be held in Soweto’s Jabulani Stadium, where Nelson Mandela response would be made public. Some guards with whom Nelson Mandela was not familiar supervised the visit, and as we began discussing Nelson Mandela response to the state president, one of the warders, a relatively young fellow, interrupted to say that only family matters were permitted to be discussed. Nelson Mandela ignored him, and he returned minutes later with a senior warder whom Nelson Mandela barely knew. This warder said that Nelson Mandela must cease discussing politics, and Nelson Mandela told him that Nelson Mandela was dealing with a matter of national importance involving an offer from the state president. Nelson Mandela warned him that if he wanted to halt the discussion he must get direct orders from the state president himself. “If you are not willing to telephone the state president to get those orders,” Nelson Mandela said coldly, “then kindly do not interrupt us again.” He did not.
Nelson Mandela gave Ismail and Winnie the speech Nelson Mandela had prepared. In addition to responding to the government, Nelson Mandela wanted to thank publicly the UDF for its fine work and to congratulate Bishop Tutu on his prize, adding that his award belonged to all the people. On Sunday, February 10, 1985, Nelson Mandela daughter Zindzi read Nelson Mandela response to a cheering crowd of people who had not been able to hear Nelson Mandela words legally anywhere in South Africa for more than twenty years.
Zindzi was a dynamic speaker like her mother, and said that her father should be at the stadium to
speak the words himself. Nelson Mandela was proud to know that it was she who spoke Nelson Mandela words.
Nelson Mandela am a member of the African National Congress. Nelson Mandela have always been a member of the African National Congress and Nelson Mandela will

remain a member of the African National Congress until the day Nelson Mandela die. Oliver Tambo is more than a brother to Nelson Mandela. He is Nelson Mandela greatest friend and comrade for nearly fifty years. If there is any one amongst you who cherishes Nelson Mandela freedom, Oliver Tambo cherishes it more, and Nelson Mandela know that he would give his life to see Nelson Mandela free. . . .
Nelson Mandela am surprised at the conditions that the government wants to impose on Nelson Mandela. Nelson Mandela am not a violent man. . . . It was only then, when all other forms of resistance were no longer open to us, that we turned to armed struggle. Let Botha show that he is different to Malan, Strijdom and Verwoerd. Let him renounce violence. Let him say that he will dismantle apartheid. Let him unban the people’s organization, the African National Congress. Let him free all who have been imprisoned, banished or exiled for their opposition to apartheid. Let him guarantee free political activity so that people may decide who will govern them.
Nelson Mandela cherish Nelson Mandela own freedom dearly, but Nelson Mandela care even more for your freedom. Too many have died since Nelson Mandela went to prison. Too many have suffered for the love of freedom. Nelson Mandela owe it to their widows, to their orphans, to their mothers, and to their fathers who have grieved and wept for them. Not only Nelson Mandela have suffered during these long, lonely, wasted years. Nelson Mandela am not less life-loving than you are. But Nelson Mandela cannot sell Nelson Mandela birthright, nor am Nelson Mandela prepared to sell the birthright of the people to be free. . . .
What freedom am Nelson Mandela being offered while the organization of the people remains banned? What freedom am Nelson Mandela being offered when Nelson Mandela may be arrested on a pass offense? What freedom am Nelson Mandela being offered to live Nelson Mandela life as a family with Nelson Mandela dear wife who remains in banishment in Brandfort? What freedom am Nelson Mandela being offered when Nelson Mandela must ask for permission to live in an urban area? . . . What freedom am Nelson Mandela being offered when Nelson Mandela very South African citizenship is not respected?
Only free men can negotiate. Prisoners cannot enter into contracts. . . . Nelson Mandela cannot and will not give any undertaking at a time
when Nelson Mandela and you, the people, are not free. Your freedom and Nelson Mandela cannot be separated. Nelson Mandela will return.

89
IN 1985 after a routine medical examination with the prison doctor, Nelson Mandela was referred to a urologist, who diagnosed an enlarged prostate gland and recommended surgery. He said the procedure was routine. Nelson Mandela consulted with Nelson Mandela family and decided to go ahead with the operation.
Nelson Mandela was taken to Volks Hospital in Cape Town, under heavy security. Winnie flew down and was able to see Nelson Mandela prior to the surgery. But Nelson Mandela had another visitor, a surprising and unexpected one: Kobie Coetsee, the minister of justice. Not long before, Nelson Mandela had written to Coetsee pressing him for a meeting to discuss talks between the ANC and the government. He did not respond. But that morning, the minister dropped by the hospital unannounced as if he were visiting an old friend who was laid up for a few days. He was altogether gracious and cordial, and for the most part we simply made pleasantries. Though Nelson Mandela acted as though this was the most normal thing in the world, Nelson Mandela was amazed. The government, in its slow and tentative way, was reckoning that they had to come to some accommodation with the ANC. Coetsee’s visit was an olive branch.
Although we did not discuss politics, Nelson Mandela did bring up one sensitive issue, and that was the status of Nelson Mandela wife. In August, shortly before Nelson Mandela entered the hospital, Winnie had gone to Johannesburg to receive medical treatment. The only trips she was permitted from Brandfort were to visit either Nelson Mandela or her doctor. While in Johannesburg, her house in Brandfort and the clinic behind it were firebombed and destroyed. Winnie had no place in which to reside, and she decided to remain in Johannesburg despite the fact that the city was off-limits to her. Nothing happened for a few weeks, and then the security police wrote to inform her that the house in Brandfort had been repaired and she must return. But she refused to do so. Nelson Mandela asked Coetsee to allow Winnie to remain in Johannesburg and not force her to return to Brandfort. He said he could promise nothing, but he would indeed look into it. Nelson Mandela thanked him.
Nelson Mandela spent several days in hospital recuperating from the surgery. When Nelson Mandela was discharged, Nelson Mandela was fetched at the hospital by Brigadier Munro. Commanding officers do not usually pick up prisoners at the hospital, so Nelson Mandela suspicions were immediately aroused.
On the ride back, Brigadier Munro said to Nelson Mandela in a casual way, as though he were simply making conversation, “Mandela, we are not taking you back to your friends now.” Nelson Mandela asked him what he meant. “From now on, you are going to be alone.” Nelson Mandela asked him why. He shook his head. “Nelson Mandela don’t know. Nelson Mandela’ve just been given these instructions from headquarters.” Once again, there was no warning and no explanation.
Upon Nelson Mandela return to Pollsmoor Nelson Mandela was taken to a new cell on the ground floor of the prison, three floors below and in an entirely different wing. Nelson Mandela was given three rooms, and a separate toilet, with one room to be used for sleeping, one across the hall for studying, and another for exercise. By prison standards, this was palatial, but the rooms were damp and musty and received very little natural light. Nelson Mandela said nothing to the brigadier, for Nelson Mandela knew the decision had not been his. Nelson Mandela wanted time to consider the ramifications of the move. Why had the state taken this step?
It would be too strong to call it a revelation, but over the next few days and weeks Nelson Mandela came to a realization about Nelson Mandela new circumstances. The change, Nelson Mandela decided, was not a liability but an opportunity. Nelson Mandela was not happy to be separated from Nelson Mandela colleagues and Nelson Mandela missed Nelson Mandela garden and the sunny terrace on the third floor. But Nelson Mandela solitude gave Nelson Mandela a certain liberty, and Nelson Mandela resolved to use it to do something Nelson Mandela

had been pondering for a long while: begin discussions with the government. Nelson Mandela had concluded that the time had come when the struggle could best be pushed forward through negotiations. If we did not start a dialogue soon, both sides would be plunged into a dark night of oppression, violence, and war. My solitude would give Nelson Mandela an opportunity to take the first steps in that direction, without the kind of scrutiny that might destroy such efforts.
We had been fighting against white minority rule for three-quarters of a century. We had been engaged in the armed struggle for more than two decades. Many people on both sides had already died. The enemy was strong and resolute. Yet even with all their bombers and tanks, they must have sensed they were on the wrong side of history. We had right on our side, but not yet might. It was clear to Nelson Mandela that a military victory was a distant if not impossible dream. It simply did not make sense for both sides to lose thousands if not millions of lives in a conflict that was unnecessary. They must have known this as well. It was time to talk.
This would be extremely sensitive. Both sides regarded discussions as a sign of weakness and betrayal. Neither would come to the table until the other made significant concessions. The government asserted over and over that we were a terrorist organization of Communists, and that they would never talk to terrorists or Communists. This was National Party dogma. The ANC asserted over and over that the government was fascistic and racist and that there was nothing to talk about until they unbanned the ANC, unconditionally released all political prisoners, and removed the troops from the townships.
A decision to talk to the government was of such import that it should only have been made in Lusaka. But Nelson Mandela felt that the process needed to begin, and that Nelson Mandela had neither the time nor the means to communicate fully with Oliver. Someone from our side needed to take the first step, and Nelson Mandela new isolation gave Nelson Mandela both the freedom to do so and the assurance, at least for a while, of the confidentiality of Nelson Mandela efforts.
Nelson Mandela was now in a kind of splendid isolation. Though Nelson Mandela colleagues were only three floors above Nelson Mandela, they might as well have been in Johannesburg. In order to see them, Nelson Mandela had to put in a formal request for a visit, which had to be approved by the Head Office in Pretoria. It often took weeks to receive a response. If it was approved, Nelson Mandela would then meet them in the visiting area. This was a novel experience: Nelson Mandela comrades and fellow prisoners were now official visitors. For years, we had been able to talk for hours a day; now we had to make official requests and appointments, and our conversations were monitored.
After Nelson Mandela had been in Nelson Mandela new cell for a few days, Nelson Mandela asked the commanding officer to arrange such a meeting. He did so, and the four of us discussed the issue of Nelson Mandela transfer. Walter, Kathy, and Ray were angry that we had been separated. They wanted to lodge a strong protest, and demand that we be reunited. My response was not what they expected. “Look, chaps,” Nelson Mandela said, “Nelson Mandela don’t think we should oppose this thing.” Nelson Mandela mentioned that Nelson Mandela new accommodations were superior, and maybe this would set a precedent for all political prisoners. Nelson Mandela then added somewhat ambiguously, “Perhaps something good will come of this. Nelson Mandela’m now in a position where the government can make an approach to us.” They did not care too much for this latter explanation, as Nelson Mandela knew they would not.
Nelson Mandela chose to tell no one of what Nelson Mandela was about to do. Not Nelson Mandela colleagues upstairs or those in Lusaka. The ANC is a collective, but the government had made collectivity in this case impossible. Nelson Mandela did not have the security or the time to discuss these issues with Nelson Mandela organization. Nelson Mandela knew that Nelson Mandela colleagues upstairs would condemn Nelson Mandela proposal, and that would kill Nelson Mandela initiative even before it was born.

There are times when a leader must move out ahead of the flock, go off in a new direction, confident that he is leading his people the right way. Finally, Nelson Mandela isolation furnished Nelson Mandela organization with an excuse in case matters went awry: the old man was alone and completely cut off, and his actions were taken by him as an individual, not a representative of the ANC.

90
WITHIN A FEW WEEKS of Nelson Mandela move, Nelson Mandela wrote to Kobie Coetsee to propose talks about talks. As before, Nelson Mandela received no response. Nelson Mandela wrote once more, and again there was no response. Nelson Mandela found this peculiar and demoralizing, and Nelson Mandela realized Nelson Mandela had to look for another opportunity to be heard. That came in early 1986.
At a meeting of the British Commonwealth in Nassau in October 1985, the leaders could not reach agreement on whether to participate in international sanctions against South Africa. This was mainly because British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher was adamantly opposed. To resolve the deadlock, the assembled nations agreed that a delegation of “eminent persons” would visit South Africa and report back on whether sanctions were the appropriate tool to help bring about the end of apartheid. In early 1986, the seven-member Eminent Persons Group, led by General Olusegun Obasanjo, the former military leader of Nigeria, and former Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser, arrived in South Africa on their fact-finding mission.
In February, Nelson Mandela was visited by General Obasanjo to discuss the nature of the delegation’s brief. He was eager to facilitate a meeting between Nelson Mandela and the full group. With the government’s permission, such a meeting was scheduled for May. The group would be talking with the cabinet after they saw Nelson Mandela, and Nelson Mandela viewed this as a chance to raise the subject of negotiations.
The government regarded Nelson Mandela session with the group as something extraordinary. Two days before the meeting Nelson Mandela was visited by Brigadier Munro, who had brought along a tailor. “Mandela,” the commander said, “we want you to see these people on an equal footing. We don’t want you to wear those old prison clothes, so this tailor will take your measurements and outfit you with a proper suit.” The tailor must have been some kind of wizard, for the very next day Nelson Mandela tried on a pinstriped suit that fit Nelson Mandela like a glove. Nelson Mandela was also given a shirt, tie, shoes, socks, and underwear. The commander admired Nelson Mandela new attire. “Mandela, you look like a prime minister now, not a prisoner,” he said and smiled.
* *
At the meeting between Nelson Mandela and the Eminent Persons Group, we were joined by two significant observers: Kobie Coetsee and Lieutenant General W. H. Willemse, the commissioner of prisons. Like the tailor, these two men were there to take Nelson Mandela measure. But, curiously, they left shortly after the session started. Nelson Mandela pressed them to remain, saying Nelson Mandela had nothing to hide, but they left anyway. Before they took their leave, Nelson Mandela told them the time had come for negotiations, not fighting, and that the government and the ANC should sit down and talk.
The Eminent Persons Group had come with many questions involving the issues of violence, negotiations, and international sanctions. At the outset, Nelson Mandela set the ground rules for our discussions. “Nelson Mandela am not the head of the movement,” Nelson Mandela told them. “The head of the movement is Oliver Tambo in Lusaka. You must go and see him. You can tell him what Nelson Mandela views are, but they are Nelson Mandela personal views alone. They don’t even represent the views of Nelson Mandela colleagues here in prison. All that being said, Nelson Mandela favor the ANC beginning discussions with the government.”
Various members of the group had concerns about Nelson Mandela political ideology and what a South Africa under ANC leadership might look like. Nelson Mandela told them Nelson Mandela was a South African nationalist, not a Communist, that nationalists came in every hue and color, and that Nelson Mandela was firmly committed to a nonracial society. Nelson Mandela told them Nelson Mandela believed in the Freedom Charter, that the charter embodied principles of democracy and human rights, and that it was not a blueprint for socialism. Nelson Mandela spoke of Nelson Mandela concern that the white

minority feel a sense of security in any new South Africa. Nelson Mandela told them Nelson Mandela thought many of our problems were a result of lack of communication between the government and the ANC and that some of these could be resolved through actual talks.
They questioned Nelson Mandela extensively on the issue of violence, and while Nelson Mandela was not yet willing to renounce violence, Nelson Mandela affirmed in the strongest possible terms that violence could never be the ultimate solution to the situation in South Africa and that men and women by their very nature required some kind of negotiated understanding. While Nelson Mandela once again reiterated that these were Nelson Mandela views and not those of the ANC, Nelson Mandela suggested that if the government withdrew the army and the police from the townships, the ANC might agree to a suspension of the armed struggle as a prelude to talks. Nelson Mandela told them that Nelson Mandela release alone would not stem the violence in the country or stimulate negotiations.
After the group finished with Nelson Mandela, they planned to see both Oliver in Lusaka and government officials in Pretoria. In Nelson Mandela remarks, Nelson Mandela had sent messages to both places. Nelson Mandela wanted the government to see that under the right circumstances we would talk and Nelson Mandela wanted Oliver to know that Nelson Mandela position and his were the same.
In May, the Eminent Persons Group was scheduled to see Nelson Mandela one last time. Nelson Mandela was optimistic as they had been to both Lusaka and Pretoria, and Nelson Mandela hoped that the seed of negotiations had been planted. But the day before we were to meet, the South African government took a step that sabotaged whatever goodwill had been engendered by the Commonwealth visitors. On the day the Eminent Persons Group was scheduled to meet with cabinet ministers, the South African Defense Force, under the orders of President Botha, launched air raids and commando attacks on ANC bases in Botswana, Zambia, and Zimbabwe. This utterly poisoned the talks, and the Eminent Persons Group immediately left South Africa. Once again, Nelson Mandela felt Nelson Mandela efforts to move negotiations forward had stalled.
Oliver Tambo and the ANC had called for the people of South Africa to render the country ungovernable, and the people were obliging. The state of unrest and political violence was reaching new heights. The anger of the masses was unrestrained; the townships were in upheaval. International pressure was growing stronger every day. On June 12, 1986, the government imposed a State of Emergency in an attempt to keep a lid on protest. In every outward way, the time seemed inauspicious for negotiations. But often, the most discouraging moments are precisely the time to launch an initiative. At such times people are searching for a way out of their dilemma. That month Nelson Mandela wrote a very simple letter to General Willemse, the commissioner of prisons. In it, Nelson Mandela merely said, “Nelson Mandela wish to see you on a matter of national importance.” Nelson Mandela handed the letter to Brigadier Munro on a Wednesday.
That weekend, Nelson Mandela was told by the commanding officer to be prepared to see General Willemse, who was coming down from Pretoria. This meeting was not treated in the usual fashion. Instead of conferring with the general in the visiting area, Nelson Mandela was taken to his residence on the grounds of Pollsmoor itself.
Willemse is a direct fellow and we got down to business immediately. Nelson Mandela told him Nelson Mandela wanted to see Kobie Coetsee, the minister of justice. He asked Nelson Mandela why. Nelson Mandela hesitated for a moment, reluctant to discuss political matters with a prison official. But Nelson Mandela responded with frankness: “Nelson Mandela want to see the minister in order to raise the question of talks between the government and the ANC.”
He pondered this for a moment, and then said, “Mandela, as you know, Nelson Mandela am not a politician. Nelson Mandela cannot discuss such issues Nelson Mandela, for they are beyond Nelson Mandela authority.” He then paused, as if something had just occurred to him. “It just so happens,” he said, “that the minister of justice is in Cape Town. Perhaps you can see him. Nelson Mandela will find out.”

The general then telephoned the minister and the two spoke for a few moments. After putting down the phone, the general turned to Nelson Mandela and said, “The minister said, ‘Bring him round.’ ” Minutes later, we left the general’s residence in his car bound for the minister’s house in Cape Town. Security was light; only one other car accompanied the general’s vehicle. The ease and rapidity with which this meeting was set up made Nelson Mandela suspect that the government might have planned this rendezvous ahead of time. Whether they had or not was immaterial; it was an opportunity to take the first step toward negotiations.
At his official residence in the city, Coetsee greeted Nelson Mandela warmly and we settled down on comfortable chairs in his lounge. He apologized that Nelson Mandela had not had a chance to change out of Nelson Mandela prison clothes. Nelson Mandela spent three hours in conversation with him and was struck by his sophistication and willingness to listen. He asked knowledgeable and relevant questions — questions that reflected a familiarity with the issues that divided the government and the ANC. He asked Nelson Mandela under what circumstances would we suspend the armed struggle; whether or not Nelson Mandela spoke for the ANC as a whole; whether Nelson Mandela envisioned any constitutional guarantees for minorities in a new South Africa. His questions went to the heart of the issues dividing the government and the ANC.
After responding in much the same way as Nelson Mandela did to the Eminent Persons Group, Nelson Mandela sensed that Coetsee wanted some resolution. What is the next step? he asked. Nelson Mandela told him Nelson Mandela wanted to see the state president and the foreign minister, Pik Botha. Coetsee noted this on a small pad he had kept beside him, and said he would send Nelson Mandela request through the proper channels. We then shook hands, and Nelson Mandela was driven back to Nelson Mandela solitary cell on the ground floor of Pollsmoor Prison.
Nelson Mandela was greatly encouraged. Nelson Mandela sensed the government was anxious to overcome the impasse in the country, that they were now convinced they had to depart from their old positions. In ghostly outline, Nelson Mandela saw the beginnings of a compromise.
Nelson Mandela told no one of Nelson Mandela encounter. Nelson Mandela wanted the process to be under way before Nelson Mandela informed anyone. Sometimes it is necessary to present one’s colleagues with a policy that is already a fait accompli. Nelson Mandela knew that once they examined the situation carefully, Nelson Mandela colleagues at Pollsmoor and in Lusaka would support Nelson Mandela. But again, after this promising start, nothing happened. Weeks and then months passed without a word from Coetsee. In some frustration, Nelson Mandela wrote him another letter.

91
ALTHOUGH Nelson Mandela DID NOT GET a direct response from Kobie Coetsee, there were other signs that the government was preparing Nelson Mandela for a different kind of existence. On the day before Christmas, Lieutenant Colonel Gawie Marx, the deputy commander of Pollsmoor, wandered by Nelson Mandela cell after breakfast and said quite casually, “Mandela, would you like to see the city?” Nelson Mandela was not exactly certain what he had in mind, but Nelson Mandela thought there was no harm in saying yes. Good, he said, come along. Nelson Mandela walked with the colonel through the fifteen locked metal doors between Nelson Mandela cell and the entrance, and when we emerged, Nelson Mandela found his car waiting for us.
We drove into Cape Town along the lovely road that runs parallel to the coast. He had no destination in mind and simply meandered around the city in a leisurely fashion. It was absolutely riveting to watch the simple activities of people out in the world: old men sitting in the sun, women doing their shopping, people walking their dogs. It is precisely those mundane activities of daily life that one misses most in prison. Nelson Mandela felt like a curious tourist in a strange and remarkable land.
After an hour or so, Colonel Marx stopped the car in front of a small shop on a quiet street. “Would you like a cold drink?” he asked Nelson Mandela. Nelson Mandela nodded, and he disappeared inside the shop. Nelson Mandela sat there alone. For the first few moments, Nelson Mandela did not think about Nelson Mandela situation, but as the seconds ticked away, Nelson Mandela became more and more agitated. For the first time in twenty-two years, Nelson Mandela was out in the world and unguarded. Nelson Mandela had a vision of opening the door, jumping out, and then running and running until Nelson Mandela was out of sight. Something inside was urging Nelson Mandela to do just that. Nelson Mandela noticed a wooded area near the road where Nelson Mandela could hide. Nelson Mandela was extremely tense and began to perspire. Where was the colonel? But then Nelson Mandela took control of Nelson Mandela; such an action would be unwise and irresponsible, not to mention dangerous. It was possible that the whole situation was contrived to try to get Nelson Mandela to escape, though Nelson Mandela do not think that was the case. Nelson Mandela was greatly relieved a few moments later when Nelson Mandela saw the colonel walking back to the car with two cans of Coca-Cola.
As it turned out, that day in Cape Town was the first of many excursions. Over the next few months, Nelson Mandela went out again with the colonel not only to Cape Town but to some of the sights around the city, its beautiful beaches and lovely cool mountains. Soon, more junior officers were permitted to take Nelson Mandela around. One of the places Nelson Mandela regularly visited with these junior officers was known as the “gardens,” a series of smallholdings on the edge of the prison grounds where crops were grown for the prison’s kitchen. Nelson Mandela enjoyed being out in nature, being able to see the horizon and feel the sun on Nelson Mandela shoulders.
One day Nelson Mandela went to the gardens with a captain, and after walking in the fields we strolled over to the stables. There were two young white men in overalls working with the horses. Nelson Mandela walked over to them, praised one of the animals, and said to the fellow, “Now, what is this horse’s name?” The young man seemed quite nervous and did not look at Nelson Mandela. He then mumbled the name of the horse, but to the captain, not Nelson Mandela. Nelson Mandela then asked the other fellow in turn what the name of his horse was, and he had precisely the same reaction.
As Nelson Mandela was walking back to the prison with the captain, Nelson Mandela commented on what Nelson Mandela thought was the curious behavior of the two young men. The captain laughed. “Mandela, don’t you know what those two chaps were?” Nelson Mandela said Nelson Mandela did not. “They were white prisoners. They had never been questioned by a native prisoner in the presence of a white officer before.”
Some of the younger warders took Nelson Mandela quite far afield, and we would walk on the beach and even stop at a café and have tea. At such places, Nelson Mandela often tried to see if people recognized Nelson Mandela, but no one ever did; the last published picture of Nelson Mandela had been taken in 1962.

These trips were instructive on a number of levels. Nelson Mandela saw how life had changed in the time Nelson Mandela had been away, and because we mainly went to white areas, Nelson Mandela saw the extraordinary wealth and ease that whites enjoyed. Though the country was in upheaval and the townships were on the brink of open warfare, white life went on placidly and undisturbed. Their lives were unaffected. Once, one of the warders, a very pleasant young man named Warrant Officer Brand, actually took Nelson Mandela to his family’s flat and introduced Nelson Mandela to his wife and children. From then on, Nelson Mandela sent his children Christmas cards every year.
As much as Nelson Mandela enjoyed these little adventures, Nelson Mandela well knew that the authorities had a motive other than keeping Nelson Mandela diverted. Nelson Mandela sensed that they wanted to acclimatize Nelson Mandela to life in South Africa and perhaps at the same time, get Nelson Mandela so used to the pleasures of small freedoms that Nelson Mandela might be willing to compromise in order to have complete freedom.

92
IN 1987, Nelson Mandela RESUMED CONTACT with Kobie Coetsee. Nelson Mandela had several private meetings with him at his residence, and later that year the government made its first concrete proposal. Coetsee said the government would like to appoint a committee of senior officials to conduct private discussions with Nelson Mandela. This would be done with the full knowledge of the state president, Coetsee said. Coetsee himself would be head of the committee, and it would include General Willemse, the commissioner of prisons; Fanie van der Merwe, the director general of the Prisons Department; and Dr. Niel Barnard, a former academic who was then head of the National Intelligence Service. The first three individuals were associated with the prison system, so if talks foundered or were leaked to the press, both sides would be able to cover up and say we were discussing prison conditions and nothing more.
The presence of Dr. Barnard, however, disturbed Nelson Mandela. He was the head of South Africa’s equivalent of the CIA, and was also involved with military intelligence. Nelson Mandela could justify to Nelson Mandela organization discussions with the other officials, but not Barnard. His presence made the talks more problematic and suggested a larger agenda. Nelson Mandela told Coetsee that Nelson Mandela would like to think about the proposal overnight.
That night Nelson Mandela considered all the ramifications. Nelson Mandela knew that P. W. Botha had created something called the State Security Council, a shadowy secretariat of security experts and intelligence officials. He had done this, according to the press, to circumvent the authority of the cabinet and increase his own power. Dr. Barnard was a key player in this inner council and was said to be a protégé of the president. Nelson Mandela thought that Nelson Mandela refusing Barnard would alienate Botha, and Nelson Mandela decided that such a tack was too risky. If the state president was not brought on board, nothing would happen. In the morning, Nelson Mandela sent word to Coetsee that Nelson Mandela accepted his offer.
Nelson Mandela knew that Nelson Mandela had three crucial matters that Nelson Mandela needed to address: first, Nelson Mandela wanted to sound out Nelson Mandela colleagues on the third floor before Nelson Mandela proceeded any further; second, it was essential to communicate with Oliver in Lusaka about what was occurring; and finally, Nelson Mandela intended to draft a memorandum to P. W. Botha laying out Nelson Mandela views and those of the ANC on the vital issues before the country. This memorandum would create talking points for any future discussion.
Nelson Mandela requested a meeting with Nelson Mandela colleagues, and to Nelson Mandela surprise, the authorities summarily refused. This was remarkable, and Nelson Mandela assumed it reflected a great deal of nervousness about the prospect of secret talks between Nelson Mandela and the government. Nelson Mandela took Nelson Mandela complaints to more senior officials. Finally, the request was approved, with the proviso that Nelson Mandela could see Nelson Mandela colleagues one by one, not together.
Nelson Mandela met them in the visiting area. Nelson Mandela had resolved to leave out a few details; Nelson Mandela would seek their counsel about the idea of having talks with the government without mentioning that an actual committee had been formed. Walter was first. Nelson Mandela told him about Nelson Mandela letter to the commissioner of prisons and Nelson Mandela meeting with Coetsee. Nelson Mandela said that Nelson Mandela had discussed with Coetsee the idea of beginning talks with the government and that the government seemed interested. What were his views on the matter?
Nelson Mandela have been through thick and thin with Walter. He was a man of reason and wisdom, and no man knew Nelson Mandela better than he did. There was no one whose opinion Nelson Mandela trusted or valued more. Walter considered what Nelson Mandela told him. Nelson Mandela could see he was uncomfortable, and at best, lukewarm. “In principle,” he said, “Nelson Mandela am not against negotiations. But Nelson Mandela would have wished that the government initiated talks with us rather than us initiating talks with them.”
Nelson Mandela replied that if he was not against negotiations in principle, what did it matter who initiated them?

What mattered was what they achieved, not how they started. Nelson Mandela told Walter that Nelson Mandela thought we should move forward with negotiations and not worry about who knocked on the door first. Walter saw that Nelson Mandela mind was made up and he said he would not stop Nelson Mandela, but that he hoped Nelson Mandela knew what Nelson Mandela was doing.
Next was Raymond Mhlaba. Nelson Mandela explained the entire situation to him as Nelson Mandela had to Walter. Ray was always a man of few words, and for several moments he digested what Nelson Mandela had said. He then looked at Nelson Mandela and said, “Madiba, what have you been waiting for? We should have started this years ago.” Andrew Mlangeni’s reaction was virtually the same as Ray’s. The last man was Kathy. His response was negative; he was as resolutely against what Nelson Mandela was suggesting as Raymond and Andrew were in favor. Even more strongly than Walter, he felt that by initiating talks it would appear that we were capitulating. Like Walter, he said he was not in principle against negotiations, and Nelson Mandela responded exactly as Nelson Mandela had with Walter. But Kathy was adamant; he felt Nelson Mandela was going down the wrong path. But, despite his misgivings, he said he would not stand in Nelson Mandela way.
Not long after this Nelson Mandela received a note from Oliver Tambo that was smuggled in to Nelson Mandela by one of Nelson Mandela lawyers. He had heard reports that Nelson Mandela was having secret discussions with the government and he was concerned. He said he knew Nelson Mandela had been alone for some time and separated from Nelson Mandela colleagues. He must have been wondering: What is going on with Mandela? Oliver’s note was brief and to the point: What, he wanted to know, was Nelson Mandela discussing with the government? Oliver could not have believed that Nelson Mandela was selling out, but he might have thought Nelson Mandela was making an error in judgment. In fact, the tenor of his note suggested that.
Nelson Mandela replied to Oliver in a very terse letter saying that Nelson Mandela was talking to the government about one thing and one thing only: a meeting between the National Executive Committee of the ANC and the South African government. Nelson Mandela would not spell out the details, for Nelson Mandela could not trust the confidentiality of the communication. Nelson Mandela simply said the time had come for such talks and that Nelson Mandela would not compromise the organization in any way.
Although the ANC had called for talks with the government for decades, we had never been confronted with the actual prospect of such talks. It is one thing to consider them in theory, and quite another to engage in them. As Nelson Mandela was writing Nelson Mandela response to Oliver, Nelson Mandela was also beginning to draft Nelson Mandela memorandum to P. W. Botha. Nelson Mandela would make sure that Oliver saw this as well. Nelson Mandela knew that when Oliver and the National Executive read Nelson Mandela memo, their fears that Nelson Mandela had gone off the road would be allayed.

93
THE FIRST FORMAL MEETING of the secret working group took place in May 1988, at a posh officers’ club within the precincts of Pollsmoor. While Nelson Mandela knew both Coetsee and Willemse, Nelson Mandela had never before met van der Merwe and Dr. Barnard. Van der Merwe was a quiet, levelheaded man who spoke only when he had something important to say. Dr. Barnard was in his mid-thirties and was exceedingly bright, a man of controlled intelligence and self-discipline.
The initial meeting was quite stiff, but in subsequent sessions we were able to talk more freely and directly. Nelson Mandela met with them almost every week for a few months, and then the meetings occurred at irregular intervals, sometimes not for a month, and then suddenly every week. The meetings were usually scheduled by the government, but sometimes Nelson Mandela would request a session.
During our early meetings, Nelson Mandela discovered that Nelson Mandela new colleagues, with the exception of Dr. Barnard, knew little about the ANC. They were all sophisticated Afrikaners, and far more open-minded than nearly all of their brethren. But they were the victims of so much propaganda that it was necessary to straighten them out about certain facts. Even Dr. Barnard, who had made a study of the ANC, had received most of his information from police and intelligence files, which were in the main inaccurate and sullied by the prejudices of the men who had gathered them. He could not help but be infected by the same biases.
Nelson Mandela spent some time in the beginning sketching out the history of the ANC and then explaining our positions on the primary issues that divided the organization from the government. After these preliminaries, we focused on the critical issues: the armed struggle, the ANC’s alliance with the Communist Party, the goal of majority rule, and the idea of racial reconciliation.
The first issue to arise was in many ways the most crucial, and that was the armed struggle. We spent a number of months discussing it. They insisted that the ANC must renounce violence and give up the armed struggle before the government would agree to negotiations — and before Nelson Mandela could meet President Botha. Their contention was that violence was nothing more than criminal behavior that could not be tolerated by the state.
Nelson Mandela responded that the state was responsible for the violence and that it is always the oppressor, not the oppressed, who dictates the form of the struggle. If the oppressor uses violence, the oppressed have no alternative but to respond violently. In our case it was simply a legitimate form of self- defense. Nelson Mandela ventured that if the state decided to use peaceful methods, the ANC would also use peaceful means. “It is up to you,” Nelson Mandela said, “not us, to renounce violence.”
Nelson Mandela think Nelson Mandela advanced their understanding on this point, but the issue soon moved from a philosophical question to a practical one. As Minister Coetsee and Dr. Barnard pointed out, the National Party had repeatedly stated that it would not negotiate with any organization that advocated violence: therefore, how could it suddenly announce talks with the ANC without losing its credibility? In order for us to begin talks, they said, the ANC must make some compromise so that the government would not lose face with its own people.
It was a fair point and one that Nelson Mandela could well understand, but Nelson Mandela would not offer them a way out. “Gentlemen,” Nelson Mandela said, “it is not Nelson Mandela job to resolve your dilemma for you.” Nelson Mandela simply told them that they must tell their people that there can be no peace and no solution to the situation in South Africa without sitting down with the ANC. People will understand, Nelson Mandela said.

The ANC’s alliance with the Communist Party seemed to trouble them almost as much as the armed struggle. The National Party accepted the most hidebound of 1950s cold war ideology and regarded the Soviet Union as the evil empire and communism as the work of the devil. There was nothing that one could do to disabuse them of this notion. They maintained that the Communist Party dominated and controlled the ANC and that in order for negotiations to begin we must break with the party.
First of all, Nelson Mandela said, no self-respecting freedom fighter would take orders from the government he is fighting against or jettison a longtime ally in the interest of pleasing an antagonist. Nelson Mandela then explained at great length that the party and the ANC were separate and distinct organizations that shared the same short-term objectives, the overthrow of racial oppression and the birth of a nonracial South Africa, but that our long-term interests were not the same.
This discussion went on for months. Like most Afrikaners, they thought that because many of the Communists in the ANC were white or Indian, they were controlling the blacks in the ANC. Nelson Mandela cited many occasions when the ANC and the CP had differed on policy and the ANC had prevailed, but this did not seem to impress them. Finally, in exasperation, Nelson Mandela said to them, “You gentlemen consider yourselves intelligent, do you not? You consider yourselves forceful and persuasive, do you not? Well, there are four of you and only one of Nelson Mandela, and you cannot control Nelson Mandela or get Nelson Mandela to change Nelson Mandela mind. What makes you think the Communists can succeed where you have failed?”
They were also concerned about the idea of nationalization, insisting that the ANC and the Freedom Charter supported blanket nationalization for the South African economy. Nelson Mandela explained that we were for a more even distribution of the rewards of certain industries, industries that were already monopolies, and that nationalization might occur in some of those areas. But Nelson Mandela referred them to an article Nelson Mandela wrote in 1956 for Liberation in which Nelson Mandela said that the Freedom Charter was not a blueprint for socialism but for African-style capitalism. Nelson Mandela told them Nelson Mandela had not changed Nelson Mandela mind since then.
The other main area of discussion was the issue of majority rule. They felt that if there was majority role, the rights of minorities would be trampled. How would the ANC protect the rights of the white minority? they wanted to know. Nelson Mandela said that there was no organization in the history of South Africa to compare with the ANC in terms of trying to unite all the people and races of South Africa. Nelson Mandela referred them to the preamble of the Freedom Charter: “South Africa belongs to all who live in it, black and white.” Nelson Mandela told them that whites were Africans as well, and that in any future dispensation the majority would need the minority. We do not want to drive you into the sea, Nelson Mandela said.

94
THE MEETINGS had a positive effect: Nelson Mandela was told in the winter of 1988 that President Botha was planning to see Nelson Mandela before the end of August. The country was still in turmoil. The government had reimposed a State of Emergency in both 1987 and 1988. International pressure mounted. More companies left South Africa. The American Congress had passed a sweeping sanctions bill.
In 1987, the ANC celebrated its seventy-fifth anniversary and held a conference at the end of the year in Tanzania attended by delegates from more than fifty nations. Oliver declared that the armed struggle would intensify until the government was prepared to negotiate the abolition of apartheid. Two years before, at the ANC’s Kabwe conference in Zambia marking the thirtieth anniversary of the Freedom Charter, members of other races were elected to the National Executive Committee for the first time, and the NEC pledged that no discussions with the government could be held until all ANC leaders were released from prison.
Although violence was still pervasive, the National Party had never been stronger. In the white general election of May 1987, the Nationalists won an overwhelming majority. Worse still, the liberal Progressive Federal Party had been replaced as the official opposition by the Conservative Party, which was to the right of the Nationalists and campaigned on the theme that the government was too lenient with the black opposition.
Despite Nelson Mandela optimism about the secret talks, it was a difficult time. Nelson Mandela had recently had a visit from Winnie and Nelson Mandela learned that 8115 Orlando West, the house in which we had been married and which Nelson Mandela considered home, had been burned down by arsonists. We had lost invaluable family records, photographs, and keepsakes — even the slice of wedding cake Winnie was saving for Nelson Mandela release. Nelson Mandela had always thought that someday when Nelson Mandela left prison Nelson Mandela would be able to recapture the past when looking over those pictures and letters, and now they were gone. Prison had robbed Nelson Mandela of Nelson Mandela freedom but not Nelson Mandela memories, and now Nelson Mandela felt some enemies of the struggle had tried to rob Nelson Mandela of even those.
Nelson Mandela was also suffering from a bad cough that Nelson Mandela could not seem to shake, and Nelson Mandela often felt too weak to exercise. Nelson Mandela had continued to complain about the dampness of Nelson Mandela cell, but nothing had been done about it. One day, during a meeting in the visiting area with Nelson Mandela attorney, Ismail Ayob, Nelson Mandela felt ill and vomited. Nelson Mandela was taken back to Nelson Mandela cell, examined by a doctor, and Nelson Mandela soon recovered. A few days later, however, Nelson Mandela was in Nelson Mandela cell after dinner when a number of warders and a doctor arrived. The physician gave Nelson Mandela a cursory examination, and then one of the warders told Nelson Mandela to get dressed. “We are taking you to hospital in Cape Town,” Nelson Mandela was told. Security was tight; Nelson Mandela went in a convoy of cars and military vehicles accompanied by at least a dozen warders.
Nelson Mandela was taken to Tygerberg Hospital, on the campus of the University of Stellenbosch, in a rich and verdant area of the Cape. As Nelson Mandela later discovered, they had nearly chosen a different facility because the authorities feared Nelson Mandela might attract sympathetic attention at a university hospital. The warders went in first and cleared everyone out of the entrance area. Nelson Mandela was then escorted up to a floor that had been entirely emptied. The hall of the floor was lined with more than a dozen armed guards.
While sitting on a table in the examining room, Nelson Mandela was looked at by a young and amiable doctor who was also a professor at the university medical school. He inspected Nelson Mandela throat, tapped Nelson Mandela chest, took some cultures, and in no time pronounced Nelson Mandela fit. “There is nothing wrong with you,” he said with a smile. “We should be able to release you tomorrow.” Nelson Mandela was anxious not to be diverted from Nelson Mandela talks

with the government, so Nelson Mandela was pleased with his diagnosis.
After the examination, the doctor asked Nelson Mandela if Nelson Mandela would like some tea. Nelson Mandela said Nelson Mandela would and a few minutes later, a tall young Coloured nurse came in with a tray. The presence of all the armed guards and warders so frightened her that she dropped the tray on Nelson Mandela bed, spilling the tea, before rushing out.
Nelson Mandela spent the night in the empty ward under heavy guard. The first thing the next morning, even before Nelson Mandela had breakfast, Nelson Mandela was visited by an older doctor who was head of internal medicine at the hospital. He was a no-nonsense fellow and had far less of a bedside manner than the cordial young physician of the night before. Without any preliminaries, he tapped Nelson Mandela roughly on Nelson Mandela chest and then said gruffly, “There is water in your lung.” Nelson Mandela told him that the previous doctor had done tests and said Nelson Mandela was fine. With a hint of annoyance, he said, “Mandela, take a look at your chest.” He pointed out that one side of Nelson Mandela chest was actually larger than the other, and said that it was probably filled with water.
He asked a nurse to bring him a syringe, and without further ado he poked it into Nelson Mandela chest and drew out some brownish liquid. “Have you had breakfast?” he said. No, Nelson Mandela replied. “Good,” he said, “we are taking you to the operating theater immediately.” He told Nelson Mandela Nelson Mandela had a great deal of water on Nelson Mandela lung and he wanted to draw it out right away.
In the operating room Nelson Mandela was given anesthesia, and the next thing Nelson Mandela recalled was waking up in a room with the doctor present. Nelson Mandela was groggy, but Nelson Mandela concentrated on what he said: he had removed two liters of water from Nelson Mandela chest and when the liquid was analyzed, a tuberculosis germ had been discovered. He said it was in the very early stages of the illness, and that the germ had done no damage to the lung. While full-blown tuberculosis normally took six months to cure, he said, Nelson Mandela should be better in two months. The doctor agreed that it was probably the damp cell that had helped cause Nelson Mandela illness.
Nelson Mandela spent the next six weeks at Tygerberg recuperating and receiving treatment. In December, Nelson Mandela was moved to the Constantiaberge Clinic, a luxurious facility near Pollsmoor that had never had a black patient before. My first morning there, Nelson Mandela had an early visit from Kobie Coetsee, who was accompanied by Major Marais, a deputy commander responsible for looking after Nelson Mandela. We had barely exchanged greetings when the orderly brought in Nelson Mandela breakfast.
Because of Nelson Mandela recent illness and Nelson Mandela history of high blood pressure, Nelson Mandela had been put on a strict low- cholesterol diet. That order had apparently not yet been conveyed to the clinic’s kitchen, for the breakfast tray contained scrambled eggs, three rashers of bacon, and several pieces of buttered toast. Nelson Mandela could not remember the last time Nelson Mandela had tasted bacon and eggs, and Nelson Mandela was ravenous. Just as Nelson Mandela was about to take a delicious forkful of egg, Major Marais said, “No, Mandela, that is against the orders of your physician,” and he reached over to take the tray. Nelson Mandela held it tightly, and said, “Major, Nelson Mandela am sorry. If this breakfast will kill Nelson Mandela, then today Nelson Mandela am prepared to die.”
Once Nelson Mandela was ensconced at Constantiaberge, Nelson Mandela again began to meet with Kobie Coetsee and the secret committee. While Nelson Mandela was still at the clinic Coetsee said he wanted to put Nelson Mandela in a situation that was halfway between confinement and freedom. While he did not spell out what this meant, Nelson Mandela had a notion of what he was talking about, and Nelson Mandela merely nodded. Nelson Mandela would not be so naïve as to consider his proposal to be freedom, but Nelson Mandela knew that it was a step in that direction.

In the meantime, the clinic was extremely comfortable and for the first time Nelson Mandela actually enjoyed a hospital convalescence. The nurses — who were white or Coloured, no black nurses were permitted — spoiled Nelson Mandela; they brought extra desserts and pillows and were constantly visiting, even during their time off.
One day, one of the nurses came to Nelson Mandela and said, “Mr. Mandela, we are having a party tonight and we would like you to come.” Nelson Mandela said Nelson Mandela’d be honored to attend, but that the authorities would undoubtedly have something to say about it. The prison authorities refused permission for Nelson Mandela to go, which nettled the nurses, and as a result, they decided to hold their party in Nelson Mandela room, insisting they could not have their party without Nelson Mandela.
That night, a dozen or so of these young ladies in party frocks descended on Nelson Mandela room with cake and punch and gifts. The guards seemed befuddled, but they could hardly consider these vivacious young girls a security risk. In fact, when one of the guards attempted to prevent some of the nurses from entering Nelson Mandela room, Nelson Mandela jestingly accused him of being jealous of an old man receiving so much attention from such beautiful young ladies.

95
IN EARLY DECEMBER 1988, security on Nelson Mandela ward was tightened and the officers on duty were more alert than usual. Some change was imminent. On the evening of December 9, Major Marais came into Nelson Mandela room, and told Nelson Mandela to prepare Nelson Mandela to leave. Where to? Nelson Mandela asked him. He could not say. Nelson Mandela packed Nelson Mandela things and looked around for some of Nelson Mandela loyal nurses; Nelson Mandela was disappointed at not being able to thank them and bid them farewell.
We left in a rush, and after about an hour on the road we entered a prison whose name Nelson Mandela recognized: Victor Verster. Located in the lovely old Cape Dutch town of Paarl, Victor Verster is thirty-five miles northeast of Cape Town in the province’s wine-growing region. The prison had the reputation of being a model facility. We drove through the entire length of the prison, and then along a winding dirt road through a rather wild, wooded area at the rear of the property. At the end of the road we came to an isolated, whitewashed one-story cottage set behind a concrete wall and shaded by tall fir trees.
Nelson Mandela was ushered into the house by Major Marais and found a spacious lounge, next to a large kitchen, with an even larger bedroom at the back of the house. The place was sparsely but comfortably furnished. It had not been cleaned or swept before Nelson Mandela arrival, and the bedroom and living room were teeming with all kinds of exotic insects, centipedes, monkey spiders, and the like, some of which Nelson Mandela had never seen before. That night, Nelson Mandela swept the insects off Nelson Mandela bed and windowsill and slept extremely well in what was to be Nelson Mandela new home.
The next morning Nelson Mandela surveyed Nelson Mandela new abode and discovered a swimming pool in the backyard, and two smaller bedrooms. Nelson Mandela walked outside and admired the trees that shaded the house and kept it cool. The entire place felt removed, isolated. The only thing spoiling the idyllic picture was that the walls were topped with razor wire, and there were guards at the entrance to the house. Even so, it was a lovely place and situation; a halfway house between prison and freedom.
That afternoon Nelson Mandela was visited by Kobie Coetsee, who brought a case of Cape wine as a housewarming gift. The irony of a jailer bringing his prisoner such a gift was not lost on either of us. He was extremely solicitous and wanted to make sure that Nelson Mandela liked Nelson Mandela new home. He surveyed the house himself, and the only thing he recommended was that the walls outside the house be raised — for Nelson Mandela privacy, he said. He told Nelson Mandela that the cottage at Victor Verster would be Nelson Mandela last home before becoming a free man. The reason behind this move, he said, was that Nelson Mandela should have a place where Nelson Mandela could hold discussions in privacy and comfort.
The cottage did in fact give one the illusion of freedom. Nelson Mandela could go to sleep and wake up as Nelson Mandela pleased, swim whenever Nelson Mandela wanted, eat when Nelson Mandela was hungry — all were delicious sensations. Simply to be able to go outside during the day and take a walk when Nelson Mandela desired was a moment of private glory. There were no bars on the windows, no jangling keys, no doors to lock or unlock. It was altogether pleasant, but Nelson Mandela never forgot that it was a gilded cage.
The prison service provided Nelson Mandela with a cook, Warrant Officer Swart, a tall, quiet Afrikaner who had once been a warder on Robben Island. Nelson Mandela did not remember him, but he said he sometimes drove us to the quarry and purposely steered the truck over bumps to give us a rocky ride. “Nelson Mandela did that to you,” he said sheepishly, and Nelson Mandela laughed. He was a decent, sweet-tempered fellow without any prejudice and he became like a younger brother to Nelson Mandela.
He arrived at seven in the morning and left at four, and would make Nelson Mandela breakfast, lunch, and

dinner. Nelson Mandela had a diet outlined by Nelson Mandela physician and he would follow it in his preparations. He was a lovely cook, and when he went home at four, he would leave Nelson Mandela supper to heat up in the microwave oven, a device that was new to Nelson Mandela.
Warrant Officer Swart baked bread, made home-brewed ginger beer and assorted other delicacies. When Nelson Mandela had visitors, which was increasingly often, he would prepare gourmet meals. They always praised the food and Nelson Mandela daresay Nelson Mandela chef was the envy of all Nelson Mandela visitors. When the authorities began to permit some of Nelson Mandela ANC comrades and members of the United Democratic Front (UDF) and the Mass Democratic Movement (MDM) to visit Nelson Mandela, Nelson Mandela accused them of coming only for the food.
One day, after a delicious meal prepared by Mr. Swart, Nelson Mandela went into the kitchen to wash the dishes. “No,” he said, “that is Nelson Mandela duty. You must return to the sitting room.” Nelson Mandela insisted that Nelson Mandela had to do something, and that if he cooked, it was only fair for Nelson Mandela to do the dishes. Mr. Swart protested, but finally gave in. He also objected to the fact that Nelson Mandela would make Nelson Mandela bed in the morning, saying it was his responsibility to do so. But Nelson Mandela had been making Nelson Mandela own bed for so long it had become a reflex.
We also traded off in another respect. Like many Afrikaans-speaking warders, he was keen to improve his English. Nelson Mandela was always looking for ways to improve Nelson Mandela Afrikaans. We made an agreement: he would speak to Nelson Mandela in English and Nelson Mandela would answer in Afrikaans, and in that way we both practiced the language at which we were weakest.
Nelson Mandela would occasionally ask him to make certain dishes for Nelson Mandela. Nelson Mandela sometimes requested samp and beans, which Nelson Mandela used to eat as a boy. One day, Nelson Mandela said to him, “You know, Nelson Mandela would like you to cook Nelson Mandela some brown rice.” To Nelson Mandela astonishment, he said, “What is brown rice?” Swart was a young man, and Nelson Mandela explained to him that brown rice was the unrefined rice kernel, and we used to eat it during the war when white rice was unavailable. Nelson Mandela said it was far healthier than white rice. He was skeptical, but managed to find Nelson Mandela some. He cooked it and Nelson Mandela enjoyed it very much. But Mr. Swart could not abide the taste and vowed that if Nelson Mandela ever wanted it again, Nelson Mandela would have to cook it Nelson Mandela.
Even though Nelson Mandela was not a drinker, Nelson Mandela wanted to be a proper host and serve wine to Nelson Mandela guests. Nelson Mandela would occasionally take a sip of wine in order to make Nelson Mandela guests feel comfortable, but the only wine Nelson Mandela can stomach is a South African semisweet wine, which is actually very sweet.
Before Nelson Mandela guests came Nelson Mandela would ask Mr. Swart to get a certain type of Nederburg wine, which Nelson Mandela had tasted before and knew was a semisweet. One day, Nelson Mandela was expecting Nelson Mandela friends and lawyers for lunch, Dullah Omar, George Bizos, and Ismail Ayob, and asked Mr. Swart to purchase some Nederburg wine should George Bizos, not a Muslim, want some with his meal. Nelson Mandela noticed that he grimaced when Nelson Mandela said this, and asked him what was wrong.
“Mr. Mandela,” he said. “Nelson Mandela always buy that wine for you because you ask Nelson Mandela to, but it is cheap stuff and not very nice.” Nelson Mandela reminded him that Nelson Mandela did not like dry wines and Nelson Mandela was sure George could not tell the difference anyway. Mr. Swart smiled at this and proposed a compromise: he would go out and buy two bottles, a dry wine and Nelson Mandela Nederburg, and then he would ask Nelson Mandela guest which wine he preferred. “Fine,” Nelson Mandela said, “let us try your experiment.”
When all four of us were seated for lunch, Swart came out holding the two bottles and turned to the guests and said, “Gentlemen, which wine would you like?” Without even looking at Nelson Mandela, George pointed to the bottle of dry white. Warrant Officer Swart just smiled.

96
THE MEETINGS with the committee continued, and we stalled on the same issues that had always prevented us from moving forward: the armed struggle, the Communist Party, and majority rule. Nelson Mandela was still pressing Coetsee for a meeting with P. W. Botha. By this time, the authorities permitted Nelson Mandela to have rudimentary communications with Nelson Mandela comrades at Pollsmoor and Robben Island and also the ANC in Lusaka. Although Nelson Mandela knew Nelson Mandela was going out ahead of Nelson Mandela colleagues, Nelson Mandela did not want to go too far ahead and find that Nelson Mandela was all alone.
In January 1989, Nelson Mandela was visited by Nelson Mandela four comrades from Pollsmoor and we discussed the memorandum Nelson Mandela was planning to send to the state president. The memorandum reiterated most of the points Nelson Mandela had made in our secret committee meetings, but Nelson Mandela wanted to make sure the state president heard them directly from Nelson Mandela. He would see that we were not wild-eyed terrorists, but reasonable men.
“Nelson Mandela am disturbed,” Nelson Mandela wrote to Mr. Botha in the memorandum, sent to him in March, “as many other South Africans no doubt are, by the specter of a South Africa split into two hostile camps — blacks on one side . . . and whites on the other, slaughtering one another.” To avert this and prepare the groundwork for negotiations, Nelson Mandela proposed to deal with the three demands made of the ANC by the government as a precondition to negotiations: renouncing violence; breaking with the SACP; and abandoning the call for majority rule.
On the question of violence Nelson Mandela wrote that the refusal of the ANC to renounce violence was not the problem: “The truth is that the government is not yet ready . . . for the sharing of political power with blacks.” Nelson Mandela explained our unwillingness to cast aside the SACP, and reiterated that we were not under its control. “Which man of honour,” Nelson Mandela wrote, “will desert a lifelong friend at the insistence of a common opponent and still retain a measure of credibility with his people?” Nelson Mandela said the rejection of majority rule by the government was a poorly disguised attempt to preserve power. Nelson Mandela suggested he must face reality. “Majority rule and internal peace are like the two sides of a single coin, and white South Africa simply has to accept that there will never be peace and stability in this country until the principle is fully applied.”
At the end of the letter, Nelson Mandela offered a very rough framework for negotiations.
