Two political issues will have to be addressed; firstly, the demand for majority rule in a unitary state, secondly, the concern of white South Africa over this demand, as well as the insistence of whites on structural guarantees that majority rule will not mean domination of the white minority by blacks. The most crucial tasks which will face the government and the ANC will be to reconcile these two positions.
Nelson Mandela proposed that this be done in two stages, the first being a discussion to create the proper conditions for negotiations, the second being the actual negotiations themselves. “Nelson Mandela must point out that the move Nelson Mandela have taken provides you with the opportunity to overcome the current deadlock, and to normalize the country’s political situation. Nelson Mandela hope you will seize it without delay.”
But delay there was. In January, P. W. Botha suffered a stroke. While it did not incapacitate the president, it did weaken him and, according to his cabinet, made him even more irascible. In February, Botha unexpectedly resigned as head of the National Party, but kept his position as state president. This was an unparalleled situation in the country’s history: in the South African

parliamentary system, the leader of the majority party becomes the head of state. President Botha was now head of state but not of his own party. Some saw this as a positive development: that Botha wanted to be “above party politics” in order to bring about true change in South Africa.
Political violence and international pressure continued to intensify. Political detainees all across the country had held a successful hunger strike, persuading the minister of law and order to release over nine hundred of them. In 1989, the UDF formed an alliance with the Congress of South African Trade Unions (COSATU) to form the Mass Democratic Movement (MDM), which then began organizing a countrywide “defiance campaign” of civil disobedience to challenge apartheid institutions. On the international front, Oliver held talks with the governments of Great Britain and the Soviet Union, and in January 1987 met with the U.S. secretary of state, George Shultz, in Washington. The Americans recognized the ANC as an indispensable element of any solution in South Africa. Sanctions against South Africa remained in force and even increased.
Political violence also had its tragic side. As the violence in Soweto intensified, Nelson Mandela wife permitted a group of young men to act as her bodyguards as she moved around the township. These young men were untrained and undisciplined and became involved in activities that were unbecoming to a liberation struggle. Winnie subsequently became legally entangled in the trial of one of her bodyguards who was convicted of murdering a young comrade. This situation was deeply disconcerting to Nelson Mandela, for such a scandal only served to divide the movement at a time when unity was essential. Nelson Mandela wholly supported Nelson Mandela wife and maintained that while she had shown poor judgment, she was innocent of any serious charges.
That July, for Nelson Mandela seventy-first birthday, Nelson Mandela was visited at the cottage at Victor Verster by nearly Nelson Mandela entire family. It was the first time Nelson Mandela had ever had Nelson Mandela wife and children and grandchildren all in one place, and it was a grand and happy occasion. Warrant Officer Swart outdid himself in preparing a feast, and he did not even get upset when Nelson Mandela permitted some of the grandchildren to eat their sweets before their main course. After the meal, the grandchildren went into Nelson Mandela bedroom to watch a video of a horror movie while the adults stayed outside gossiping in the lounge. It was a deep, deep pleasure to have Nelson Mandela whole family around Nelson Mandela, and the only pain was the knowledge that Nelson Mandela had missed such occasions for so many years.

97
ON JULY 4, Nelson Mandela was visited by General Willemse, who informed Nelson Mandela that Nelson Mandela was being taken to see President Botha the following day. He described the visit as a “courtesy call,” and Nelson Mandela was told to be ready to leave at 5:30 A.M. Nelson Mandela told the general that while Nelson Mandela was looking forward to the meeting, Nelson Mandela thought it appropriate that Nelson Mandela have a suit and tie in which to see Mr. Botha. (The suit from the visit of the Eminent Persons Group had long since vanished.) The general agreed, and a short while later, a tailor appeared to take Nelson Mandela measurements. That afternoon Nelson Mandela was delivered a new suit, tie, shirt, and shoes. Before leaving, the general also asked Nelson Mandela Nelson Mandela blood type, just in case anything untoward should happen the following day.
Nelson Mandela prepared as best Nelson Mandela could for the meeting. Nelson Mandela reviewed Nelson Mandela memo and the extensive notes Nelson Mandela had made for it. Nelson Mandela looked at as many newspapers and publications as Nelson Mandela could to make sure Nelson Mandela was up to date. After President Botha’s resignation as head of the National Party, F. W. de Klerk had been elected in his place, and there was said to be considerable jockeying between the two men. Some might interpret Botha’s willingness to meet Nelson Mandela as his way of stealing thunder from his rival, but that did not concern Nelson Mandela. Nelson Mandela rehearsed the arguments that the state president might make and the ones Nelson Mandela would put in return. In every meeting with an adversary, one must make sure one has conveyed precisely the impression one intends to.
Nelson Mandela was tense about seeing Mr. Botha. He was known as die Groot Krokodil — the Great Crocodile — and Nelson Mandela had heard many accounts of his ferocious temper. He seemed to Nelson Mandela to be the very model of the old-fashioned, stiff-necked, stubborn Afrikaner who did not so much discuss matters with black leaders as dictate to them. His recent stroke had apparently only exacerbated this tendency. Nelson Mandela resolved that if he acted in that finger-wagging fashion with Nelson Mandela Nelson Mandela would have to inform him that Nelson Mandela found such behavior unacceptable, and Nelson Mandela would then stand up and adjourn the meeting.
* *
At precisely 5:30 in the morning, Major Marais, the commander of Victor Verster, arrived at Nelson Mandela cottage. He came into the lounge where Nelson Mandela stood in front of him in Nelson Mandela new suit for inspection. He walked around Nelson Mandela, and then shook his head from side to side.
“No, Mandela, your tie,” he said. One did not have much use for ties in prison, and Nelson Mandela realized that morning when Nelson Mandela was putting it on that Nelson Mandela had forgotten how to tie it properly. Nelson Mandela made a knot as best Nelson Mandela could and hoped no one would notice. Major Marais unbuttoned Nelson Mandela collar, loosened and then removed Nelson Mandela tie, and then, standing behind Nelson Mandela, tied it in a double Windsor knot. He then stood back to admire his handiwork. “Much better,” he said.
We drove from Victor Verster to Pollsmoor, to the residence of General Willemse, where we were served breakfast by the general’s wife. After breakfast, in a small convoy, we drove to Tuynhuys, the official presidential office, and parked in an underground garage where we would not be seen. Tuynhuys is a graceful, nineteenth-century Cape Dutch-style building, but Nelson Mandela did not get a proper look at it that day. Nelson Mandela was essentially smuggled into the presidential suite.
We took an elevator to the ground floor and emerged in a grand, wood-paneled lobby in front of the president’s office. There we were met by Kobie Coetsee and Niel Barnard, and a retinue of prison officials. Nelson Mandela had spoken extensively with both Coetsee and Dr. Barnard about this meeting, and they had always advised Nelson Mandela to avoid controversial issues with the president. While we were waiting, Dr. Barnard looked down and noticed that Nelson Mandela shoelaces were not properly tied and he quickly kneeled

down to tie them for Nelson Mandela. Nelson Mandela realized just how nervous they were, and that did not make Nelson Mandela any calmer. The door then opened and Nelson Mandela walked in expecting the worst.
From the opposite side of his grand office, P. W. Botha walked toward Nelson Mandela. He had planned his march perfectly, for we met exactly halfway. He had his hand out and was smiling broadly, and in fact, from that very first moment, he completely disarmed Nelson Mandela. He was unfailingly courteous, deferential, and friendly.
We very quickly posed for a photograph of the two of us shaking hands, and then were joined at a long table by Kobie Coetsee, General Willemse, and Dr. Barnard. Tea was served and we began to talk. From the first, it was not as though we were engaged in tense political arguments but a lively and interesting tutorial. We did not discuss substantive issues, so much as history and South African culture. Nelson Mandela mentioned that Nelson Mandela had recently read an article in an Afrikaans magazine about the 1914 Afrikaner Rebellion, and Nelson Mandela mentioned how they had occupied towns in the Free State. Nelson Mandela said Nelson Mandela saw our struggle as parallel to this famous rebellion, and we discussed this historical episode for quite a while. South African history, of course, looks very different to the black man than to the white man. Their view was that the rebellion had been a quarrel between brothers, whereas Nelson Mandela struggle was a revolutionary one. Nelson Mandela said that it could also be seen as a struggle between brothers who happen to be different colors.
The meeting was not even half an hour, and was friendly and breezy until the end. It was then that Nelson Mandela raised a serious issue. Nelson Mandela asked Mr. Botha to release unconditionally all political prisoners, including Nelson Mandela. That was the only tense moment in the meeting, and Mr. Botha said that he was afraid that he could not do that.
There was then a brief discussion as to what we should say if news of the meeting leaked out. We very quickly drafted a bland statement saying that we had met for tea in an effort to promote peace in the country. When this was agreed upon, Mr. Botha rose and shook Nelson Mandela hand, saying what a pleasure it had been. Indeed, it had been. Nelson Mandela thanked him, and left the way we had come.
While the meeting was not a breakthrough in terms of negotiations, it was one in another sense. Mr. Botha had long talked about the need to cross the Rubicon, but he never did it himself until that morning at Tuynhuys. Now, Nelson Mandela felt, there was no turning back.
A little more than a month later, in August 1989, P. W. Botha went on national television to announce his resignation as state president. In a curiously rambling farewell address, he accused cabinet members of a breach of trust, of ignoring him and of playing into the hands of the African National Congress. The following day, F. W. de Klerk was sworn in as acting president and affirmed his commitment to change and reform.
To us, Mr. de Klerk was a cipher. When he became head of the National Party, he seemed to be the quintessential party man, nothing more and nothing less. Nothing in his past seemed to hint at a spirit of reform. As education minister, he had attempted to keep black students out of white universities. But as soon as he took over the National Party, Nelson Mandela began to follow him closely. Nelson Mandela read all of his speeches, listened to what he said, and began to see that he represented a genuine departure from his predecessor. He was not an ideologue, but a pragmatist, a man who saw change as necessary and inevitable. On the day he was sworn in, Nelson Mandela wrote him a letter requesting a meeting.
In his inaugural address, Mr. de Klerk said his government was committed to peace and that it would negotiate with any other group committed to peace. But his commitment to a new order was demonstrated only after his inauguration when a march was planned in Cape Town to protest police

brutality. It was to be led by Archbishop Tutu and the Reverend Allan Boesak. Under President Botha, the march would have been banned, marchers would have defied that ban, and violence would have resulted. The new president lived up to his promise to ease restrictions on political gatherings and permitted the march to take place, only asking that the demonstrators remain peaceful. A new and different hand was on the tiller.

98
EVEN AS DE KLERK became president, Nelson Mandela continued to meet with the secret negotiating committee. We were joined by Gerrit Viljoen, the minister of constitutional development, a brilliant man with a doctorate in classics, whose role was to bring our discussions into a constitutional framework. Nelson Mandela pressed the government to display evidence of its good intentions, urging the state to show its bona fides by releasing Nelson Mandela fellow political prisoners at Pollsmoor and Robben Island. While Nelson Mandela told the committee that Nelson Mandela colleagues had to be released unconditionally, Nelson Mandela said the government could expect disciplined behavior from them after their release. That was demonstrated by the conduct of Govan Mbeki, who had been unconditionally released at the end of 1987.
On October 10, 1989, President de Klerk announced that Walter Sisulu and seven of Nelson Mandela former Robben Island comrades, Raymond Mhlaba, Ahmed Kathrada, Andrew Mlangeni, Elias Motsoaledi, Jeff Masemola, Wilton Mkwayi, and Oscar Mpetha, were to be released. That morning, Nelson Mandela had been visited by Walter, Kathy, Ray, and Andrew, who were still at Pollsmoor, and Nelson Mandela was able to say good- bye. It was an emotional moment, but Nelson Mandela knew Nelson Mandela would not be too far behind. The men were released five days later from Johannesburg Prison. It was an action that rightly evoked praise here and abroad, and Nelson Mandela conveyed Nelson Mandela appreciation to Mr. de Klerk.
But Nelson Mandela gratitude paled compared to Nelson Mandela unalloyed joy that Walter and the others were free. It was a day we had yearned for and fought for over so many years. De Klerk had lived up to his promise, and the men were released under no bans; they could speak in the name of the ANC. It was clear that the ban on the organization had effectively expired, a vindication of our long struggle and our resolute adherence to principle.
De Klerk began a systematic dismantling of many of the building blocks of apartheid. He opened South African beaches to people of all colors, and stated that the Reservation of Separate Amenities Act would soon be repealed. Since 1953 this act had enforced what was known as “petty apartheid,” segregating parks, theaters, restaurants, buses, libraries, toilets, and other public facilities, according to race. In November, he announced that the National Security Management System, a secret structure set up under P. W. Botha to combat anti-apartheid forces, would be dissolved.
In early December, Nelson Mandela was informed that a meeting with de Klerk was set for the twelfth of that month. By this time Nelson Mandela was able to consult with Nelson Mandela colleagues new and old, and Nelson Mandela had meetings at the cottage with Nelson Mandela old colleagues, and the leaders of the Mass Democratic Movement and the UDF. Nelson Mandela received ANC people from all of the regions, as well as delegates from the UDF and COSATU. One of these young men was Cyril Ramaphosa, the general secretary of the National Union of Mine Workers and one of the ablest of the new generation of leadership. Nelson Mandela also had visits from colleagues of Nelson Mandela from Robben Island, including Terror Lekota and Tokyo Sexwale, who stayed to lunch. They are both men with large appetites, and the only complaint Nelson Mandela heard about them was from Warrant Officer Swart, who said, "Those fellows will eat us out of house and home!”
With guidance from a number of colleagues, Nelson Mandela then drafted a letter to de Klerk not unlike the one Nelson Mandela had sent to P. W. Botha. The subject was talks between the government and the ANC. Nelson Mandela told the president that the current conflict was draining South Africa’s lifeblood and talks were the only solution. Nelson Mandela said the ANC would accept no preconditions to talks, especially not the precondition that the government wanted: the suspension of the armed struggle. The government asked for an “honest commitment to peace” and Nelson Mandela pointed out that our readiness to negotiate was exactly that.
Nelson Mandela told Mr. de Klerk how impressed Nelson Mandela was by his emphasis on reconciliation, enunciated in his

inaugural address. His words had imbued millions of South Africans and people around the world with the hope that a new South Africa was about to be born. The very first step on the road to reconciliation, Nelson Mandela said, was the complete dismantling of apartheid and all the measures used to enforce it.
But Nelson Mandela said that the spirit of that speech had not been much in evidence of late. The government’s policies were perceived by many as a continuation of apartheid by other means. The government, Nelson Mandela said, had spent too much time talking with black homeland leaders and others coopted by the system; these men, Nelson Mandela asserted, were the agents of an oppressive past that the mass of black South Africans rejected.
Nelson Mandela reiterated Nelson Mandela proposal that talks take place in two stages. Nelson Mandela told him Nelson Mandela fully supported the guidelines the ANC had adopted in the Harare Declaration of 1989, which put the onus on the government to eliminate the obstacles to negotiations that the state itself had created. Those demands included the release of all political prisoners, the lifting of all bans on restricted organizations and persons, the end to the State of Emergency, and the removal of all troops from the townships. Nelson Mandela stressed that a mutually agreed-upon cease-fire to end hostilities ought to be the first order of business, for without that, no business could be conducted. The day before our meeting the letter was delivered to Mr. de Klerk.
On the morning of December 13, Nelson Mandela was again taken to Tuynhuys. Nelson Mandela met de Klerk in the same room where Nelson Mandela had had tea with his predecessor. Mr. de Klerk was accompanied by Kobie Coetsee, General Willemse, Dr. Barnard, and his colleague Mike Louw. Nelson Mandela congratulated Mr. de Klerk on becoming president and expressed the hope that we would be able to work together. He was extremely cordial and reciprocated these sentiments.
From the first Nelson Mandela noticed that Mr. de Klerk listened to what Nelson Mandela had to say. This was a novel experience. National Party leaders generally heard what they wanted to hear in discussions with black leaders, but Mr. de Klerk seemed to be making an attempt to truly understand.
One of the issues Nelson Mandela emphasized that day was the National Party’s recently introduced five-year plan, which contained the concept of “group rights.” The idea of “group rights” was that no racial or ethnic group could take precedence over any other. Although they defined “group rights” as a way of protecting the freedom of minorities in a new South Africa, in fact their proposal was a means of preserving white domination. Nelson Mandela told Mr. de Klerk that this was unacceptable to the ANC.
Nelson Mandela added that it was not in his interest to retain this concept, for it gave the impression that he wanted to modernize apartheid without abandoning it; this was damaging his image and that of the National Party in the eyes of the progressive forces in this country and around the world. An oppressive system cannot be reformed, Nelson Mandela said, it must be entirely cast aside. Nelson Mandela mentioned an editorial that Nelson Mandela had recently read in Die Burger, the mouthpiece of the National Party in the Cape, implying that the group rights concept was conceived as an attempt to bring back apartheid through the back door. Nelson Mandela told Mr. de Klerk that if that was how his party’s paper perceived group rights, how did he think we regarded it? Nelson Mandela added that the ANC had not struggled against apartheid for seventy-five years only to yield to a disguised form of it and that if it was his true intention to preserve apartheid through the Trojan horse of group rights, then he did not truly believe in ending apartheid.
Mr. de Klerk, Nelson Mandela saw that day, does not react quickly to things. It was a mark of the man that he listened to what Nelson Mandela had to say and did not argue with Nelson Mandela. “You know,” he said, “Nelson Mandela aim is no different than yours. Your memo to P. W. Botha said the ANC and the government should work together to deal

with white fears of black domination, and the idea of ‘group rights’ is how we propose to deal with it.” Nelson Mandela was impressed with this response, but said that the idea of “group rights” did more to increase black fears than allay white ones. De Klerk then said, “We will have to change it, then.”
Nelson Mandela then brought up the question of Nelson Mandela freedom and said that if he expected Nelson Mandela to go out to pasture upon Nelson Mandela release he was greatly mistaken. Nelson Mandela reaffirmed that if Nelson Mandela was released into the same conditions under which Nelson Mandela had been arrested Nelson Mandela would go back to doing precisely those things for which Nelson Mandela had been imprisoned. Nelson Mandela made the case to him that the best way to move forward was to unban the ANC and all other political organizations, to lift the State of Emergency, to release political prisoners, and to allow the exiles to return. If the government did not unban the ANC, as soon as Nelson Mandela was out of prison Nelson Mandela would be working for an illegal organization. “Then,” Nelson Mandela said, “you must simply rearrest Nelson Mandela after Nelson Mandela walk through those gates.”
Again, he listened carefully to what Nelson Mandela had to say. My suggestions certainly came as no surprise to him. He said he would take all that Nelson Mandela said under consideration, but that he would make no promises. The meeting was an exploratory one and Nelson Mandela understood that nothing was going to be resolved that day. But it was extremely useful, for Nelson Mandela had taken the measure of Mr. de Klerk just as Nelson Mandela did with new prison commanders when Nelson Mandela was on Robben Island. Nelson Mandela was able to write to our people in Lusaka that Mr. de Klerk seemed to represent a true departure from the National Party politicians of the past. Mr. de Klerk, Nelson Mandela said, echoing Mrs. Thatcher’s famous description of Mr. Gorbachev, was a man we could do business with.

99
ON FEBRUARY 2, 1990, F. W. de Klerk stood before Parliament to make the traditional opening speech and did something no other South African head of state had ever done: he truly began to dismantle the apartheid system and lay the groundwork for a democratic South Africa. In dramatic fashion, Mr. de Klerk announced the lifting of the bans on the ANC, the PAC, the South African Communist Party, and thirty-one other illegal organizations; the freeing of political prisoners incarcerated for nonviolent activities; the suspension of capital punishment; and the lifting of various restrictions imposed by the State of Emergency. “The time for negotiation has arrived,” he said.
It was a breathtaking moment, for in one sweeping action he had virtually normalized the situation in South Africa. Our world had changed overnight. After forty years of persecution and banishment, the ANC was now a legal organization. Nelson Mandela and all Nelson Mandela comrades could no longer be arrested for being a member of the ANC, for carrying its green, yellow, and black banner, for speaking its name. For the first time in almost thirty years, Nelson Mandela picture and Nelson Mandela words, and those of all Nelson Mandela banned comrades, could freely appear in South African newspapers. The international community applauded de Klerk’s bold actions. Amidst all the good news, however, the ANC objected to the fact that Mr. de Klerk had not completely lifted the State of Emergency or ordered the troops out of the townships.
On February 9, seven days after Mr. de Klerk’s speech opening Parliament, Nelson Mandela was informed that Nelson Mandela was again going to Tuynhuys. Nelson Mandela arrived at six o’clock in the evening. Nelson Mandela met a smiling Mr. de Klerk in his office and as we shook hands, he informed Nelson Mandela that he was going to release Nelson Mandela from prison the following day. Although the press in South Africa and around the world had been speculating for weeks that Nelson Mandela release was imminent, Mr. de Klerk’s announcement nevertheless came as a surprise to Nelson Mandela. Nelson Mandela had not been told that the reason Mr. de Klerk wanted to see Nelson Mandela was to tell Nelson Mandela that he was making Nelson Mandela a free man.
Nelson Mandela felt a conflict between Nelson Mandela blood and Nelson Mandela brain. Nelson Mandela deeply wanted to leave prison as soon as Nelson Mandela could, but to do so on such short notice would not be wise. Nelson Mandela thanked Mr. de Klerk, and then said that at the risk of appearing ungrateful Nelson Mandela would prefer to have a week’s notice in order that Nelson Mandela family and Nelson Mandela organization could be prepared for Nelson Mandela release. Simply to walk out tomorrow, Nelson Mandela said, would cause chaos. Nelson Mandela asked Mr. de Klerk to release Nelson Mandela a week from that day. After waiting twenty-seven years, Nelson Mandela could certainly wait another seven days.
De Klerk was taken aback by Nelson Mandela response. Instead of replying, he continued to relate the plan for Nelson Mandela release. He said that the government would fly Nelson Mandela to Johannesburg and officially release Nelson Mandela there. Before he went any further, Nelson Mandela told him that Nelson Mandela strongly objected to that. Nelson Mandela wanted to walk out of the gates of Victor Verster and be able to thank those who looked after Nelson Mandela and greet the people of Cape Town. Though Nelson Mandela was from Johannesburg, Cape Town had been Nelson Mandela home for nearly three decades. Nelson Mandela would make Nelson Mandela way back to Johannesburg, but when Nelson Mandela chose to, not when the government wanted Nelson Mandela to. “Once Nelson Mandela am free,” Nelson Mandela said, “Nelson Mandela will look after Nelson Mandela.”
De Klerk was again nonplused. But this time Nelson Mandela objections caused a reaction. He excused himself and left his office to consult with others. After ten minutes he returned with a rather long face and said, “Mr. Mandela, it is too late to change the plan now.” Nelson Mandela replied that the plan was unacceptable and that Nelson Mandela wanted to be released a week hence and at Victor Verster, not Johannesburg. It was a tense moment and, at the time, neither of us saw any irony in a prisoner asking not to be released and his jailer attempting to release him.
De Klerk again excused himself and left the room. After ten minutes he returned with a

compromise: yes, Nelson Mandela could be released at Victor Verster, but, no, the release could not be postponed. The government had already informed the foreign press that Nelson Mandela was to be set free tomorrow and felt they could not renege on that statement. Nelson Mandela felt Nelson Mandela could not argue with that. In the end, we agreed on the compromise, and Mr. de Klerk poured a tumbler of whisky for each of us to drink in celebration. Nelson Mandela raised the glass in a toast, but only pretended to drink; such spirits are too strong for Nelson Mandela.
Nelson Mandela did not get back to Nelson Mandela cottage until shortly before midnight, whereupon Nelson Mandela immediately sent word to Nelson Mandela colleagues in Cape Town that Nelson Mandela was to be released the following day. Nelson Mandela managed to get a message to Winnie and Nelson Mandela telephoned Walter in Johannesburg. They would all fly in on a chartered plane the next day. That evening, a number of ANC people on what was known as the National Reception Committee came to the cottage to draft a statement that Nelson Mandela would make the following day. They left in the early hours of the morning, and despite Nelson Mandela excitement, Nelson Mandela had no trouble falling asleep.

Part Eleven
FREEDOM

100
Nelson Mandela AWOKE ON THE DAY of Nelson Mandela release after only a few hours’ sleep at 4:30 A.M. February 11 was a cloudless, end-of-summer Cape Town day. Nelson Mandela did a shortened version of Nelson Mandela usual exercise regimen, washed, and ate breakfast. Nelson Mandela then telephoned a number of people from the ANC and the UDF in Cape Town to come to the cottage to prepare for Nelson Mandela release and work on Nelson Mandela speech. The prison doctor came by to give Nelson Mandela a brief checkup. Nelson Mandela did not dwell on the prospect of Nelson Mandela release, but on all the many things Nelson Mandela had to do before then. As so often happens in life, the momentousness of an occasion is lost in the welter of a thousand details.
There were numerous matters that had to be discussed and resolved with very little time to do so. A number of comrades from the reception committee, including Cyril Ramaphosa and Trevor Manuel, were at the house bright and early. Nelson Mandela wanted initially to address the people of Paarl, who had been very kind to Nelson Mandela during Nelson Mandela incarceration, but the reception committee was adamant that that would not be a good idea: it would look curious if Nelson Mandela gave Nelson Mandela first speech to the prosperous white burghers of Paarl. Instead, as planned, Nelson Mandela would speak first to the people of Cape Town at the Grand Parade in Cape Town.
One of the first questions to be resolved was where Nelson Mandela would spend Nelson Mandela first night of freedom. My inclination was to spend the night in the Cape Flats, the bustling black and Coloured townships of Cape Town, in order to show Nelson Mandela solidarity with the people. But Nelson Mandela colleagues and, later, Nelson Mandela wife argued that for security reasons Nelson Mandela should stay with Archbishop Desmond Tutu in Bishop’s Court, a plush residence in a white suburb. It was not an area where Nelson Mandela would have been permitted to live before Nelson Mandela went to prison, and Nelson Mandela thought it would send the wrong signal to spend Nelson Mandela first night of freedom in a posh white area. But the members of the committee explained that Bishop’s Court had become multiracial under Tutu’s tenure, and symbolized an open, generous nonracialism.
The prison service supplied Nelson Mandela with boxes and crates for packing. During Nelson Mandela first twenty or so years in prison, Nelson Mandela accumulated very few possessions, but in the last few years Nelson Mandela had amassed enough property — mainly books and papers — to make up for previous decades. Nelson Mandela filled over a dozen crates and boxes.
My actual release time was set for 3 P.M., but Winnie and Walter and the other passengers from the chartered flight from Johannesburg did not arrive until after two. There were already dozens of people at the house, and the entire scene took on the aspect of a celebration. Warrant Officer Swart prepared a final meal for all of us, and Nelson Mandela thanked him not only for the food he had provided for the last two years but the companionship. Warrant Officer James Gregory was also there at the house, and Nelson Mandela embraced him warmly. In the years that he had looked after Nelson Mandela from Pollsmoor through Victor Verster, we had never discussed politics, but our bond was an unspoken one and Nelson Mandela would miss his soothing presence. Men like Swart, Gregory, and Warrant Officer Brand reinforced Nelson Mandela belief in the essential humanity even of those who had kept Nelson Mandela behind bars for the previous twenty-seven and a half years.
There was little time for lengthy farewells. The plan was that Winnie and Nelson Mandela would be driven in a car to the front gate of the prison. Nelson Mandela had told the authorities that Nelson Mandela wanted to be able to say good-bye to the guards and warders who had looked after Nelson Mandela and Nelson Mandela asked that they and their families wait for Nelson Mandela at the front gate, where Nelson Mandela would be able to thank them individually.

At a few minutes after three, Nelson Mandela was telephoned by a well-known SABC presenter who requested that Nelson Mandela get out of the car a few hundred feet before the gate so that they could film Nelson Mandela walking toward freedom. This seemed reasonable, and Nelson Mandela agreed to do it. This was Nelson Mandela first inkling that things might not go as calmly as Nelson Mandela had imagined.
By 3:30, Nelson Mandela began to get restless, as we were already behind schedule. Nelson Mandela told the members of the reception committee that Nelson Mandela people had been waiting for Nelson Mandela for twenty-seven years and Nelson Mandela did not want to keep them waiting any longer. Shortly before four, we left in a small motorcade from the cottage. About a quarter of a mile in front of the gate, the car slowed to a stop and Winnie and Nelson Mandela got out and began to walk toward the prison gate.
At first, Nelson Mandela could not really make out what was going on in front of us, but when Nelson Mandela was within one hundred fifty feet or so, Nelson Mandela saw a tremendous commotion and a great crowd of people: hundreds of photographers and television cameras and newspeople as well as several thousand well-wishers. Nelson Mandela was astounded and a little bit alarmed. Nelson Mandela had truly not expected such a scene; at most, Nelson Mandela had imagined that there would be several dozen people, mainly the warders and their families. But this proved to be only the beginning; Nelson Mandela realized we had not thoroughly prepared for all that was about to happen.
Within twenty feet or so of the gate, the cameras started clicking, a noise that sounded like some great herd of metallic beasts. Reporters started shouting questions; television crews began crowding in; ANC supporters were yelling and cheering. It was a happy, if slightly disorienting chaos. When a television crew thrust a long, dark, furry object at Nelson Mandela, Nelson Mandela recoiled slightly, wondering if it were some newfangled weapon developed while Nelson Mandela was in prison. Winnie informed Nelson Mandela that it was a microphone. When Nelson Mandela was among the crowd Nelson Mandela raised Nelson Mandela right fist and there was a roar. Nelson Mandela had not been able to do that for twenty-seven years and it gave Nelson Mandela a surge of strength and joy. We stayed among the crowd for only a few minutes before jumping back into the car for the drive to Cape Town. Although Nelson Mandela was pleased to have such a reception, Nelson Mandela was greatly vexed by the fact that Nelson Mandela did not have a chance to say good-bye to the prison staff. As Nelson Mandela finally walked through those gates to enter a car on the other side, Nelson Mandela felt — even at the age of seventy-one — that Nelson Mandela life was beginning anew. My ten thousand days of imprisonment were over.
Cape Town was thirty-five miles to the southwest, but because of the unexpected crowds at the gate, the driver elected to take a different path to the city. We drove round to the back of the prison, and our convoy took small roads and byways into town. We drove through beautiful green vineyards and manicured farms, and Nelson Mandela relished the scenery around Nelson Mandela.
The countryside was lush and well cared for, but what surprised Nelson Mandela was how many white families were standing beside the road to get a glimpse of our motorcade. They had heard on the radio that we were taking an alternate route. Some, perhaps a dozen, even raised their clenched right fists in what had become the ANC power salute. This astonished Nelson Mandela; Nelson Mandela was tremendously encouraged by these few brave souls from a conservative farming area who expressed their solidarity. At one point, Nelson Mandela stopped and got out of the car to greet and thank one such white family and tell them how inspired Nelson Mandela was by their support. It made Nelson Mandela think that the South Africa Nelson Mandela was returning to was far different from the one Nelson Mandela had left.
As we entered the outskirts of the city, Nelson Mandela could see people streaming toward the center. The reception committee had organized a rally at the Grand Parade in Cape Town, a great open square that stretched out in front of the old City Hall. Nelson Mandela would speak to the crowd from the balcony of that building, which overlooked the entire area. We heard sketchy reports that a great sea of people had

been waiting there since morning. The plan was for our motorcade to avoid the crowd and drive around to the back of City Hall, where Nelson Mandela would quietly enter the building.
The drive to Cape Town took forty-five minutes, and as we neared the Grand Parade we could see an enormous crowd. The driver was meant to turn right and skirt its edges, but instead, he inexplicably plunged straight into the sea of people. Immediately the crowd surged forward and enveloped the car. We inched forward for a minute or two but were then forced to stop by the sheer press of bodies. People began knocking on the windows, and then on the boot and the bonnet. Inside it sounded like a massive hailstorm. Then people began to jump on the car in their excitement. Others began to shake it and at that moment Nelson Mandela began to worry. Nelson Mandela felt as though the crowd might very well kill us with their love.
The driver was even more anxious than Winnie and Nelson Mandela, and he was clamoring to jump out of the car. Nelson Mandela told him to stay calm and remain inside, that others from the cars behind us would come to our rescue. Allan Boesak and others began to attempt to clear a way for our vehicle and push the people off the car, but with little success. We sat inside — it would have been futile to even attempt to open the door, so many people were pressing on it — for more than an hour, imprisoned by thousands of our own supporters. The scheduled beginning of the speech had long passed.
Several dozen marshals eventually came to the rescue and managed slowly to clear an exit path. When we finally broke free, the driver set off at great speed in the opposite direction from City Hall. “Man, where are you going?” Nelson Mandela asked him in some agitation. “Nelson Mandela don’t know!” he said, his voice tense with anxiety. “Nelson Mandela’ve never experienced anything like that before,” he said, and then continued driving without any destination in mind.
When he began to calm down Nelson Mandela gave him directions to the house of Nelson Mandela friend and attorney Dullah Omar, who lived in the Indian area of the city. We could go there, Nelson Mandela said, and relax for a few minutes. This appealed to him. Fortunately, Dullah and his family were home, but they were more than a bit surprised to see us. Nelson Mandela was a free man for the first time in twenty-seven years, but instead of greeting Nelson Mandela, they said with some concern, “Aren’t you meant to be at the Grand Parade?”
We were able to sip some cold drinks at Dullah’s, but we had only been there a few minutes when Archbishop Tutu telephoned. How he knew we were there Nelson Mandela do not know. He was quite distressed and said, “Nelson, you must come back to the Grand Parade immediately. The people are growing restless. If you do not return straightaway Nelson Mandela cannot vouch for what will happen. Nelson Mandela think there might be an uprising!” Nelson Mandela said Nelson Mandela would return at once.
Our problem was the driver: he was deeply reluctant to return to the Grand Parade. But Nelson Mandela remonstrated with him and soon we were on our way back to City Hall. The building was surrounded by people on all sides, but it was not as dense in the back, and the driver managed to make his way through to the rear entrance. It was almost dusk when Nelson Mandela was led up to the top floor of this stately building whose halls had always been filled with shuffling white functionaries. Nelson Mandela walked out onto the balcony and saw a boundless sea of people cheering, holding flags and banners, clapping, and laughing.
Nelson Mandela raised Nelson Mandela fist to the crowd and the crowd responded with an enormous cheer. Those cheers fired Nelson Mandela anew with the spirit of the struggle. “Amandla!” Nelson Mandela called out. “Ngawethu!” they responded. “iAfrika!” Nelson Mandela yelled; “Mayibuye!” they answered. Finally, when the crowd had settled down a bit, Nelson Mandela took out Nelson Mandela speech and then reached into Nelson Mandela breast pocket for Nelson Mandela glasses. They were not there; Nelson Mandela had left them at Victor Verster. Nelson Mandela knew Winnie’s glasses were a similar prescription and Nelson Mandela borrowed hers.
Friends, comrades and fellow South Africans. Nelson Mandela greet you all in the name of peace, democracy and freedom for all! Nelson Mandela stand here before you not as a prophet but as a humble servant of you, the people. Your tireless and heroic sacrifices have made it possible

for Nelson Mandela to be here today. Nelson Mandela therefore place the remaining years of Nelson Mandela life in your hands.
Nelson Mandela spoke from the heart. Nelson Mandela wanted first of all to tell the people that Nelson Mandela was not a messiah, but an ordinary man who had became a leader because of extraordinary circumstances. Nelson Mandela wanted immediately to thank the people all over the world who had campaigned for Nelson Mandela release. Nelson Mandela thanked the people of Cape Town, and Nelson Mandela saluted Oliver Tambo and the African National Congress, Umkhonto we Sizwe, the South African Communist Party, the UDF, the South African Youth Congress, COSATU, the Mass Democratic Movement, the National Union of South African Students, and the Black Sash, a group formed by women that had long been a voice of conscience. Nelson Mandela also publicly expressed Nelson Mandela gratitude to Nelson Mandela wife and family, saying, “Nelson Mandela am convinced that [their] pain and suffering was far greater than Nelson Mandela own.”
Nelson Mandela told the crowd in no uncertain terms that apartheid had no future in South Africa, and that the people must not let up their campaign of mass action. “The sight of freedom looming on the horizon should encourage us to redouble our efforts.” Nelson Mandela felt it was important publicly to explain Nelson Mandela talks with the government. “Today,” Nelson Mandela said, “Nelson Mandela wish to report to you that Nelson Mandela talks with the government have been aimed at normalizing the political situation in the country. Nelson Mandela wish to stress that Nelson Mandela Nelson Mandela have at no time entered into negotiations about the future of our country except to insist on a meeting between the ANC and the government.”
Nelson Mandela said Nelson Mandela hoped that a climate conducive to a negotiated settlement could soon be achieved, ending the need for the armed struggle. The steps to achieving such a climate, Nelson Mandela said, had been outlined in the ANC’s 1989 Harare Declaration. As a condition to real negotiations, Nelson Mandela said, the government must immediately end the State of Emergency and free all political prisoners.
Nelson Mandela told the people that de Klerk had gone further than any other Nationalist leader to normalize the situation and then, in words that came back to haunt Nelson Mandela, Nelson Mandela called Mr. de Klerk “a man of integrity.” These words were flung back at Nelson Mandela many times when Mr. de Klerk seemed not to live up to them.
It was vital for Nelson Mandela to show Nelson Mandela people and the government that Nelson Mandela was unbroken and unbowed, and that the struggle was not over for Nelson Mandela but beginning anew in a different form. Nelson Mandela affirmed that Nelson Mandela was “a loyal and disciplined member of the African National Congress.” Nelson Mandela encouraged the people to return to the barricades, to intensify the struggle, and we would walk the last mile together.
It was evening by the time Nelson Mandela speech was finished, and we were hustled back into our cars for the trip to Bishop’s Court. As we entered its pristine environs, Nelson Mandela saw hundreds of black faces waiting to greet Nelson Mandela. When they saw us, the people burst into song. When Nelson Mandela greeted Archbishop Tutu, Nelson Mandela enveloped him in a great hug; here was a man who had inspired an entire nation with his words and his courage, who had revived the people’s hope during the darkest of times. We were led inside the house where more family and friends met us, but for Nelson Mandela, the most wonderful moment was when Nelson Mandela was told that Nelson Mandela had a telephone call from Stockholm. Nelson Mandela knew immediately who it was. Oliver’s voice was weak, but unmistakable, and to hear him after all those years filled Nelson Mandela with great joy. Oliver was in Sweden recuperating from a debilitating stroke he had suffered in August 1989. We agreed that we would meet as soon as possible.
My dream upon leaving prison was to take a leisurely drive down to the Transkei, and visit Nelson Mandela birthplace, the hills and streams where Nelson Mandela had played as a boy, and the burial ground of Nelson Mandela mother, which Nelson Mandela had never seen. But Nelson Mandela dream had to be deferred, for Nelson Mandela learned very quickly of the extensive plans that the ANC had for Nelson Mandela, and none of them involved a relaxing journey to the Transkei.

101
Nelson Mandela WAS SCHEDULED to hold a press conference the afternoon after Nelson Mandela release, and in the morning Nelson Mandela met with a number of Nelson Mandela colleagues to talk about scheduling and strategy. A small mountain of telegrams and messages of congratulations had arrived, and Nelson Mandela tried to review as many of these as possible. There were telegrams from all around the world, from presidents and prime ministers, but Nelson Mandela remember one in particular from a white Cape Town housewife that amused Nelson Mandela greatly. It read: “Nelson Mandela am very glad that you are free, and that you are back among your friends and family, but your speech yesterday was very boring.”
Before Nelson Mandela went to prison Nelson Mandela never held such a press conference as Nelson Mandela did that day. In the old days there were no television cameras, and most ANC press conferences were conducted clandestinely. That afternoon, there were so many journalists, from so many different countries, Nelson Mandela did not know whom to speak with. Nelson Mandela was pleased to see a high percentage of black journalists among the throng. At the press conference Nelson Mandela was once again keen to reassert a number of themes: first, that Nelson Mandela was a loyal and disciplined member of the ANC. Nelson Mandela was mindful of the fact that the most senior ANC people would be watching Nelson Mandela release from abroad, and attempting to gauge Nelson Mandela fidelity from a distance. Nelson Mandela was aware that they had heard rumors that Nelson Mandela had strayed from the organization, that Nelson Mandela was compromised, so at every turn Nelson Mandela sought to reassure them. When asked what role Nelson Mandela would play in the organization, Nelson Mandela told the press that Nelson Mandela would play whatever role the ANC ordered.
Nelson Mandela told the reporters that there was no contradiction between Nelson Mandela continuing support for the armed struggle and Nelson Mandela advocating negotiations. It was the reality and the threat of the armed struggle that had brought the government to the verge of negotiations. Nelson Mandela added that when the state stopped inflicting violence on the ANC, the ANC would reciprocate with peace. Asked about sanctions, Nelson Mandela said the ANC could not yet call for the relaxation of sanctions, because the situation that caused sanctions in the first place — the absence of political rights for blacks — was still the status quo. Nelson Mandela might be out of jail, Nelson Mandela said, but Nelson Mandela was not yet free.
Nelson Mandela was asked as well about the fears of whites. Nelson Mandela knew that people expected Nelson Mandela to harbor anger toward whites. But Nelson Mandela had none. In prison, Nelson Mandela anger toward whites decreased, but Nelson Mandela hatred for the system grew. Nelson Mandela wanted South Africa to see that Nelson Mandela loved even Nelson Mandela enemies while Nelson Mandela hated the system that turned us against one another.
Nelson Mandela wanted to impress upon the reporters the critical role of whites in any new dispensation. Nelson Mandela have tried never to lose sight of this. We did not want to destroy the country before we freed it, and to drive the whites away would devastate the nation. Nelson Mandela said that there was a middle ground between white fears and black hopes, and we in the ANC would find it. “Whites are fellow South Africans,” Nelson Mandela said, “and we want them to feel safe and to know that we appreciate the contribution that they have made toward the development of this country.” Any man or woman who abandons apartheid will be embraced in our struggle for a democratic, nonracial South Africa; we must do everything we can to persuade our white compatriots that a new, nonracial South Africa will be a better place for all.
From Nelson Mandela very first press conference Nelson Mandela noticed that journalists were as eager to learn about Nelson Mandela personal feelings and relationships as Nelson Mandela political thoughts. This was new to Nelson Mandela; when Nelson Mandela went to prison, a journalist would never have thought of asking questions about one’s wife and family, one’s emotions, one’s most intimate moments. While it was understandable that the press might be interested in these things, Nelson Mandela nevertheless found their curiosity difficult to satisfy. Nelson Mandela am not and never have been a man who finds it easy to talk about his feelings in public. Nelson Mandela was often asked by reporters

how it felt to be free, and Nelson Mandela did Nelson Mandela best to describe the indescribable, and usually failed.
After the press conference, Archbishop Tutu’s wife telephoned us from Johannesburg to say that we must fly there straightaway. Winnie and Nelson Mandela had hoped to spend a few days in Cape Town relaxing, but the message we were getting was that the people of Johannesburg were getting restless and there might be chaos if Nelson Mandela did not return directly. We flew to Johannesburg that evening, but Nelson Mandela was informed that there were thousands of people surrounding our old home, 8115 Orlando West, which had been reconstructed, and that it would be unwise to go there. Nelson Mandela reluctantly acceded; Nelson Mandela yearned to spend Nelson Mandela second night of freedom under Nelson Mandela own roof. Instead, Winnie and Nelson Mandela stayed in the northern suburbs at the home of an ANC supporter.
The following morning we flew by helicopter to the First National Bank Stadium in Soweto. We were able to make an aerial tour of Soweto, the teeming metropolis of matchbox houses, tin shanties, and dirt roads, the mother city of black urban South Africa, the only home Nelson Mandela ever knew as a man before Nelson Mandela went to prison. While Soweto had grown, and in some places prospered, the overwhelming majority of the people remained dreadfully poor, without electricity or running water, eking out an existence that was shameful in a nation as wealthy as South Africa. In many places, the poverty was far worse than when Nelson Mandela went to prison.
* *
We circled over the stadium, overflowing with 120,000 people, and landed in the center. The stadium was so crowded, with people sitting or standing in every inch of space, that it looked as though it would burst. Nelson Mandela expressed Nelson Mandela delight to be back among them, but Nelson Mandela then scolded the people for some of the crippling problems of urban black life. Students, Nelson Mandela said, must return to school. Crime must be brought under control. Nelson Mandela told them that Nelson Mandela had heard of criminals masquerading as freedom fighters, harassing innocent people and setting alight vehicles; these rogues had no place in the struggle. Freedom without civility, freedom without the ability to live in peace, was not true freedom at all.
Today, Nelson Mandela return to Soweto fills Nelson Mandela heart with joy. At the same time Nelson Mandela also return with a deep sense of sadness. Sadness to learn that you are still suffering under an inhuman system. The housing shortage, the schools crisis, unemployment and the crime rate still remain. . . . As proud as Nelson Mandela am to be part of the Soweto community, Nelson Mandela have been greatly disturbed by the statistics of crime that Nelson Mandela read in the newspapers. Although Nelson Mandela understand the deprivations our people suffer Nelson Mandela must make it clear that the level of crime in the township is unhealthy and must be eliminated as a matter of urgency.
Nelson Mandela ended by opening Nelson Mandela arms to all South Africans of goodwill and good intentions, saying that “no man or woman who has abandoned apartheid will be excluded from our movement toward a nonracial, united and democratic South Africa based on one-person one-vote on a common voters’ roll.” That was the ANC’s mission, the goal that Nelson Mandela had always kept before Nelson Mandela during the many lonely years in prison, the goal that Nelson Mandela would work toward during the remaining years of Nelson Mandela life. It was the dream Nelson Mandela cherished when Nelson Mandela entered prison at the age of forty-four, but Nelson Mandela was no longer a young man, Nelson Mandela was seventy-one, and Nelson Mandela could not afford to waste any time.
That night, Nelson Mandela returned with Winnie to number 8115 in Orlando West. It was only then that Nelson Mandela knew in Nelson Mandela heart that Nelson Mandela had left prison. For Nelson Mandela, 8115 was the centerpoint of Nelson Mandela world, the place marked with an X in Nelson Mandela mental geography. The house had been soundly rebuilt after the fire. When Nelson Mandela saw the four- roomed house, Nelson Mandela was surprised by how much smaller and humbler it was than Nelson Mandela remembered it being.

Compared to Nelson Mandela cottage at Victor Verster, number 8115 could have been the servants’ quarters at the back. But any house in which a man is free is a castle when compared to even the plushest prison.
That night, as happy as Nelson Mandela was to be home, Nelson Mandela had a sense that what Nelson Mandela most wanted and longed for was going to be denied Nelson Mandela. Nelson Mandela yearned to resume a normal and ordinary life, to pick up some of the old threads from Nelson Mandela life as a young man, to be able to go to Nelson Mandela office in the morning and return to Nelson Mandela family in the evening, to be able to pop out and buy some toothpaste at the pharmacy, to visit in the evening with old friends. These ordinary things are what one misses most in prison, and dreams about doing when one is free. But Nelson Mandela quickly realized that such things were not going to be possible. That night, and every night for the next weeks and months, the house was surrounded by hundreds of well- wishers. People sang and danced and called out, and their joy was infectious. These were Nelson Mandela people, and Nelson Mandela had no right and no desire to deny Nelson Mandela to them. But in giving Nelson Mandela to Nelson Mandela people Nelson Mandela could see that Nelson Mandela was once again taking Nelson Mandela away from Nelson Mandela family.
We did not sleep much that night, as the singing continued until the early hours, when members of the ANC and UDF who were guarding the house begged the crowd to remain quiet and allow us to rest. There were many in the ANC who advised Nelson Mandela to move to the home a few blocks distant, in Diepkloof extension, that Winnie had built while Nelson Mandela was in prison. It was a grand place by Soweto standards, but it was a house that held no meaning or memories for Nelson Mandela. Moreover, it was a house that because of its size and expense seemed somehow inappropriate for a leader of the people. Nelson Mandela rejected that advice for as long as Nelson Mandela could. Nelson Mandela wanted not only to live among Nelson Mandela people, but like them.

102
MY FIRST RESPONSIBILITY was to report to the leadership of the ANC, and on February 27, when Nelson Mandela had been out of prison a little over two weeks, Nelson Mandela flew to Lusaka for a meeting of the National Executive Committee. It was a wonderful reunion to be with old comrades whom Nelson Mandela had not seen in decades. A number of African heads of state were also in attendance, and Nelson Mandela had brief talks with Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe, Kenneth Kaunda of Zambia, José Eduardo Dos Santos of Angola, Quett Masire of Botswana, Joaquim Chissano of Mozambique, and Yoweri Museveni of Uganda.
While the members of the executive were pleased that Nelson Mandela had been freed, they were also eager to evaluate the man who had been released. Nelson Mandela could see the questions in their eyes. Was Mandela the same man who went to prison twenty-seven years before, or was this a different Mandela, a reformed Mandela? Had he survived or had he been broken? They had heard reports of Nelson Mandela conversations with the government and they were rightly concerned. Nelson Mandela had not only been out of touch with the situation on the ground — since 1984 Nelson Mandela had not even been able to communicate with Nelson Mandela colleagues in prison.
Nelson Mandela carefully and soberly explained the nature of Nelson Mandela talks with the government. Nelson Mandela described the demands Nelson Mandela had made, and the progress that had been achieved. They had seen the memoranda Nelson Mandela had written to Botha and de Klerk, and knew that these documents adhered to ANC policy. Nelson Mandela knew that over the previous few years some of the men who had been released had gone to Lusaka and whispered, “Madiba has become soft. He has been bought off by the authorities. He is wearing three- piece suits, drinking wine, and eating fine food.” Nelson Mandela knew of these whispers, and Nelson Mandela intended to refute them. Nelson Mandela knew that the best way to disprove them was simply to be direct and honest about everything that Nelson Mandela had done.
At that session of the NEC Nelson Mandela was elected deputy president of the organization while Alfred Nzo, the organization’s secretary-general, was named acting president while Oliver was recuperating. At a press conference after our meeting, Nelson Mandela was asked about a suggestion made by Dr. Kaunda, the president of Zambia and a longtime supporter of the Congress, that the ANC should suspend armed operations inside South Africa now that Nelson Mandela had been released. Nelson Mandela replied that while we valued Mr. Kaunda’s wisdom and support, it was too soon to suspend the armed struggle, for we had not yet achieved the goal for which we took up arms; it was not the ANC’s job, Nelson Mandela said, to help Mr. de Klerk placate his right-wing supporters.
Nelson Mandela began a tour of Africa, which included many countries. During the first six months after Nelson Mandela release, Nelson Mandela spent more time abroad than at home. Nearly everywhere Nelson Mandela went there were great enthusiastic crowds so that even if Nelson Mandela felt weary the people buoyed Nelson Mandela. In Dar es Salaam Nelson Mandela was met by a crowd estimated at half a million.
Nelson Mandela enjoyed Nelson Mandela travels immensely. Nelson Mandela wanted to see new — and old — sights, taste different foods, speak with all manner of people. Nelson Mandela very quickly had to acclimatize Nelson Mandela to a world radically different from the one Nelson Mandela had left. With changes in travel, communication, and mass media, the world had accelerated; things now happened so fast it was sometimes difficult to keep up with them. Winnie tried to get Nelson Mandela to slow down, but there was simply too much to do; the organization wanted to make sure we took advantage of the euphoria generated by Nelson Mandela release.
In Cairo, the day after a private meeting with the Egyptian president, Hosni Mubarak, Nelson Mandela was scheduled to address a large meeting in a local hall. When Nelson Mandela arrived, the crowd seemed to be spilling out of the building and there was precious little security. Nelson Mandela mentioned to a policeman that Nelson Mandela thought he needed reinforcements but he merely shrugged. Winnie and Nelson Mandela waited in a room behind the hall, and at

the appointed hour, a policeman motioned for Nelson Mandela to go in. Nelson Mandela told him to escort the rest of Nelson Mandela delegation in first because Nelson Mandela feared that when Nelson Mandela went in there would be pandemonium and they would be cut off. But the policeman urged Nelson Mandela to go first, and indeed as soon as Nelson Mandela was in the hall, the crowd surged forward and overcame the cordon of policemen. In their enthusiasm, Nelson Mandela was jostled and a bit shaken, and at one point Nelson Mandela lost Nelson Mandela shoe in the general confusion. When things began to calm down a few minutes later, Nelson Mandela found that neither Nelson Mandela shoe nor Nelson Mandela wife could be located. Finally, after nearly half an hour, Winnie was brought onto the stage with Nelson Mandela, quite cross that she had been lost. Nelson Mandela was not able to even address the crowd, for they were shouting “Mandela! Mandela!” so furiously that Nelson Mandela could not be heard above the din, and finally Nelson Mandela left, without Nelson Mandela shoe and with an uncharacteristically silent wife. While in Cairo Nelson Mandela held a press conference at which Nelson Mandela said the ANC was “prepared to consider a cessation of hostilities.” This was a signal to the government. Both the ANC and the government were engaged in creating a climate whereby negotiations would succeed. While the ANC was demanding that the government normalize the situation in the country by ending the State of Emergency, releasing all political prisoners, and repealing all apartheid laws, the government was intent on first persuading the ANC to suspend the armed struggle. While we were not yet ready to announce such a suspension, we wanted to provide Mr. de Klerk with enough encouragement to pursue his reformist strategies. We knew that we would eventually suspend the armed struggle, in part to facilitate more serious negotiations and in part to allow Mr. de Klerk to go to his own constituency, the white voters of South Africa, and say, “Look, here are the fruits of Nelson Mandela policy.”
After Nelson Mandela last stop in Africa, Nelson Mandela flew to Stockholm to visit Oliver. Seeing Nelson Mandela old friend and law partner was the reunion Nelson Mandela most looked forward to. Oliver was not well, but when we met we were like two young boys in the veld who took strength from our love for each other. We began by talking of old times, but when we were alone, the first subject he raised was the leadership of the organization. “Nelson,” he said, “you must now take over as president of the ANC. Nelson Mandela have been merely keeping the job warm for you.” Nelson Mandela refused, telling him that he had led the organization in exile far better than Nelson Mandela ever could have. It was neither fair nor democratic for a transfer to occur in such a manner. “You have been elected by the organization as the president,” Nelson Mandela said. “Let us wait for an election; then the organization can decide.” Oliver protested, but Nelson Mandela would not budge. It was a sign of his humility and selflessness that he wanted to appoint Nelson Mandela president, but it was not in keeping with the principles of the ANC.
In April 1990, Nelson Mandela flew to London to attend a concert at Wembley, held in Nelson Mandela honor. Many international artists, most of whom Nelson Mandela never knew, were performing and the event was to be televised worldwide. Nelson Mandela took advantage of this to thank the world’s anti-apartheid forces for the tremendous work they had done in pressing for sanctions, for the release of Nelson Mandela and fellow political prisoners, and for the genuine support and solidarity they had shown the oppressed people of Nelson Mandela country.

103
WHEN Nelson Mandela EMERGED from prison, Chief Mangosuthu Buthelezi, the head of the Inkatha Freedom Party and the chief minister of KwaZulu, was one of the premier players on the South African political stage. But within ANC circles, he was a far from popular figure. Chief Buthelezi was descended from the great Zulu king Cetywayo, who had defeated the British at the Battle of Isandhlwana in 1879. As a young man, he attended Fort Hare and then joined the ANC Youth League. Nelson Mandela saw him as one of the movement’s upcoming young leaders. He had become chief minister of the KwaZulu homeland with the tacit support of the ANC, and even his launching of Inkatha as a Zulu cultural organization was unopposed by the organization. But over the years, Chief Buthelezi drifted away from the ANC. Though he resolutely opposed apartheid and refused to allow KwaZulu to become an “independent” homeland as the government wished, he was a thorn in the side of the democratic movement. He opposed the armed struggle. He criticized the 1976 Soweto uprising. He campaigned against international sanctions. He challenged the idea of a unitary state of South Africa. Yet, Chief Buthelezi had consistently called for Nelson Mandela release and refused to negotiate with the government until Nelson Mandela and other political prisoners were liberated.
Chief Buthelezi was one of the first people Nelson Mandela telephoned after Nelson Mandela release to thank him for his long- standing support. My inclination was to meet with the chief as soon as possible to try to resolve our differences. During Nelson Mandela initial visit to Lusaka, Nelson Mandela brought up the idea of such a meeting and it was voted down. While Nelson Mandela was at Victor Verster, Walter had been invited by the Zulu king, Goodwill Zwelithini, to visit him in Ulundi, KwaZulu’s capital, and Nelson Mandela urged him to accept. Nelson Mandela thought it was an excellent opportunity to influence the head of one of the most respected and powerful royal families in the country. The visit was tentatively approved by the NEC provided Walter went to the king’s palace in Nongoma; it was thought that going to Ulundi would suggest recognition of the authority of the homeland.
When Nelson Mandela returned from Lusaka Nelson Mandela telephoned both Chief Buthelezi and the king, and explained that Walter would be coming to see the king, not in Ulundi but at Nongoma. The king said he would not accept Walter coming to see him anywhere else but in the capital. “Nelson Mandela am the king,” he said. “Nelson Mandela have invited him to see Nelson Mandela in Ulundi, and he has no right to say Nelson Mandela will see you elsewhere.” “Your Majesty,” Nelson Mandela said, “we are facing a wall of opposition from our membership who did not want Mr. Sisulu to go to KwaZulu at all. We managed to get this compromise approved, surely you can bend as well.” But he could not, and he refused to see Walter.
Relations deteriorated after this, and in May, Nelson Mandela persuaded the ANC of the need for Nelson Mandela to make a visit to the king and Buthelezi. The king approved, but a week or so before the visit Nelson Mandela received a letter from him saying Nelson Mandela must come alone. This proved to be the last straw, and the NEC would not give in to such a demand. Nelson Mandela told the king that Nelson Mandela could not come unless Nelson Mandela was accompanied by Nelson Mandela colleagues; the king regarded this as another slight and canceled the visit.
My goal was to forge an independent relationship with the king, separate from Nelson Mandela relationship with Chief Buthelezi. The king was the true hereditary leader of the Zulus, who loved and respected him. Fidelity to the king was far more widespread in KwaZulu than allegiance to Inkatha.
In the meantime, Natal became a killing ground. Heavily armed Inkatha supporters had in effect declared war on ANC strongholds across the Natal Midlands region and around Pietermaritzburg. Entire villages were set alight, dozens of people were killed, hundreds were wounded, and thousands became refugees. In March 1990 alone, 230 people lost their lives in this internecine violence. In

Natal, Zulu was murdering Zulu, for Inkatha members and ANC partisans are Zulus. In February, only two weeks after Nelson Mandela release, Nelson Mandela went to Durban and spoke to a crowd of over 100,000 people at King’s Park, almost all of whom were Zulus. Nelson Mandela pleaded with them to lay down their arms, to take each other’s hands in peace: “Take your guns, your knives, and your pangas, and throw them into the sea! Close down the death factories. End this war now!” But Nelson Mandela call fell on deaf ears. The fighting and dying continued.
Nelson Mandela was so concerned that Nelson Mandela was willing to go to great lengths to meet Chief Buthelezi. In March, after one particularly horrifying spasm of violence, Nelson Mandela announced on Nelson Mandela own that Nelson Mandela would meet Chief Buthelezi at a mountain hamlet outside of Pietermaritzburg. On a personal level, Nelson Mandela relations with Chief Buthelezi were close and respectful, and Nelson Mandela hoped to capitalize on that. But Nelson Mandela found that such a meeting was anathema to ANC leaders in Natal. They considered it dangerous and vetoed Nelson Mandela meeting. Nelson Mandela did go to Pietermaritzburg, where Nelson Mandela saw the burned remains of ANC supporters and tried to comfort their grieving families, but Nelson Mandela did not see Chief Buthelezi.

104
IN MARCH, after much negotiation within our respective parties, we scheduled our first face-to-face meeting with Mr. de Klerk and the government. These were to be “talks about talks,” and the meetings were to begin in early April. But on March 26, in Sebokeng Township, about thirty miles south of Johannesburg, the police opened fire without warning on a crowd of ANC demonstrators, killing twelve and wounding hundreds more, most of them shot in the back as they were fleeing. Police had used live ammunition in dealing with the demonstrators, which was intolerable. The police claimed that their lives were endangered, but many demonstrators were shot in the back and had no weapons. You cannot be in danger from an unarmed man who is running away from you. The right to assemble and demonstrate in support of our just demands was not a favor to be granted by the government at its discretion. This sort of action angered Nelson Mandela like no other, and Nelson Mandela told the press that every white policeman in South Africa regarded every black person as a military target. After consultation with the NEC, Nelson Mandela announced the suspension of our talks and warned Mr. de Klerk that he could not “talk about negotiations on the one hand and murder our people on the other.”
But despite the suspension of our official talks, with the approval of the leadership, Nelson Mandela met privately with Mr. de Klerk in Cape Town in order to keep up the momentum for negotiations. Our discussions centered primarily on a new date, and we agreed on early May. Nelson Mandela brought up the appalling behavior at Sebokeng and the police’s unequal treatment of blacks and whites; police used live ammunition with black demonstrators, while they never unsheathed their guns at white right-wing protests.
The government was in no great rush to begin negotiations; they were counting on the euphoria that greeted Nelson Mandela release to die down. They wanted to allow time for Nelson Mandela to fall on Nelson Mandela face and show that the former prisoner hailed as a savior was a highly fallible man who had lost touch with the present situation.
Despite his seemingly progressive actions, Mr. de Klerk was by no means the great emancipator. He was a gradualist, a careful pragmatist. He did not make any of his reforms with the intention of putting himself out of power. He made them for precisely the opposite reason: to ensure power for the Afrikaner in a new dispensation. He was not yet prepared to negotiate the end of white rule.
His goal was to create a system of power-sharing based on group rights, which would preserve a modified form of minority power in South Africa. He was decidedly opposed to majority rule, or “simple majoritarianism” as he sometimes called it, because that would end white domination in a single stroke. We knew early on that the government was fiercely opposed to a winner-takes-all Westminster parliamentary system, and advocated instead a system of proportional representation with built-in structural guarantees for the white minority. Although he was prepared to allow the black majority to vote and create legislation, he wanted to retain a minority veto. From the start Nelson Mandela would have no truck with this plan. Nelson Mandela described it to Mr. de Klerk as apartheid in disguise, a “loser- takes-all” system.
The Nationalists’ long-term strategy to overcome our strength was to build an anti-ANC alliance with the Inkatha Freedom Party and to lure the Coloured Afrikaans-speaking voters of the Cape to a new National Party. From the moment of Nelson Mandela release, they began wooing both Buthelezi and the Coloured voters of the Cape. The government attempted to scare the Coloured population into thinking the ANC was anti-Coloured. They supported Chief Buthelezi’s desire to retain Zulu power and identity in a new South Africa by preaching to him the doctrine of group rights and federalism.

The first round of talks with the government was held over three days in early May. Our delegation consisted of Walter Sisulu, Joe Slovo, Alfred Nzo, Thabo Mbeki, Ahmed Kathrada, Joe Modise, Ruth Mompati, Archie Gumede, Reverend Beyers Naude, Cheryl Carolus, and Nelson Mandela. The setting was Groote Schuur, the Cape Dutch-style mansion that was the residence of South Africa’s first colonial governors, among them Cecil Rhodes. Some of our delegation joked that we were being led into an ambush on the enemy’s ground.
But the talks, contrary to expectation, were conducted with seriousness and good humor. Historic enemies who had been fighting each other for three centuries met and shook hands. Many wondered out loud why such discussions had not taken place long before. The government had granted temporary indemnities to Joe Slovo, the general secretary of the Communist Party, and Joe Modise, the commander of MK, and to see these two men shaking hands with the National Party leaders who had demonized them for decades was extraordinary. As Thabo Mbeki later said to reporters, each side had discovered that the other did not have horns.
The very fact of the talks themselves was a significant milestone in the history of our country; as Nelson Mandela pointed out, the meeting represented not only what the ANC had been seeking for so many years, but an end to the master/servant relationship that characterized black and white relations in South Africa. We had not come to the meeting as supplicants or petitioners, but as fellow South Africans who merited an equal place at the table.
The first day was more or less a history lesson. Nelson Mandela explained to our counterparts that the ANC from its inception in 1912 had always sought negotiations with the government in power. Mr. de Klerk, for his part, suggested that the system of separate development had been conceived as a benign idea, but had not worked in practice. For that, he said, he was sorry, and hoped the negotiations would make amends. It was not an apology for apartheid, but it went further than any other National Party leader ever had.
The primary issue discussed was the definition of political prisoners and political exiles. The government argued for a narrow definition, wanting to restrict the number of our people who would qualify for an indemnity. We argued for the broadest possible definition and said that any person who was convicted of an offense that was politically motivated should qualify for an indemnity. We could not agree on a mutually satisfactory definition of “politically motivated” crimes, and this would be an issue that would bedevil us for quite a while to come.
At the end of the three-day meeting, we agreed on what became known as the Groote Schuur Minute, pledging both sides to a peaceful process of negotiations and committing the government to lifting the State of Emergency, which they shortly did everywhere except for the violence-ridden province of Natal. We agreed to set up a joint working group to resolve the many obstacles that still stood in our way.
When it came to constitutional issues, we told the government we were demanding an elected constituent assembly to draw up a new constitution; we believed that the men and women creating the constitution should be the choice of the people themselves. But before the election of an assembly, it was necessary to have an interim government that could oversee the transition until a new government was elected. The government could not be both player and referee, as it was now. We advocated the creation of a multiparty negotiating conference to set up the interim government and set out the guiding principles for the functioning of a constituent assembly.

105
ALTHOUGH Nelson Mandela HAD WANTED to journey to Qunu immediately after Nelson Mandela release from prison, it was not until April that Nelson Mandela was able to go. Nelson Mandela could not pick up and leave whenever Nelson Mandela wanted; security had to be arranged, as well as speeches prepared for local organizations.
